RATING: 8
Scales well 2-5 players, beautifully produced, great introductory game. A bit of luck around the ticket draw but this is fine for this length and weight of game (light-middle). An essential purchase for anyone who plays with casual gamers or for serious gamers who occassionally like something lighter. The Europe map provides some variety and the ticket distribution is an improvement but the rest of the new rules detract from the game. The passenger rules in Marklin are excellent but make the game that little bit too long and the board is a bit too biased to completing tickets. I probably prefer the base game particularly now the 1910 cards have been released

Anyway, that's why it's best for non-gamers and certainly worth a try for gamers too.

I saw the reviews and BGG rating but every time I was close to dropping the cash for it, I would look at the components, look at the theme, and go, "erm, no." Turns out it is a well made game with a tight system that is accessible to nearly everyone no matter what their level of game experience.
Moral? Do not judge a book (or game) by it's cover.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
[I]tl;dr Ticket to Ride is a modern-day classic, deserves to be in most collections as a good intro set-collection game.[/I] 
[COLOR=#CCCCFF]____________________________[/COLOR]

Ticket to Ride is a classic along the level of Catan, and I definitely enjoy its simplicity and elegance. It's a very simple mechanic, but the player competition and the unknown aspect of the cards makes it different every time. 

Basically, players are competing to build train routes along different colored tracks throughout the United States. They accomplish this by drawing cards of the correct color, then claiming routes by placing their own trains along the route. 

You earn points by completing Tickets (preset routes that you draw from the ticket deck), placing routes, and winning the longest connected route, which is similar to the Longest Road in Settlers of Catan. 

Overall, I enjoy Ticket to Ride, but I don't feel the need to have it in my collection. It's definitely worth some plays even if you're a hardcore gamer, and the rules can be gone over in about fifteen minutes. This makes Ticket to Ride a great choice for new or reluctant gamers, since it's really easy to have a fun time with it. Personally, I prefer introducing people with [thing=123540][/thing] instead.

RATING: 8
A good light game with little downtime and relatively quick play. After playing with two different sets of friends in 4-player games, I can see the criticism of this game being multiplayer solitaire. The games were pretty quiet as everyone went about playing their routes. Still, a good game that I enjoy playing.

Update (11/2010): After many more plays, the multiplayer solitaire element diminishes once people know the game better. More interaction/blocking. Enjoying playing this with my wife and our 2 1/2 year old daughter likes to do "jobs" like picking cards, laying trains, etc.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
A true joy of a game to play. One which owing to the cartoonish box art, I walked by many a time but glad my gut feeling kept drawing me back for another look.

Extremely simple to learn and teach, with multiple strategies for victory. Play ethically or ruthlessly, this game is packed to the rafters with that "just on more try" feeling and a very peaceful flow.

Well expanded by the "1910" game pack, once players become attuned to each other's devious minds, city objectives and ways to play are manifestly mulitplied.

Hard to play solitaire (a web/PC version caters for this), this is a gem for 2-3 people, though the game does cater for a competitive 5. Extremely well suited for husbands and wives, guys and gals. Bound to create some fun-borne controversy for discussion (or moody glances) whilst watching TV after.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
One of those games that just screams "instant classic". I remember seeing it on the table of the game shop I would frequent when I lived in Seattle, being played consistently. Anybody can sink their teeth into this one and enjoy themselves.

While I find Ticket to Ride to maybe be a little too simple in execution, it gets serious points for being intuitive and easy to teach. There's really no reason not to own this game, since it's a bulls-eye for introducing new people to the hobby. The component quality is rock-solid and the pace of the game is a quick clip, giving just the right amount of time to plan out your next move before it's your turn again. 

And, considering how straightforward the game is, it has a decent amount of freedom in strategy. Depending on how things are playing out, it may be best to just try for all of the six train routes, or maybe you're feeling cutthroat and just want to prevent other players from completing their routes. I've even seen a player do a mad grab for more route tickets at the end of the game, in order to hopefully have fulfilled them already. Which worked!

Ticket to Ride may seem like a bit of a relic at this point, but it's status as a go-to gateway game or simple competition isn't a question in my mind.

2013/01
To be honest, I'll turn down a game on certain occasions. TtR has grown slightly old.
8->7 

2014/10
Original = Best for families with 4-5 players, elegant rules, suffers from card hoarding strategy

Märklin = Most satisfactory for gamers, strong incentive to make early plays mitigating the hoarding problem, a bit fiddly

Nordic = Best for families with 2-3 players, slight hoarding problems which are mitigated by the tight map, random take that aspects due to the tunnel mechanics

Europe = worst of the bunch in all aspects

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What a good game!  It works well with any number of players from 2-5, but plays very differently with each.  I use different tactics accordingly.  It's light, colourful, well made, simple to play, but with plenty to make you think.  It's not as deep as some German-style games, but it's elegant and fun and much better than Santa Fe and several other rail games.  Tactically, it's hard to tie down.  I've won by going for a few long tickets, lots of shorter tickets, playing for long (5 and 6) routes, dominating the middle of the board, dominating a side, going North to South, East to West.  And of course, most often I lose, anyway!  It's this hard to tie down quality added to the fun factor that makes me return to it so often.  I'll play this anytime.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Another one of the modern classics. A cornerstone of my family's collection. 

Anyone from an 8 year old kid to your 80 year old grandmother can learn this game in 10 minutes, and the theme, construction, bits, mechanics, and replayability rock. 

Recommended for parents who want to get their kids into the tabletop hobby, and for anyone who wants a simple, enjoyable, and dependable workhorse to introduce to new gamers. It can be arbitrary/random, and it isn't without flaws, but it's worth the price of admission.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
A good gateway game, I prefer the Europe map to add a bit more complexity and to ease the pressure with station tokens for blocked routes, otherwise it can be too easy to be completely blocked. Not a game I tend to seek out but with new/non-gamers it's a nice introductory game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Ok, so it's not the DEEPEST game.  A lot depends on luck - which destination cards you draw and which your opponent(s) draw.  Two player games are over faster than my wife would like, but she's always ready to go again.  The more you play, though, the more strategies open up.  Blocking becomes enjoyable to try and accomplish, though it's not very apparent WHO you should block.  It also becomes important to watch how many trains your opponent(s) have left - in that it reminds me of Lost Cities (among others) where you have to be aware of when the game will end.

Most of all, though, this game is FUN.  And I've enjoyed every time I've played it - and how often can you say that?

RATING: 2
Played this three player and I thought the winner had skunked both of us. But then I did the math. At one point in the game the winner played on the last two spaces going into Los Angeles one turn before I was going to play on them. This allowed him to complete a route and screwed me out of completing a route. This resulted in a 90+ point swing of the final score. Had I played on those two points first the winner would have tied me for second place. Any game that allows such a huge swing in scoring by such a minor play is broken in my opinion.

RATING: 6
A gateway game, but it's one I introduced to my wife and we play over and over.  Easy to learn and easy to play and the games are less than half an hour. Another interesting fact is that the optimal strategy in a 2-player game is not the optimal strategy in a 4-player game.  Eventually, you can figure out the optimal strategy and then to some extent, it becomes a luck-of-the-draw game.  It took a LOT of plays for us to figure it out, but because of that, I downgraded it, because the replay factor is evaporating.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I played this game just once, so these are mostly impressions that may change after multiple plays.

There're games with simple rules that are lots of fun. This game is not one of them. Ticket to Ride is not a bad game by any means but it is a very mediocre and disappointing one. I saw countless reviews and game-plays before buying it... and the game never sounded fun to me, but I ended up picking up a copy anyway. I needed a good gateway game to introduce people to the hobby during my Erasmus scholarship and on-line tons of people kept going over and over about Ticket to Ride being the best of them. So I decided to try it.

I understand that this is my opinion and experience, but Ticket to Ride really didn't work for me. I sincerely don't understand what is the fun of collecting cards turn after turn after turn, until you can finally play something. There's some tactics involved for sure, but the mechanics are really not exciting. It's the just same thing over and over again! Furthermore every time I played it, Ticket to Ride felt too long for what it is. I ended up wishing for the game to end and ironically so did the other people at the table: those that I wanted to introduce to board-gaming. I understand that TtR is a simple family game and it was wrong from me to expect more... maybe the hype ruined this for me, but I can also name a bunch of other family games that are way more fun and way better as gateway game. Terribly mediocre game.

The United Kingdom/Pennsylvania expansion brought some new life into this game and it actually made me enjoy it more. Yet I still think that Ticket to Ride is an average game that doesn't work for me.

Rating without expansion: 5.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
FAVOURITE GAME - Ticket to Ride is a cross-country train adventure game. Players collect train cards that enable them to claim railway routes connecting cities throughout North America. The longer the routes, the more points they earn. Additional points come to those who can fulfill their Destination Tickets by connecting two distant cities, and to the player who builds the longest continuous railway. It is one of the best family games I have tried until now. With the simple rules and relatively fast playing time it catches on very quickly. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I've found people who dislike Settlers or Dominion, but no one who really dislikes Ticket to Ride, and most love it. My PARENTS will play it! Probably helps that the base game is the USA map. Won the Spiel des Jahres. Rated a little higher than others because it's really easy to explain. Rules: http://www.daysofwonder.com/tickettoride/en/content/rules_tt/

RATING: 6.5
Just doesn't grab me.  I can see its gateway potential, but the rules seem to me to cry out for the thing to be played with spoiler-style nastiness.  For some reason, we just don't do it that way, and as a result it's pretty blah.

Update: I think the problem is that the disincentive for spoiling play is so great - you miss a turn.  But what if there was a rule allowing you to lay down n-1 cards instead of the required n as long as the rails you were claiming shared an endpoint town with the last player's move?

RATING: 8
Einsteigerspiel
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Ticket to Ride isn't my first choice. Ever.

However, it has endured in my collection as a favourite of family members and has endeared itself to me over the years I've owned it. 

Strategy gamers can struggle to understand casual/family gamers and how accessability is a really big deal for them. Ticket to Ride is completely accessible and provides that sense of building something, together, while also taking the edge off confrontation (which is present, but subtle). 

Although I don't love it, I tried my hand at 'train', pickup-and-deliver, and other route-building games and I'd still rather play this. I'm terrible at it, but I always seem to have some fun playing :).

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.3
A railway game which players have to build railway tracks based on the colours of the railways cards players possess.  Mission cards are present in the game which helps players to gain more points if they manage to link up a chain of cities.  At the start of the game, players are given the chance to change mission cards but once the game is played, the mission cards could not be exchanged anymore.  Deduction of points at the end of the game if objectives of mission cards could not be accomplished.

Good points: Easy to play.  Mission cards are present so that players will choose their cards wisely before the game even starts.

Bad points: This game resides too much on luck.  There is no actions which players can decide on the railway cards to be chosen.  Missions cards are also given by random.  Though it can be exchanged, players can

This game is similar to Thurn and Taxis with connecting railway routes instead of postal routes.  With less decision making components in Ticket to Ride, I would think that Ticket to Ride is less appealing to me.  During the game, I felt that that is hardly anything I can do to affect the game.  Of course, I can connect a railway to disrupt the mission of another player but that is only when I can get the necessary cards in hand and I have guessed the mission correctly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Good game with solid rules. Very enjoyable.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
So, I recently played the original TtR (with Mystery Train edition). We ended up playing a variant that I made up - I separated the 17-22 pt long routes and distributed them as one of the route cards at the beginning of the game. All discards are still returned to the bottom of the deck, so if someone ends up picking a long route later (even with the Engineer card), that's fine. I only wanted to even out the beginning routes so that everyone has an opportunity to keep a long route ticket. 

With 5 players, TtR becomes too chaotic and less strategic - it's more of a frantic scramble to complete the first route. Perhaps TtR makes a better 4 player game. Played Ticket to Ride several times before I started tracking my games played (approx. 2-5 times). Tracked on family game list (grooven).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It is so hard to describe my relationship with Ticket to Ride. I got it for Christmas from my girlfriend because I really wanted it. At this point I had begun to play games such as Puerto Rico and El Grande. I had also been branching out to try other games as well. The first time I played Ticket to Ride it didn't seem to have the spark or staying power that El Grande (my current favorite) had. My family enjoyed it and that was great so it got played at home, but when I brought it to school there was a lukewarm reaction to it.

It sat shelved for months until the summer when I tried to get together a weekly gaming group. Ticket to Ride was my game of choice for indoctrinating new gamers because it supported a larger group of players better than Carcassonne. At first I did not see how there was a lot of strategy in the game. All of the meaningful decisions seemed to be made when you picked your tickets (before you even start the game); however, the more I played the more I realized that board position was important. Long routes are better than short routes, regardless of what type of ticket to you have. You have to balance your important priorities now vs. your long term goals.

I came back to school with a renewed sense of how to play and love this game and I was lucky enough to find a lot of people who share my love for it. It is one of the games that gets pulled out the most often now which is great, because it is truly a great game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
2-5(4)

It's a great, great, great gateway. Probably the best I've encountered. (A good metric is what my "I've got two kids, I'm playing a game, I don't want to work" sister thinks of it, and she would play this one again). It's incidentally, and non-confrontationally, interactive (until you get more advanced, in which case you start to tactically block).

There are some "more dominant" strategies: I can see accumulating lots of cards, getting long routes and then, after your network is established, cycling tickets being really hard to beat. But it's Ticket to Ride! If you're playing that way against people you're trying to introduce to gaming, you're not doing "gateway" very well. Not saying that you should try to lose, but don't break the game.

People (correctly) say that it's basically set collection. Sure, but it's easy to get, attractive, and all of it feels thematic enough (and not tacked on) to really engage players. Not something I'll always play, but a go-to gateway, easily.

RATING: 7
Returning to Ticket to Ride after a long break, I found a game I'd thought rather average that was actually pretty enjoyable.  It remains a simple game and yet the choke points on the board and the pressure to complete that ticket before somebody blocks you (or the game ends) creates a good tension.  I still find the luck of the ticket draw somewhat problematic and in future will propose separating the long and short tickets as the Europe version first did.

The Days of Wonder production can't be faulted and the card art is particularly evocative.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ticket to Ride (w/ USA 1910 expansion) is fairly light, medium length, and easy to learn.  Overall, I think the game could be a touch shorter, to balance the degree of luck with drawing tickets.  I don't really mind the tickets and their push-your-luck effect since I like a degree of managing probabilities in a game, and I do enjoy games with spatial contention.

I liked the USA 1910 expansion, and was told that it helps fix some design problems TtR (Ticket to Ride).

OVERALL: I've enjoyed playing TtR and will play again, though preferably w/ the USA 1910 expansion.

RECOMMENDATIONS: TtR fans interested in a shorter game with a bit more push-your-luck should certainly check out Ra (http://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/12).  For fans of the spatial aspects of TtR, Through the Desert (http://www.boardgamegeek.com/game/503) is an absolute gem of a game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Includes:
[thing=14996][/thing]
[thing=53383][/thing]
[thing=106637][/thing]

:arrowE: [u]Synopsis[/u]:
Rummy played with a board and fancy trains. Draw train cards and play them in sets to construct routes between cities. Use destination cards to allow for scoring completed routes across the continent. Draw two cards of your choice, or draw from the pile blind, or take a single wild train. Once a player gets down to two or fewer available trains, the last round is triggered. It's basic, but compelling.

:arrowE: [u]What I like most[/u]:
The base game is bland, even for a gateway game. TTR: Europe adds just enough complexity to make the system more interesting, but it's really TTR: Team Asia that provides the evergreen rating I ascribe to Ticket to Ride. Team Asia adds a sort of blind, mostly-cooperative aspect to scoring for a pair of players, wherein a single tray of train cards are shared between both and can be used by either player, but the individual hands of train cards and destination cards are still hidden from each other. This creates a great sense of industrialist cooperation in a time period where neither company has complete access to each other's planning. I love it. It's fun. It's hilarious. It makes for a lot of "YES! I hoped you would do that!" and "GAH, I needed those! No!" moments. If you can read the actions of your teammate, you can do very, very well.

:arrowE: [u]What I like least[/u]:
Overall, I find Ticket to Ride can be boring for some new players who might do better with "deeper" entry points, and  I need to get a good gauge on what I should expect from beginners. Should we start with the base or Europe? Should we add Asia? Should we just play a different game? I see TTR as a tool more than a game I want to go out of my way to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

[4]2-5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
The new standard for entry games. The 1910 expansion is essential die to the small train cards and destination tickets found in the base game. 

Complexity - simple, you draw cards, place trains from cards in hand, or draw new tickets

Strategy - moderate, you have to be flexible. Being bold and managing your trains will net you a high score but you have to be timely and efficient or the game will end too soon for you. 

Luck - moderate, you have no say in what cards are available, what routes and train cards you draw randomly, only how to place them. Even the most flexible strategies can get beat by a good draw. 

Interaction - very high. Almost everything you do effects other players. There is a chance nobody will want to go to the areas you do or get the colored trains you have but that is not the case most of the time. 

Fun - with the luck factor moderate many skill levels can compete and first time players can even win. You can enjoy this game with friends but not if you are hoping a grand matter plan will win you the game for certain.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Simple and bold.  Ticket to ride is like Rummy with trains.  While the gameplay hardly paves any roads unpaved, it just does everything so well, and you can't help but love it.  Even though the Rummy style gameplay, with matching train colors is not representative at all to the theme.  The overall thought process, when playing, is.  Players take on tickets to link far away cities for big points, and other players battle to be the first to lay track on certain routes.  The coordination of all this equals a brilliant game, the whole family can play.

RATING: 2
Not much interaction or fun, and highly derivative of other games. It seemed to drag with five players, and no one tried blocking anyone else; it just seems to be a case of "collect cards and play them."  (Same thing in my second play, with four players -- no one really focuses on anything except their own goals.  If any blocking occurred it was unwitting.) A step above Transamerica, but that's not saying much. Don't understand why people play it, much less rate it highly. Only strategy is to try to make long chains; shorter ones are almost worthless. I'm sure this game made Mr. Moon a millionaire, but I just don't see it.

RATING: 5
I just don't get this game. I mean I get it. I just don't get what all the fuss is about. You draw color cards so you can later play them to play train tokens on matching color tracks to make routes that hopefully you can match to the tickets you drew earlier else you will lose a ton of points. It's not that the game is bad, I just don't get why it's such a stand out to so many people. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A real fun game, Ticket to Ride is simple to play and games are pretty quick. The route system (and rather, how it's randomly handed out at the start of the game) can put players at a disadvantage, but the real point winners in this game are the six-length train routes. Games between experienced players can be pretty fun, because you start to get a good feel for what routes the other guy has, so it's easier to be a bit more cutthroat.The 'resource' system of drawing cards is very well done; Even if you draw resources you can't use, the ability to 'cash' them in for five and 6 length train routes (and big points) makes sure that the player isn't frustrated by his bad 'luck.' In fact, building a giant hand of cards is a pretty good strategy, allowing you to pick and choose the routes you take.The game is extremely easy to teach to new players, and while a great game with only two players, is still a lot of fun with 3 to 5. A game you can't go wrong with!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I love this game. Easy to teach and learn. Best part is that it has a lot of expansions.

RATING: 9.5
Purchased in 2012 after playing with Jennifer and Josh
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
It's better than some of the terrible classic board games, but this gateway game was still too close to them for me to enjoy.

You look at the board and identify some cities to connect.  Even this is going to be heavily influenced by the city connection bonus cards you are randomly dealt.  And then you draw cards that have the color you need.  And you draw and draw and draw.  

Decision making time is over.  Now you sit and take turns drawing cards to see who's plan is going to work out best.

It's not quite that terrible.  You can sometimes spot an opening and slightly modify your plan or take advantage of an opening to block an opponent, but it really isn't that interesting.

Ultimately, the meaningful decision making offered by the game doesn't come close to the amount of time you spend trying to collect matching sets of colored cards in your hand.  It's just a fancy Rummy variant.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
PROS:
*) Simple, elegant rules
*) Planning ahead is important
*) Stays interesting all game long, because you can never be sure who's leading
CONS:
*) Some luck involved on what combination of destination tickets you get
*) Little player interaction (route blocking, and grabbing cards of the same color are the only ones)

RATING: 9
This game is a hit with virtually everyone I've introduced to it, even observers.  People can get locked into Settlers if you show them that first, and Ingenious works too but doesn't seem to really get people going on other stuff.  I've found that people will actually play other games after TTR, though.  Playing online will make you realize how often you're drawing, but also illustrates how much skill can be a factor; if you play top players in 2P games, you will get smoked.  TTR:Europe appears to be more popular as a "gamer's game," but I think that's a ruse as it effectively eliminates blocking as a major tactic.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of the easiest to teach games available.  Game play is straight forward.  There is a significant luck element in the ticket draws, but the train car draws are more strategic since the players can select the color of their choice from the ones displayed.  Watching other players picks will also give an edge in predicting where they may play.  Highly playable, quick, and enjoyable.  Not a gamers' game, but a solid light fun game nonetheless.  [GTI Code: TGCL]

RATING: 6.5
Rules are so simple, it's easy to explain and play, but involves a lot of thinking.

seems like best strategy is to horde cards and then make your move all at once.

the strategy of trying to block people doesn't really work.  You just waste your pieces and they most likely just path right around you with no issues.

fun with more than 2 people.  very "take that!" when playing one on one.

I'm usually up for a game, but not really that excited about more than one game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
First Game: 13 Oct. 2007
Played this with 6 player using my 6-player variant and it worked wonderfully.  I just grabbed another set of trains from TtR: Marklin and we were set to go.  However, we were running out of tickets fast and I need to get 1910 to supplement this.

I prefer this so much more to TtR:Marklin.  It has far less rules overhead for the same approximate amount of depth.  Also It was much easier to handle 6 players.  The things that I do miss from TtR: Marklin is the bonus points for completing the most amount of tickets and splitting the tickets into two decks of short and long tickets.  Next time I'll just split them up, Marklin style.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The third game in the gateway "Holy Trimurti" (Settlers of Catan and Carcassonne being the other two), it's simple and funny and well worth a play or three when you have some non-gamer friend and you want to give him his first dose of eurogaming drugs...
Ticket to Ride can be just a very simple set collection game, but the competition on the map contributes to a tense gameplay: mr. Moon delivered a home run (as far as you want a gateway game) and did deserve his Spiel des Jahres!

Update august 30th, 2012: after I bought the iOS version of TTR Europe, physical versions of the game had seen play again, and I must admit the light fare is quite enjoyable... vote raised to 6.5!

Update january 1st, 2015: the game sees the table quite often, thanks to the in-laws and the iOS version. Vote raised to 7.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Have to use more of the 1910 components in the next game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Now that I own and have played Ticket to Ride I am amazed by comparisons I have read regarding this and TransAmerica.  Aside from both being about trains and situated in North America, they are nothing alike.

In Ticket to Ride hand management plays a key role in winning or losing.  I enjoy how different strategies regarding route cards come into play after mulitple playings.  For anyone who enjoys rummy and it's variants, this game is for you.  I also feel that the game scales very well from two to five players.  

I believe, and it's been proven, that this is an excellent gateway game for non-gamers.   I wouldn't mind a variant with trading of route cards or train cards, but then again, I could do it on my own.

RATING: 8
The artwork and quality of the trains, cars and board should be applauded. There is a good pace to this game that I like: it seldom drags along (unless some people unnecessarily over-analyse), is great for newbies to pick up and has enough variety from game to game to prevent over-familiarity, monotony, predictability and boredom. There is enough luck-element in the game which prevents it from being totally strategy-based. For some of us, a bit of luck is a good, though sometimes frustrating thing!

RATING: 9
[b]Spiel des Jahres 2004[/b]
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 6th Place 2004[/SIZE][/COLOR]

[i]Posted: 9/20/05, Rated: 10[/i]

I love this game!  Its theme is wonderfully romantic, its concepts are easy to learn, and it looks great while playing.  It can be confrontational or not, depending on your preference.  My seven year-old son won convincingly in his second game.

But perhaps the most telling is this comment from my wife "I would definitely play that game again!"  Any title that has that effect on her should be rated an eleven.

[i]Updated: 12/24/09, Rated: 9[/i]

[i]Ticket to Ride[/i] is still a fantastic gateway game.  However, it has reached a point where it feels "solved:" strategically place a couple of key routes (I'll leave the discovery of them up to the reader), and then raid the "tickets" deck.  It also ends up being a game where you draw, and draw, and draw, and draw, and draw, and draw, and draw, and draw, and draw, and draw, and draw, trying to push your luck one more turn before finally buying a segment.  My wife and her friends still like to play, so this will remain a "9" due to its mass appeal.

[url=http://www.boardgameswithscott.com/?p=19]BGWS Review[/url]

RATING: 8
Very fun game on the lighter side. The wife and I play often, as well as with other people while visiting. Very easy to get into and easy to play. 

The train cards could have been a little bigger to make for easier shuffling. Other than that, the components are good.

I do notice that the players picking W-E routes seem to win more often than people picking N-S routes although that's just me and we play it more to have fun than for any serious level of competitiveness.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This game is mildly entertaining when the group plays quickly, and mind-numbingly boring when the group plays slowly. If my entire turn is to draw two cards, and then I have to wait five minutes until my next turn, I'd simply rather not play the game. But if people play quickly enough to keep me engaged, I'm willing to play a game now and then. Additionally, I think Carcassonne, Settlers of Catan, Fjords, Through the Desert, and a host of other games are more interesting 'gateway games' than Ticket to Ride, further reducing its appeal to me. On iOS, the game is more enjoyable (less upkeep, faster pace), but still doesn't offer much in the way of interesting decisions or a particularly enjoyable experience -- perhaps a 5 or 6 rather than a 4. (2011-11; updated 2012-03; minor text edits after)

RATING: 3

Now eclipsed by much better clever games in my collection. Rating reduced to 6.

In fact so eclipsed its traded. Uwe Rosenberg says its broken and having heard his reasons I believe him.

Reviewed in 2012 and I'm somewhat ashamed to have believed this to be tactical. This game is the epitome of randomness and represents most of the attributes that I really dislike in a game. Rating cut to 3.

RATING: 8
Who doesn't know about this game at this point? The best "gateway" games are those that you can use to introduce others to the hobby while still being a game seasoned gamers want to play. That's where this game falls for me. Do you play nice or try to cut off everyone's routes? Do you go for more tickets and hope for synergy or risk getting burned? Do you take that faceup locomotive or take two off the top? It's not a game I want to play all the time but I really enjoy it when I do.

RATING: 7.5

There is no deep strategy here and there is certainly luck in the draw of tickets, but it moves fast and it is so enjoyable to play.  This game provides excellent tension and gives a sense of satisfaction as you complete tickets.  It doesn't hurt that the components are great looking and that it is one of my wife's favorite game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fun, but can get a bit long at times.  The planning and strategy is fun, and occasionally you are forced to improvise when you get beat to the punch on claiming certain tracks.  It's also interesting how you can play friendly or agressive depending on the group you are gaming with.  My biggest beef is with the claiming of route cards.  For some reason it seems to take players way too long to decide, and if you don't wait they may change their decisions based on what other players do while they're choosing.

I have found that the game has a very wide appeal and many non-gamers will jump right on board for this game.  The rules are simple and the strategies aren't too deep so almost anyone can play.  I should mention that I find the 1910 expansion to be almost a requirement.  Still this game, even without the expansion, is fun and can be played by almost anyone.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Steve
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Bought it from a friend after playing a few times. Nice game to play with family and friends, who don't like too complex or strategic games. After starting with the card-hoarding tactic and all other players followed, the game wasn't really fun any more. Then everyone in the game was taking 2 cards until there were almost none left and then building stretches requiring 5 or 6 trains to get maximum points.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Probably one of the better casual games I've ever played.  The strategy isn't very intense, although there are certainly tense moments when there is only one route open and you can't be certain if you're racing anyone for it.  I think the tickets add a little too much luck at times (open with a few long routes and you have a big advantage), but let's face it; the game has a lot of luck anyway.  If you can accept that, you should have a blast.  A great gateway game for non-gamers, yet fiercely competitive with experienced gamers.  I've yet to meet somebody who didn't like this.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.25
I think it's an okay game, and I can absolutely understand the appeal. However, I think it is far too dependent on the luck of the draw when it comes to routes, and to a lesser extent train cards. I get that it's a light experience, but it's definitely one of my least favorite of the "classic" examples of modern gateway games. I far prefer Carcassonne, 7 Wonders, and Settlers of Catan, among others. There's too much luck and not enough player interaction (although there is tension when it comes to the race to build, so there is some interaction). Ultimately it just doesn't do it for me. I do think overall it is a nice, solid design, though. And I generally could be convinced to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A generous gift from a club member.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Like it or not, Ticket to Ride is just a little more complex version of the extremely simplistic Transamerica: you still have to connect cities with your railways, even though now you need to play with a more subtle strategy in order to get points for completing routes and avoid point losses for missing tickets.

Anyhow, I find Ticket to Ride is the perfect gateway game for non-gamers, since it’s easy to learn, plays smoothly and in the end it even feels like playing a bigger or harder game as it constantly requires the players to make relevant decisions and overcome new obstacles: its mix of simplicity and complexity is enough for me to make it one of the best games to play with anyone, no matter how much «gamers» they are. [i](September 2011)[/i]

[b]Update I[/b] - In light of the very comment above, in July 2013 I found it proper to raise my rating from 6.5 to 8, which feels better fitting.

[b]Update II[/b] - So many years after my original comment, Ticket to Ride is still both a favorite of the several groups I play with and one of the best games to choose when non-gaming players drop by: hence during my Fall 2015 rating revise I raised my rating from 8 to 9. I still can’t see it reaching 10 though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
One of the best gateway games I've come across. Can be taught in two minutes flat. There are only two options per turn, making it very easy for younger players and uber-casual gamers to understand: Either draw two colored train cards or discard a number cards to lay out trains along a track of corresponding color. 
If you're playing with kids in the 5-7 range, this is the version to get. Not much of a gamer's game unless playing with 4-5 players, or 3+ players if you've got the expansion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I got this for my wife and for my non-gamer friends and family members. For playing with them it's absolutely a ten. There is a lot more game hidden in this than is advertised by those who would reductively call it a rummy game. While there is that element, it also includes strategic and tactical play, as well as press-your-luck and bluffing mechanics. I feel this a much better gateway game than Settlers or Carcassonne. It is perfect for anyone who wants to play a game with depth and engage others resistant to "designer games." Gamers like myself who usually like a litte more mystery about what is under the hood will find themselves reaching for other games. However, the engine of this game is without a doubt so elegant that you won't find yourself leaving a game of Ticket to Ride unsatisfied. Note: the USA 1910 expansion is probably a required purchase along with the base game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
15 plays: 

A light game, accessible to kids, able to be cutthroat and intense with skilled players. 

What's great is that it's quick to learn set up, and the turn to turn play is satisfying and flows nicely. There is little analysis paralysis. 

My complaint is that the whole thing doesn't quite add up to more than the sum of its parts. The many colors have no ultimate meaning; they are interchangeable abstractions that have no consistent role on the board. The destinations are arbitrary. Scoring seems almost like an afterthought. 

Also, it just runs a bit long. Flaying with a group of 5 can take 90 minutes, and it's kind of a long 90 minutes because there are sooooo many turns, most of which are just drawing more train cards.

But it's always ready to take off the shelf and play, and one of the most widely flexible games for various ages and skill levels.

This game is likely to remain in my collection perpetually, especially since the additional maps and variations that have been introduced over the years have provided enough variety to always keep it in play as a choice for my gaming group.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The only "fixed" board game I can wholeheartedly recommend with a guarantee for infinite replayability. When I say "fixed" board gaming, I'm essentially referring to the kinds of games that don't really contain much of any potential for expansion, or any gameplay mechanics that include any kind of customization. 
The kinds of games we've all played as children, like Life or Monopoly, where nothing changes, it's played the exact same way every single time, and there's no way you can change up the experience or customize it. And that's exactly what makes Ticket to Ride so remarkable, the fact that it's a "fixed" board game that can be replayed indefinitely, something that is exceptionally rare in games of this type.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Wow!  My opinion of this game has changed a lot from when I entered the hobby.  First, it remains a great gateway game.  However, after being in the hobby for almost 10 years, I find this game much better than most.  First off, there are simple rules so the "how do you play" gets out of the way almost immediately.  However, experienced players will almost always win because knowing the tickets is a huge advantage.  Second off, it's not a multi-player solitaire game like so many modern euros.  To play well, player need to manage risk (choke points, single routes) and pay attention to what other players are collecting.  There's never downtime.  Turns on quick and even when it's someone else's turn, you need to be paying attention.  Third off, with all that said, it's still a great game to play with company over a beer.  

I do like the expansions better (Switzerland, Nordic Countries, and India) but I'd never say no to base game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Pros:  fast, good social interaction, easy rules, colored trains!  Cons:  plays better with at least four.

RATING: 8
This game serves as a reminder that instant karma is alive and well. My girlfriend plays nice - she politely lets me complete routes even when it's obvious what I am up to.

Like I said, she's nice.

I'm less nice, and I do enjoy claiming that one route train between Seattle and Portland [i]just in case[/i] you might be headed there, you know.

She beats me so mercilessly at this game it is not even funny. I think the severity of the beatings have turned me into the spiteful route grabber I am today. I'm the true victim here.

This one is a great, light game for the naughty and nice alike.  Choo-chooooo!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Short on complexity, but long on fun. All ages enjoy this game. Destination cards "separate the men from the boys." Blocking other players' routes steps up the competition to another level. The players decide at what level they will compete (interfere with other player's lines). Still, careful planning is needed when deciding how many routes to connect. We play the rule in TtRE that everyone starts with one long destination.  Good game design and simple mechanics = an 8 rating.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I've heard many places that this is a good beginner game, and I agree--the gameplay is simple, so much so that at first you wouldn't expect this game to offer so much. Turns go quickly, which generally makes this game much more bearable, time-wise, than Settlers or the like can be. I've discovered the most enjoyable way to play this (without squabbling with other players) is to play with three or four players; at five, this game really turns into fighting over a few key paths. I've also discovered that an effective strategy is to save cards and build up for your biggest paths first, rather than placing down the small tracks first, as it becomes harder and harder to claim certain routes later in the game. Still, I've not managed to ever win this one, which perhaps makes me a little more hesitant to play this than previously.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Another fun Spiel des Jahres winner. Simple rules, quick play and plenty of trying to second guess your opponent and scupper them. Seems a bit same-y though after a lot of plays - Canal Mania might have more replayability.

RATING: 9
My gateway game. Have played with the husband, niece and nephew (11 and 9), sister, mother, sister-in-law, mother-in-law, and several friends. All have enjoyed themselves. After dozens and dozens of plays I still never tire of it.

I prefer Märklin but I like the U.S. map because of the abundance of six-car routes. Days of Wonder really needs an events expansion to spice up the gameplay, though, because the board loses its luster after too many plays. How about adding labor strikes, natural disasters, crashes, service repairs? Something to add some variety to an already great game.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
UPDATE II - My now 8- and 10-year-olds both prefer TTR: Europe, and so do my wife and I.

UPDATE - I have upped my rating since I found out how much fun this game is to play with my 7- and 5-year-olds.  They crave the game, and with a minor handicap (they can play on both routes at any time, while I have to play by the standard three-player rules) it is challenging for all of us.

This is a good game, and it fits my taste, but I'm not sure it's perfect or a SDJ lock.  One issue I have is that the game tension, while strong, isn't strategic.  Luck plays a large factor in the game, as card arrival is the main component of TWO game factors - resources and goals.  I will play this often, but likely not for more than 6 months or so.  As for SDJ... well, Alhambra won, so I guess this one could win and still be a better choice than 2003.  Days of Wonder bits and boxes are still the top of the heap in production.

RATING: 8
At the risk of sounding cliche....  As a noob I really have/had no expectations for any of these games.  TTR is a game that shows up on every must own list as well as every "gateway" list.  After a dozen or so family plays, several one on ones, and an App purchase I can only be added to the list of people praising this game.  While I have not played enough games (yet) to have an opinion on "Best Game" my opinion of TTR is that it has "enough" to be played often. "Enough" what?  Enough strategy, enough press your luck, enough randomness, enough theme, enough...fun.  Ultimately that's it, fun.  This game is fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
My opinion of this game keeps going down each time I play it. The theme/game disconnect is just too wide. Ticket to Ride is really just a melding game with complicated and misleading scoring; the rewards for completing routes (via the ticket cards) are not sensibly given out.
---
I am wierdly conflicted on Ticket to Ride.

To me, this seems to be a game that is clearly in the American style. That is to say, it's winning converts based on being a) familiar through its melding-game heritage, b) modestly engaging, and c) pretty much non-threatening. That's cool, but leaves it a bit in the margins for the gamer who is a fan of much more sophisticated German games like Beowulf, Settlers, Modern Art, etc. You can tell this is not a Knizia because of the impressive imbalances between the various activities - tickets are a sucker play, you want to just put down large routes. This is at least partly because the value of each ticket is just the number of trains required to complete it, without any regard to difficulty whatsoever - a route that contains many short links in a central, contested area is going to be vastly more difficult and more expensive to complete than one containing a few long links on the periperies. Thus, getting a ticket for the long northern or southern routes is a ticket to victory, and drawing tickets is a very risky sucker play. This is a double-whammy because it kills the theme - anyone who mistakes this for a route-building game instead of a point-scoring game is screwed.

Where does that leave me on Ticket to Ride? If I was going to play an "experience" game with a large chaos element, I'd rather do a game with a fun factor, like Liar's Dice or Pitchcar or Nuclear War. I've never been clear where the fun factor is with Ticket to Ride, which is why I never recommend it, even as a "gateway" game. In fairness, there is more to engage the intellect in Ticket to Ride than in many low-brainpower games, but in this class I'd definitely prefer the less-fiddly, less time-consuming Reibach (Get the Goods) or High Society or For Sale, or at the very least something with a minimally functioning theme. Ticket to Ride also has a problem with limited replayability, rapidly becoming pretty samey - much moreso than similar weight class games like Carcassonne: Hunters & Gatherers or Through the Desert.

All this is not to say that Ticket to Ride is a bad game; it's not. It's a decent game, it works, it's attractive, it's easy to play, and so on. But for me personally, it's just too bland. Too long to make a virtue of brevity or simplicity, yet too light to be really engaging. Even after all these years, give me Settlers any day.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A decent light-weight route building game, where you draft cards hoping to form sets that allow you to place routes.  You have a hand of ticket cards showing connections you need to make with those routes you're placing.  Make the connection to score points, but if you don't you'll lose the points!

Lots of fun with lots of very tense moments as the board gets crowded and potential routes are cut off by your opponents.  You can also gamble on taking extra tickets, but if you draw poorly, you might really get screwed into getting tickets you can't complete!  So, overall, the tension here is very good.

Overall, a light game that is still very enjoyable despite the simplicity.  Great for introducing people to the hobby.

Although the Europe version has a few more interesting rules, I prefer the original for its simplicity and the familiarity of the U.S. map. A great choice for families or for people wanting to try modern board games.

RATING: 6

I find you really need five players to experience tension, less than five and I find any feel any reason to lay track. With five and I lay track because I'm worried that I'll get blocked out of the best route, or possibly be unable to even complete my route.

I prefer the Europe variant as it ensures a better distribution of the long tracks and the Stations diminish the tension just a bit of getting blocked out, which is nice. Not a fan of the tunnels though.

RATING: 6
While this is definitely a very simple game, Ticket to Ride is great for what it is and fills a (to me) important niche. It's simple and aesthetically pleasing enough that non-gamers are usually willing to give it a go, and it's still fun for gamers in the mood for a light, quick game. This goes super, super fast with an experienced group, making the luck factor a non-issue for me. I actually played this AFTER the other games in the series, but I enjoy this one the most. The map and lack of stations/passengers make it the most cutthroat, and the simplicity of the rules makes it the ideal choice for non-gamers.

RATING: 3
I am not so sure why this game is rated that high.  

Production: great quality, sturdy box, nice illustrations, not very realistic geography wise. 

Rules and mechanic: not much, the whole game is about three or four rules. you exchange cards for trains and claim so-called "routes." Very, very abstract. And while abstract, no big strategy either. Emotion wise it is overally a negative game.  All you need to do is to cut the other person, that'd be the basically the major strategy.   

I am not a uber-board gamer; however, this game is far too dry for any kind of taste.  We have tried with 2-3 people, no difference. As boring as it gets.  I am looking other RR games, such as Railways of the World, or Steam, even a crayon game, Empire Builder "awesome map!."  Maybe my mistake was to think this as a RR game. 

Avoid.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Often recommended as a "gateway" Euro, this Alan Moon favourite belongs in any Eurogamer's collection.  The set collection, network building, and completion of specified routes are easy enough for an eight-year-old to comprehend, but the optimal mix of the three is constantly shifting; the simplicity of the rules belies the depth of strategic and tactical considerations that arise during a game.  The amount of player interaction and confrontation varies depending on the number and/or experience of the players - beginners (or crybabies) can play a soft game, keeping out of each other's way, while more seasoned gamers can play hardball, blocking routes, snapping up train cards needed by their opponents, and generally trying to fuck things up for other players.  Definitely one of the first games that should be introduced to any budding Eurogamer, and one that will likely be a lifelong companion.    
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
This game is a popular gateway game for a reason.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is hands down *THE BEST* gateway game in existence! It's the very first game I introduce new people to if they haven't played board games before - and it has been a huge succes every single time! I have managed to get people so hooked on board games that they have requested to play more games which is obviously great. Many of these persons have even bought TtR themselves!

So, if I should rate it by popularity, it would get a 9 or so, but the fact that it's so easy for non-gamers to understand is also the downside for me; I would like just a bit more to think about than drawing two cards or lay down train cars (or take new route cards). 

Rating is including the expansion Ticket to Ride: USA 1910 which I always play with. Otherwise the rating would probably drop a little.

It never fails to impress new players - it's so easy to explain and understand, it looks great, there is some tense decision-making going on, and even the losing players feel that they have accomplished something when the game is over (due to the train tracks; they start with nothing but end up with a lot of trains on the board).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The simplest of the Ticket to Ride series and a safe bet for a 'gateway' or family game. An appealing theme and not too much screwage due to the many alternative routes, at least on this map.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I'm going against the general trend here, but this game did nothing for me.  I'm not a big fan of train games anyway, but the gameplay just didn't engage me.  Maybe my rating will improve after more playings...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I have come to really appreciate the game for the addictive joy that it is. It is a great gateway because it's simple, beautiful, and has a very positive first play experience. But please stop saying this is "just" a gateway game. Yes, it is an amazing game to introduce people to the hobby, but it is more than a simple game when experienced players sit down to play. Deep? Maybe not, but fully engaging to a player choosing to track every detail.  

I do think in every way that it is a landmark for the hobby and that was clear from the very beginning. My first set of cards are nearly ragged. And sharing it with my students was a great joy. 

The tension can be palpable with some groups, and yet I can play loose with others. I love that range of experience based on my fellow players. Those who say it is all luck fail to regard how you can play your way out of any hand by knowing the game and watching the other players. The best players win much, much more often---but not so much that a new player can't pull a game out. The group I play this with make me proud to play games because anyone can win and people can still play with a personal style. That's a very high compliment in my book! 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.91
Tense and quick-playing - I really enjoy this game.  The online implementation at daysofwonder.com is very good.  A friend of mine complained that whoever gets the west-east connection wins.  While that is an advantage, it's not insurmountable; first of all, there is more than one east-west connection; second, you can block some of the straight shots, especially the southern route, fairly easily.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My go-to gateway "family" game.  Basic intro into modern board games with just enough strategy to keep me interested each time I play.

Rules and turns are very simple - either take two cards, or turn in some card to build a train.  Longer trains = more points, and don't forget to build the route for your ticket.

I know there are a ton of other maps out there, but I have never felt the need to go beyond the basic America map.  Once players get the feel for the game and mechanics I think it can get a bit dry.

**Had many plays before logging.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The only reason I would play this if I was playing against smaller children - since the game mechanics are simple enough that they would probably enjoy it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]Includes 1910 expansion[/b]

My first "gateway game" purchase... in Dec. 2008.

This is the ultimate gateway game. I have not yet found a person that did not like this game at least a little bit. I still enjoy it, even though I'm increasingly attracted to more difficult games.

This is a definite keeper and a great means for introducing new people to board games.

Update: Just played this game with three other "gamers" familiar with TTR, and it was still very enjoyable... possibly even more so with the increased competition. Yes, this is a "gateway" game, but that's not to suggest that the game's limit is for introducing newbies. TTR can stand on its own. I've dropped the rating to a "7", but only because I've played this many more times prior to my official effort to log games. I'm not actively suggesting it, but I certainly won't turn down a game.

RATING: 8.5
I played this version of Ticket to Ride after having already played TtR Europe. I prefer TtR Europe due to the tunnels and ferries and the layout of the tracks - USA is very rectangular but this can make for a somewhat more ruthless game (which is not a bad thing).

I was glad that when I bought this for my sister I also bought the 1910 expansion because the cards are so small in the base game! (They may have changed this by now, I bought the game in early 2011)

All in all this is a very good game, and the US map is easier to teach people who are new to TtR or games in general.

RATING: 10
With my kids (5,7,10) this one is a clear favorite.  We play it constantly and it never seems to get old.  It also seems that every time the kids have a friend over, this is the first game my kids want to teach their friends.

I moved this from a 9 to a 10 based on how frequently we play it, how much my kids like it, and the reaction from others trying it out for the first time.

Nearly every time we play, my daughter ends up with the longest route 10+ bonus and in a large majority of the games, that either pushes her ahead for a victory or solidifies her already substantial lead.

Very fun game and we're looking forward to the 1910 expansion.

We've had fun playing this one with relatives who don't game a lot. I would never pull this out with the gaming group, though.

RATING: 5
While I see the appeal as a super complexity-light gateway game, I simply don't feel the love for "Ticket to Ride" that so many others profess. One problem is that, too often, I feel like I'm playing on an island. I take my turn and then just sit around waiting for everyone else, vaguely hoping they don't take the track I want. When my turn comes around, what interesting choices do I have to make? Take two cards or claim a route. That's it. And it's not like things get more interesting later on - they just get more crowded. That's not enough to excite me. I can see playing this game with a friend who simply loves it, but I'd never elect to put it on my table.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A fairly average set collecting / drafting card game with an often unessential board. In theory, the routes on the board add tension and uncertainty, but unless you have a full table there is little room for defensive play, which made this strangely feel like a solitaire game in that any time a player thwarted another, except in extremely rare circumstances, it was circumstantial. 

A bit of room for good play: drawing cards to prevent changing the face up pile, and getting a huge hand and then creating a huge run of 6 links, and it seems the choice between short and long tickets, and long runs vs. quantity of tickets is decently balanced. 

Very little tension most of the time though, pick up a card, pick up a card, lay out several cards, accidentally screw someone along the way. Note that I am more fond of the later Nordic variant that has few enough routes to make this actually competitive in many situations, even with only 2, and especially with 3. This original version of the game really requires a fullish table to have any sense of competition.

(Note that Elfengold has many of the good things about TtR while adding many more gamer friendly aspects such as auctions and opportunities to screw with your opponents. I suggest it by a wide margin over this lighter implementation of a 'route planning' game...and if you really want something light in this vein on the cheap I recommend Canasta, all it takes is two Bicycle decks!)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Another game concept that is fantastic, cut down in it's prime by over reliance on random factors in determining the final result.  Random what cards you get, but more importantly are the tickets you draw.  If one player draws two overlapping results, that player will win.  If another player has no overlap, that player will lose.  Still, very accessible, very entertaining game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
I love it that people who have reviewed this game praise it to the heavens but then turn around and snobbishly sniff at other games that "don't bring anything new to the table".  OK, this is Alan Moon's 36th (?) reuse of the same theme, mechanics, and scoring methods and this is somehow "new"?  I think they just like the pretty pictures.  This is a well-designed game, sure, but it's pointless to waste another hour on it when that hour could be applied to something meaningful and thought-provoking.  Like most recent German-style games, this has little replay value or depth and that ultimately is a better barometer of a game's merit than anything else.  As far as its accessibility, there was a time when gamers got into the hobby through Axis and Allies or Civilization...this game might as well be Candyland compared to those.  In fact, this game is evidence that if Candyland were released today, fat bearded men and their grotesquely obese wives would be hunkered over it declaring how "clever" and "elegant" the mechanics are- just like they do with TTR.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Easily taught but interesting enough for gamers. Tickets can be incredibly scary.

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
You really need to twist my arm to get me to play this.  The winning strategy is to hoard cards and play big routes.  The only real strategy is completing your destinations, which is actually sort of luck based.  Blocking is way too difficulkt to make it worth while unless you are also competing your routes.  So the game just turns into "i draw two cards" over and over again, then play a bunch, maybe grab destinations a second time, game over.  I don't even think this is a good entry game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I was and still am dissappointed with this game. It should/could be a 9 for me. Let me explain why. I feel very strongly that the bonuses for completing your rail links between cities is too small. In game play terms I'd add about a 25-50% to the value of the bonus to every city card. You could do this by adding 5 to every card or use a percentage as above. If you added say 30% a 10 would be worth 13. As the game sits its mainly about getting a east to west rail line using as many 5 or 6 link sections as you can. There is virtually no way you can win without using large links. I played a game where I drew mainly north south runs in the east. I completed 7 of 8 but as it turns out even if I'd completed 8 of 8 I still would have lost. This just doesn't seem right. A train game should primarily reward you for building clever rail lines not just a big sections where ever. If you wish you can overlook this completely and play it as a pure strategy game and have fun but I think it still limits the strategic options to one rather than two.

New Idea: I might try a strategy which is to keep two small runs which you can complete easily and focus on playing a mainly defensive strategy to stop others from connecting their big runs. If you get help from one or two other players who may also try this strategy, then completing a big run becomes difficult. This should nicely balance things out. If you really mess with one guy early he will have no choice but to join you in stopping someone else when he is not going to make his big runs. Then this can landslide to 3 or 4 people stopping the last one or two people trying for the big connection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Played online version only

RATING: 8
This game feels like an 'Old Faithful' to me. It gets played frequently, and I often use it to introduce people who say they don't like games, to the wonderful world of boardgames. 

It's easy to learn, easy to play, but still has enough strategy involved that it can get really difficult when playing with the right group of people.

I'd recommend picking this up (or one of it's descendents) to anyone, and any level of gamer.

RATING: 8
3rd boardgame I have bought since started my hobby, but it was the first Euro game I have played. I bought this for to play at party with my relatives, who do like games, like Pit, Pictionary, etc but aren't familar with Euro games. It was ver easy to teach and it went over well everything but the session was a little long with 5 new players, like 2 hours, but since it was our first time, that was understandable. While I thought it was a little light, as compared with my experience with playing Last Night On Earth, which I loved, I did like it as I could see the strategies in the game. My cousins especially really liked the game and wanted to play in the future so it was a successful hit with my relatives, and I got them excited to play other games I think, just like a good gateway game should do. If I had a choice, I'd play Downfall of Pompeii as the first gateway game, as it's quicker, and has a better theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I love this game, even though I always loose :( I suppose I'm too chicken to take risks involving drawing more tickets.

RATING: 7
Board Game and App

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Ticket to Ride is the perfect gateway game into the world of strategy board gaming. I taught Ticket to Ride to about a dozen couples who only knew games like Monopoly, and every couple loved the game. It's simple game with a train-based theme. All you do is draw colored cards and then discard those cards to lay your train track needed to complete your assignments, or tickets, from, say, London to Berlin.

Once you learn the game, however, you'll discover a few flaws. First, the cards themselves are too small and thus hard to handle, especially since there is no hand limit. Second, there's too much luck involved with what tickets you draw. Put simply, some tickets produce a lot more points than other tickets.

But the 1910 expansion comes to the rescue. With the expansion, you can replace the small cards with the big ones. And the additional tickets reduce the luck factor.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
There's very little direct competition in this version because there's plenty of room to maneuver and everyone is usually just worried about their own routes unless there's some obvious and easy way to block someone else's route.  If you try to block someone, they usually have 2 or 3 or 4 outs and so it's you who pays the bigger price in that they lose little in development time and you've lost whatever you've invested on your own development.  It's a good family game.  Experience is a huge bonus.  Memorizing the common cities used helps in figuring out what the opponent is doing and also there are several places on the map that are commonly sought after.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Seems very repetitive to me. Never saw the appeal.

RATING: 7.6
Finally purchased it and played it with my family. Was worried that it wouldn't live up to all the hype. Family enjoyed it, but didn't love it. Fun game. Held everyone's attention. Lots of planning and strategizing and yelling (jokingly?) at each other for taking cards or routes. Lots of strategy without being too difficult. Components are eye-catching and high quality. While not the first game we have played with a sort of "get you" mechanism, is probably the one that has it the strongest. I think this game may not be pulled off the shelf very often - there are many games my family loves that they would rather play and some of the scoring mechanisms get a bit confusing for the family.

Keep

While I still prefer Ticket to Ride: Europe, I found this version very easy to teach to four other new players without the added complications of tunnels and stations. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
R's
Draw cards from a display or blindly.  These can be goals or trains.  Goals are cities to connect.  Play sets to place trains along a section of track on the board to help achieve goals.  Score points mid-game for claiming track.  Score points at the end of the game for goals.  Unachieved goals are negative points.

RATING: 8

It is a gateway game with surprisingly deep strategy and a very cutthroat feel.  The energy and suspense in this game is relentless from beginning to end.  My mom loved this game, and she is a very far cry from being a game-lover.  This game would be a ten, but because it was my introduction to the hobby, it got a bit overplayed.  I predict that in the future it will be hailed as "The Monopoly of the 2000s".  It is the first game I recommend to those new to the hobby.

RATING: 8
Easy game to learn for just about anyone. Individual strategies are difficult for other to guess at, and the Draw OR Play mechanic stops people from overrunning the game.

Connect cities to gain points, and complete Destination Tickets for even more. The only score that eveeryone knows is what you get for placing trains, leading to a dramatic change in victors as the Destination Tickets are added/subtracted at the end of the game.

Highly recommended!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Simplistic euro style game for building railroads across the United States.  Complete routes to score special cards,  work for the longest route, and build as much track as you can before the game ends.  This game plays fast with little down time.  The game is neat looking and the plastic trains are cool.  This is easy to teach others and fun to play.  There's no dice in Ticket to Ride and the only variability is in card draw for scoring points or building track.  Several expansions now exist.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This is a great gateway game. Also, aside of Magic the Gathering, it is the most played game I own (counting all expansions together).
The core of the game is to fulfill set of tickets - connect two cities on the ticket with the train route. You do this by collecting train cards of different colors and claiming routes by placing number of trains according to their length. 
This is the core set of the game with no additional rules covering USA territory. The strategy is usually to connect the west with east to make one long route ideally. I strongly recommend to add USA 1910 expansion and play megagame variant - shuffling all tickets together and having 10p bonus for longest track and 15p for the most tickets completed.

What I like:
- easy, not brain burning, perfect for the new people in the hobby, Ideal game to pick when you want to introduce board gaming.
- You feel you have actually building something, and when completing all your tickets, it feels somehow good.
- Nice components, artwork is great (in all maps in series general)
- this version I pick when I just need to relax, play without any additional rules introduced in later versions.

What I dislike:
- Sometimes the game is too luck dependent - you desperately need the fifth green train taking again and again cards from the top and not seeing any card you need while opponent draws one locomotive (bonus train) after another. This issue can be partially overdone by good planning and preparing your tracks for the future.
- As this is light gateway game, don't expect some hard brain work, the gaming experience is very casual.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Ticket to Ride is the BEST gateway game out there.  I don't even think it's close.  Newbies are going to be able to pick this one up in a heartbeat but will probably get destroyed by board game veterans...the reason being is this game has so much hidden depth.  There is little to no luck in this game and it's highly strategic (aside from starting destination tickets).  Every route you connect matters.  There's also a great dash of tactical play with taking cards you know your opponent needs and laying routes that block your opponents.  There's a great amount of tension in between your turns where you are sweating if someone is going to take the card you want or lay a route that you needed.  Highly recommend this game to everyone!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Components: The production is quite good: very attractive, functional, and durable components. I've upgraded to the 1910 cards; wish I had the 2nd edition score track.

Experience: Very tense, from the first turns stockpiling cards, to the very end, when the threat of the final round looms over any incomplete tickets. RATING: 10
Ticket to Ride games should still be in the gaming stores hundreds of years from now. TTR has a clean, elegant design with tension despite the lack of direct player interaction. It looks good and has a great deal of stand alone expansions with limitless potential (you have a map? TTR could make a game out of it). This game should be held in the same regards as the "best" mass-market games such as Monopoly or Clue. Highest possible recommendation.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
