=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I had played a couple of Euro-style games before my first game of Ticket to Ride, but this was the game that really set me down the path of the Serious Boardgamer (TM). 

First, the bad: I now mostly play the game online, where it is substantially faster than in real life. In person, I find things move pretty slowly, especially when playing with less experienced players. Sometimes you have lots of three-wild boards and need to shuffle the deck a bunch, which means even more sitting around waiting for things to happen. Sometimes people will stare at the board wondering what to do for a bit too long, and you don't want to push them along because it's a pretty casual and newbie-friendly game, but come...on...already...

In terms of actual mechanical lackings, the most readily apparent one is the randomness of the opening ticket draw. You will sometimes get three terrible routes that go North-South along short routes that eat up valuable resources, and then you will sometimes get Los Angeles-New York and Los Angeles-Miami or some other busted start and have to actively work to lose the game. It's not fun knowing that you've got so much riding (no pun intended) on something that happens at the beginning of a potentially hourlong game. Obviously a skilled player can overcome this (and I'm far from a high-skilled player), but it's still frustrating. I don't know how to improve it, though.

On the other hand, this game is just very fun for something so simple and so easy to teach. You can take someone with no gaming experience beyond Monopoly and have them putting up a fight in TtR within five minutes of the board hitting the table. There's a sort of push-your-luck element where you grip your cards hoping that nobody else takes that valuable 6 car route before you can get it without using your wilds, but unless you have exceptionally bad luck off the top of the deck you will rarely be completely out of the game. The theme is obviously well-implemented, if a bit straightforward (you're not gonna see 18xx mechanics here, and that's fine), and I love trying to make a really cool route or a really powerful route with lots of long journeys.

Ultimately, the game rewards longtime players and still offers plenty for a beginner. It's by no means perfect, but it's an excellent gateway that still held up for me even as I moved to heavier games.

Equivalent Beer: Lagunitas Hop Stoopid.

"The merit of good light games is they have some sort of dynamic fun factor. I don't consider draw-draw-draw-draw-draw-draw- play route -draw-draw-draw- play route (screw someone blindly)- draw-draw-draw-draw-draw-draw-draw-draw- play route - to be a very fun gaming experience."

You actually use the map in this game; UP has always bummed me out because even though there are restrictions as to what can be placed where on the map it is extremely difficult to use physical position to block anyone.  I love the jockeying to connect your target cities and block your opponents' connections.  I also love the risk/reward tradeoff of the connections...

RATING: 8
This was the game for us.  The kids love it, it's quick, easy, strategic. much deeper than it appears to start with, looks great.  Can't say enough good things about it.  We got the 1910 expansion - worth it for the bigger cards alone, but also adds variety if the original tickets become too predictable.  Have played Europe but didn't like it as much - the one long ticket each mechanism makes it too easy to see what people are up to, and a bit formulaic.  Saying that, there's still something not quite right with the luck of the intial deal and it would be nice to figure out a way to balance this in the game.  There's an interesting card passing initial deal variant, which we should probably try.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Really, this game is a glorified version of gin and it's ilk (gin rummy, rummy, etc.), but with a nice theme, and a little extra strategy involved. There's definitely a learning curve, but a fairly quick one, and not too steep, but just enough surprising subtlety to make the games interesting. It can play a little slow, and it's not my preferred kind of game, but as it's accessible for anyone ages 6 or 7 and up, it's easier than most to get people to play. In fact, most of my games have been with people who otherwise wouldn't even look at a board game.

Original Comments:

I actually enjoy it, but there's not much depth here.  It's just so approachable, though our games are always tense.  I sweat more playing this game more than I sweat or have sweated playing any other game before.

It's certainly not an ugly game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This game would be a lot more fun if you had to start in one city and arrive at another before the end of the game, circumventing various obstacles and other players along the way. Instead, despite the theme of a turn of the century "Around the World in 80 Days" re-enactment you can, in fact, grab any route on the board you have the cards for at any time. Scoring has been rigged to encourage you to try to connect up everything by the end of the game but it plays like an afterthought... actually, at best, it plays like you're *flying* from one city to the next, then taking short train trips. In the end the game is fun enough, but with a little extra attention to theme this game could have been so much better. Addendum: And what's the deal with all the card accumulating at the start? The more I play the less this appeals to me...

RATING: 7
A game we use frequently to introduce people to the hobby. Accomplished players can get through the game fairly quickly and it is fun to play on the USA map. I much prefer the Nordic Countries map as it has more strategic decisions. This game is fun and light.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Is about railway routes between cities across the USA. These are pre-printed on the map. You claim them by playing a set of cards and putting plastic train pieces in your colour on the board along the route. So, each turn has a basic decision. Do you pick up more cards or put some down to claim a route? That's not too difficult, so turns tend to move pretty quickly. Usually you get several turns of players picking up cards and eyeing each other. Then someone cracks and claims a route. A flurry of card playing follows as players claim routes they need – or just have the cards for.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

HOW DO THEY GET FROM LAS VEGAS TO NEW YORK IN ONE TURN!?!?

Doesn't make sense...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Ticket to Ride is a tremendous game. It is extremely engaging and fun to play. Players must carefully balance their needs to claim routes early as well as to collect the right cards to finish the job. Players can choose to rely on luck more (get cards from the deck, draw risky tickets) or to play it safer (only take face up cards and build long routes rather than risk taking more tickets). Both ways can easily win as the tempo of the game is determined very much by the players. There are many expansion maps available which make sure that this one will not get old, although I would probably be happy even with just the basic USA map.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Easy to pick up and fun with a small-medium group. Even people who do not tend to enjoy board games will enjoy this one. The art and pieces are great and the box is wonderful. No baggies or bowls needed. Takes minutes to set up and clean up and games can go by rather quickly.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Probably one of the most overrated games I have seen yet.

You draw cards to cover train routes.  Different cards have different colors, and so do the routes.  The bigger the route you take, the more points you receive.  In addition, semi-random "tickets" can be chosen that give you a bonus for finishing the route or a decrement if you do not cover the route.

The good thing about this game is that it is easy to learn.  Most people (including a 6 year old) figured it out in 3 minutes and could play it.

So why is this game a fail?  It's entire design revolves around card counting, deck memorization, and knowing the shape of the map.  You had better keep track of how many red cards (and blue, purple, white, etc) have been played or you will never know what % chance you have of finishing one route over another (quickly that is).  Knowing what cards are left in the "tickets" deck is crucial.  Drawing another ticket can win or lose a game for you, if you know that it is highly unlikely that anything left is going to help you, you had better skip pulling another card.  And finally, knowing which sides of the map are easy or hard depending on your ticket selection is crucial.  

Basically that means you need to memorize a lot.  The person who owns it will probably destroy everyone else.  That doesn't lead to many replays in some groups.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
The best gateway game since SoC. I expect I will tire of it like SoC... after 50+ plays. It plays so quickly that it doesn't outlast it's welcome.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I enjoyed this a lot more than Europe. The lack of stations gave it a bit more tension, as I genuinely worried at times that other players may 'steal my routes'.

Of course, if that threat had become reality, I may have hated it...

Rules are simple to teach and it works as a gateway game, yet there's a good few choices to make. Choosing cards to take, a route to claim or pushing your luck with more tickets - these 3 possible moves each involve their own set of choices and whilst it never gets particularly heavy, there is potential for trying out varying strategies.

Pushing your luck by getting more routes is probably the most interesting part of the game, as well as the potential screwage.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
People may not ride the train anymore. But lots of people still play this game series. It's familiar, casual, peaceful, and classic ride. Everyone has some idea of what to expect. But new games in the series are still finding slight innovations to improve the formula or alter it in fun and novel ways. Some of them are fairly relaxing. Some of them are very cutthroat and nasty. There's room for strategy in all of them despite it being an entry-level game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Beautiful components. New players enjoy the setup and play of this game a lot, making it a great intro game. After playing a number of times, I find it lacks much "Take That". There also appears to be a winning strategy of connecting long paths between cities. 
I would perhaps recommend TTR Europe even to new Euro collectors above TTR as it appears to have a bit more strategy, though I haven't played it myself. 
UPDATE: 7.0 I cant help it but I must raise the rating. New players are all over this game, and it is pretty satisfying to tell them - "look just make sure you get your tickets done", then on the second turn slap down a three route like its the end of the world and see the pressure  hit the roof on thier faces. I mean it doesn't even have to be near their routes! The moment they feel that tension they are hooked, and its pretty fun to be the one to get the kettle boiling. 3-4 players only please. 
After all that Im still on the fence about getting the expansion. Is this the new Monopoly? sigh.

RATING: 6
I've got to admit, that although I was skeptical, I actually enjoyed this game.  Could be because I won in my first game (against 3 other players)!  But, after playing Thurn & Taxis, I didn't think TTR would be as entertaining.  

Well, it isn't quite as fun, but it was still pretty good.  The game offers enough options to keep it from being completely out of the players' control.  And, being a light game, it doesn't drag on too long.  The hidden VPs in the route cards really make it a good game, rather than a decent one.

Like other light, gateway games, this one will be fun to play once in a while.  Being the gamer that I am, I will want to play meatier games more often.

RATING: 5
I don't get the love for this game. It's basically draw 2 cards, draw 2 cards, draw 2 cards, draw 2 cards, play a train. Rinse and repeat. I've played it with different player counts and the game is just not that tight. Trying to block your opponents usually only hinders you unless you just happen to need to go that way as well. I hear the other versions are better in this regard but for me the base game is just purely for newer gamers and kids.

I'll keep it around simply because I think my kids will enjoy it.

RATING: 7.5
I do like this game quite a bit - it's easy to teach and quick to learn for new players. The initial issue I have had with the game after about 10 plays or so is that the luck of the initial draw determines a good portion of the scoring. If a player is able to get two of the los angeles/san francisco to new york/atlanta routes at the beginning of the game, they can easily dominate someone who gets all mid-count tickets [ie. 4's through 9's].

RATING: 6.5

I'd play again with groups of gamers that enjoy lighter games or if someone really wants to play it. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
Basically, you draw cards and lay tracks.  You can't foil anyone as there are virtually a million paths to every destination.  So then it comes down to drawing cards and placing trains.  This has to be the most over-hyped game ever.  

If you are looking for a game where you drink beer and occasionally pay attention to what's going on, this is it.


I once saw a guy draw a circle on his white board then toss small sticky balls (about an inch is size) at it for hours.  I thought he would grow tired of this painfully dull act after a day or so.  A year later he still does it as he finds it most relaxing and fun.  I realized that this is how some people meditate (whether they know it or not).  They focus on the easy task at hand and clear the mind.  The easier the task, the more euphoria the brain experiences.  This game is popular because satisfies the same requirement.  A very simple, zero strategy game that sends the brain in to an easy mediative state.  This euphoria elevates when the brain discovers that it could complete a route and did not have to work - thus fulfilling one the the laws of physics that states everything seeks is lowest energy level.  

For that, I give it a 10.  But for gaming, I give it a 1.  I have played this 11 or 12 times now.  After the first 4 (trying to find something I may have been missing) I mostly observed the other players - a very interesting experiment (try it sometime!).  They had the same happy look on their faces as the guy with the sticky balls.  Don't think me negative, I too now like the sticky balls (heh heh).  But for this type of game, I prefer Risk or Monopoly - a tad more excitement with the dice.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
TTR is a great gateway or middle ground game that anyone can play.  The game mechanics work perfectly and make for some tense moments as you hope to not get cut off by your opponents.  Easy enough to teach to kids and non-gamers, although the heavy amount of luck could be a turn off to those who like more brain burning games.  Nastier players can go on an all out defensive by simply cutting off all the important routes.  Once you complete your routes you can take new route cards.  This is a dangerous lottery as you will usually get either easy points, or instantly get stuck with impossible routes that will end your would-be victory.  All in all though, a good game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Doel van het spel:

Wanneer een speler aan het einde van zijn beurt nog 2 ,1 of  0 treinwagons in zijn voorraad heeft, dan begint de laatste ronde. Iedere speler is nog 1 keer aan de beurt (inclusief de speler die het spel beëindigde). De spelers berekenen hun eindscore en de speler met de meeste punten wint het spel. In geval van gelijkstand, wint de speler met de meeste bestemmingskaarten. 

Voorbereiding:

+ Iedere speler kiest een kleur en neemt zijn 45 treinwagons en een scoresteen (op veld “1” van het scorespoor). 
+ Schud de treinwagonkaarten en geef iedere speler 4 kaarten. Leg 5 kaarten open en de overige kaarten vormen een gedekte trekstapel. 
+ Iedere speler krijgt 3 bestemmingskaarten waarvan hij er minstens 2 moet houden. 
+ Kies een startspeler. 

Speelverloop:

Het spel wordt met de wijzers van de klok gespeeld. De speler aan de beurt kan slechts één van de 3 beschikbare acties uitvoeren: 

1/ Treinwagonkaarten nemen 

De actieve speler kan 2 open en/of gedekte treinwagonkaarten nemen. Bij het trekken van een open kaart, moet de speler direct een nieuwe kaart uit de gedekte stapel neerleggen. Pas daarna kan hij een tweede kaart nemen (geen locomotief van de open stapel). 
Wanneer de speler een open locomotiefkaart neemt dan mag hij geen tweede kaart meer nemen. 

2/ Een route claimen 

De speler claimt een route tussen twee steden door exact het aantal treinwagonkaarten (met de kleur van de route) uit te spelen. Hij plaatst een treinwagon op ieder vakje van de route. De speler is steeds verplicht om de volledige route te claimen. Hij kan iedere, open route op de kaart claimen (hij moet geen verbinding maken met eerder gelegde routes). Na het bouwen van een route ontvangt hij direct punten:

Lengte van de route – punten:

1 – 1
2 – 2
3 – 4
4 – 7
5 – 10
6 – 15

Alle kaarten die nodig waren om de route te bouwen worden afgelegd. 

3/ Bestemmingskaarten nemen 

De speler trekt 3 bestemmingskaarten waarvan hij er minstens 1 moet houden. De niet-gekozen kaarten legt hij af.

Eindscore = huidige score van de gemaakte verbindingen + punten van de voltooide bestemmingskaarten + 10 punten voor de speler met de langste aaneengesloten route – punten van alle onvoltooide bestemmingskaarten.

Belangrijke regels:

+ Bij 2 à 3 spelers kan slechts één dubbele route gebruikt worden. 
+ Een locomotief telt als een joker en kan een treinwagonkaart vervangen in het bouwen aan een route. 
+ Grijze routes = de speler bouwt met een kleur naar keuze. 
+ Een speler kan niet beide routes van een “dubbele routeverbinding” claimen. 
+ Liggen er 3 locomotiefkaarten in de open trekstapel, dan wordt de trekstapel afgelegd en 5 nieuwe kaarten getrokken.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.25
What I liked
* Easy to teach and play
* Appeals to gamers and non gamers
* Thought the theme would be dry, but enjoyed it
* Plays fast, little downtime
* The map just feels less interesting than the Europe map.
* Pieces come baged and with spare carrages!

What I didn't like
* Need to make sure the deck is VERY shuffled before starting each game.
* Game is all about efficiency, unfortunately luck plays a fairly big part in how efficiant you can be.

If experienced players are playing against beginners, they really should give some helpful advice about what to go for and strategy before the game starts otherwise there is a very big advantage to the experienced player.

* Some of the printing on the cards on my copy was dodgy

It is a pity that the cards were not balanced better...

RATING: 5
Ticket to Ride was fine as far as shorter games go. But, like Alhambra, it seemed to bet not quite interesting enough to play over other other, better games. I am sure that if I played it another half dozen times I could gain some joy out of the experience of exploring the game, but I would quickly grow bored with it after that. It just seemed that there was not enough "game" there for it to be worth spending time or money on it. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Players either draft rail car cards, play melds of these cards to connect cities together (and score points), or draw ticket cards (hidden agenda points).  Most points wins.   So simple, anybody could have invented it.  It's a fun meld/connection game, looks wonderful, but once you get past that, the game leaves you with a huge "is that it?" factor.  Sits between ultra-fluffy TransAmerica and more meaty Santa Fe Rails.  Looks like it's aimed at families, and I can see it being a strong SdJ contender.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Wow, for such a simple game, it creates a surprisingly exciting atmosphere. Every decision in the game is tense because of the anticipation of what might happen before your next turn. My wife does not like this game anymore because it stresses her out. It's not a game I can play over and over, but it's one that will never lose its appeal to me. Our house rule is that all your trains have to be gone before the game ends. It lengthens the game slightly, but I think it requires better planning. 

On a side note, I recently played a game where one card (or the lack thereof) made a difference of -166 points in my score. I had bet it all on the big routes and came up short.

RATING: 7.75
1.9
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Nice game, but Europe is better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This generation's Monopoly.

1. Card / Set Collecting - Check.
2. Competition on getting limited resources (Properties vs. Routes) - Check.
3. Luck Element (Dice Rolling vs. Card Drawing) - Check
4. Limited supply of components to utilize the resources (Train miniatures vs. House / Hotels) - Check
5. Low Learning Curve - Check

Ticket to Ride has a better process to end the game vs. Monopoly. The worst case with Monopoly is when nobody owns a Monopoly AND the players refuse to negotiate. The game goes on an on with people paying anywhere from $ 2 to $ 50 rentals. The only way to mitigate this is via time limit, but if time limit was not set this lends to a long and boring game. Ticket to Ride addresses this by having either the board filled out or the depletion of train supply by any player. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very nice intro to Euro style games for new gamers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A great learning game that dies once you discover better games.  The problem is that the game doesn't offer a lot of intentional interaction, doesn't punish horading, and really is just waiting for the right color cards to come out for a very predictable and bland path.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
MD

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Most people agree this is a good game especially for non-gamers.  I'd say slightly better than Carcassonne.  So just from that I'd give it a 7.5.  The reason its a 10 is that playing 2 player is highly skill intensive.  If you don't believe me, meet me at the Days of Wonder site and I'll play you online and will probably beat you 90% of the time.  If you are good than maybe only 75%, but either way if you play a decent number of games (which go really fast online), the more skilled player will come out on top. [After playing 5,000+ games online, and being one of the top 20 or so players in the world, I don't think I would really enjoy the game face to face unless I was just introducing it to new people]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Without a doubt, THE definitive gateway game to modern boardgames for non-gamers.  This was really the first Euro-game that got me into Euro Games.  Prior to this I played Chess a lot as a kid, and played the old Milton Bradley “GameMaster” series games “Axis & Allies” and “Conquest of the Empire” along with “Risk” and “Diplomacy”.  In fact it was at a Diplomacy meet that I played Ticket to Ride for the first time.  We had finished a five hour game and one participant pointed out this game to us and recommend we give it a try.  None of us had really played anything outside our usual strategy war games before.  I had played “Settlers of Catan” before, but that game never really grabbed me.  After we finished Ticket to Ride we all looked at each other wide-eyed like we had just found the map to El Dorado.  I myself could never go back to playing those old strategy war games again and began my journey into Eurogame land.  Fast forward many many years later and I STILL enjoy playing the original Ticket to Ride (although you really do need the 1910 expansion).  
I’ve introduced so many people to modern boardgaming through this game and it always go over so well with non-gamers.  Although the game is something of a litmus test as I can count three instances where this game showed that some people really can’t handle anything beyond Sorry, Uno and Monopoly.  
I think the reason this game makes a better gateway game than Settler of Catan is that the tickets give players some very SPECIFIC goals that they can zero-in and focus on.  With very simple streamlined rules (for about 99% of the human population) and a set of starting individual goals that players can zero-in on, players can really get a hold of game after just a few rounds.  Yet there is strategy required here and players are focusing on multiple objectives and stay intrigued with gameplay even when its not their turn, breathlessly hopping no one blocks their route before they can play their hand.  
One thing you really do need to hammer in with new players is that there is no correlation between the color of your trains and the color of your routes/cards.  I’m not sure why, but it can be troubling for some people; for example, they want to claim a route that needs five green cards but then look at their (red) train supply and say, “oh, I can’t do that, I only have red trains” even though I’ve gone over the rules several times (and even laid down some routes myself).  They then realize that and say, “Oh, that’s right, I knew that!” but honestly, its just something they can’t get past mentally and I’ve seen it happen a few times while teaching the game.  Although once they are able to get past that, its bye bye to Sorry, Uno and Monopoly.  
Overall, Ticket to Ride is THE PERFECT GAME.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

However, simply adding the 1910 expansion vastly improves the game, amking it an often played enjoyable experience.

RATING: 10
This is an excellent game - in some ways it really reminded me of TranAmerica:
-hidden goal cards 
-connecting cities
-color coded player rails (not in TransAmerica)

but with a lot more added strategy
-no shared player networks
-limited links between cities
-must pay to create longer links
-bigger and bigger rewards for successfully completing larger links

Not only that - it plays very quickly - a lot of fun in a nice tidy little package.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A really nice game. The art and the concept are great. 

Ticket to Ride is really easy to play and to learn. The goal is to connect all the routes you have, to score more points than the other players. The routes are kept in secret, and only at the end of the game are revealed to score (+) or (-) points depending if you did the connection between the two places of the route or not. 

There are 3 options to do, but only 1 per turn. You can go for train tickets (the trains are colored), claim a route (discarding many train tickets according to the route path) and draw extra route tickets (to try to make more routes).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Played two player a couple of times.  Interesting concept, but I had two problems with it.  The main problem is the insane amount of card shuffling necessary to start the game and/or reshuffle the discard deck.  Since you play cards in sets of the same color, if you don't shuffle 10+ times, you will see these same sets show up again.  I can't count how many times we had the same card color show up four draws in a row.

The other problem was that there wasn't really any competition to get the tracks; I laid the ones to get my destination, and the other guy laid the ones to get his--there didn't seem to be much overlap in what we wanted.  This could easily be a problem with the two player game that doesn't show up with more players.

I could see this being a good game with more players and therefore more competition, but as a two player game, it's just ok.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
UPDATE: I can't remember the last time I've played this game or seen anyone in our game group play this. I keep it on the shelf mostly out of habit these days.

UPDATE: This game is starting to wear a little thin for me -- my desire to play this game again is becoming less and less but it's been a good run.

This has now replaced Transamerica as our "bring new gamers into the fold" game. Unlike Transamerica and other "non-gamer" games though, it's a good game in its own right. My only quibble with the game is the randomness of the routes -- you can know before the first turn if you're hosed.

See my review for more details.

Playing with people who love strategy is even better, as it can get very cutthroat. Downside is, there will be some games with little interaction (if say you're both completing tickets in very different areas). But even this is fun.

RATING: 9
This is a great game for several reasons. First, the mechanics are simple and it's easy to learn. Second, it moves along at a very good pace. Third, the excitement is there because at multiple points in the game you are forced to make critical decisions that could make or break you. Will another player take that critical route before I am able to get it? Should I gamble and take more tickets? It's just a lot of fun and easy enough that you can probably play with your kids. My 10 year-old has no problem handling this game.

RATING: 8
The backstory connection to the game is weak; the game feels more like you're building track than traveling around the country.  This is a game about set collection, where you use the sets to claim routes between cities.  Simple and accessible.  Plays quickly, with little downtime between turns.  There's tension in the game: do you continue to collect cards, or claim a route before you're blocked?

RATING: 9
Never intro'd anyone to TTR who doesn't enjoy it right away. It's always fun to play, even with very experienced players. Newbies won't feel so left behind, aside from the fact that they won't be familiar with the routes.

I also pick this game when playing with difficult players - not much interaction means everyone can play out their own strategies, while having a chance to block without killing each other's chance of winning. 

I highly recommend this game for anyone and everyone above 8 yo.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
(As of [b]2[/b] plays) Regarded as one of the "must-have" gateway games, as there is enough potential for player conflict to keep it entertaining without becoming too openly cutthroat. Not the flavor of the month for my gaming group, but I have finally successfully introduced this to my relatives, several of whom are positively [i]rabid[/i] about it. I can't say my heart leaps up at the prospect of playing it, but the fact that it has made my relatives interested in gaming is positively priceless.

[b]2 year verdict:[/b] After sitting dormant and unloved by my regular gaming group, I finally got my relatives to play this and, as a result, I can see many more plays of this in my future.

RATING: 8
Perfect gateway game.  

The game is easily explained in 5 minutes, and strategy is mostly intuitive.  It starts off with an open board and people typically cooperate.  However, it can quickly become more cutthroat as those spots start to fill in, and people are taking the cards you want.  But it never gets completely hopeless, which means everyone stays engaged the whole time.

RATING: 10
Truly one of the greatest games ever produced. I still remember my feeling of wonder the first time I played it; I felt like I had finally found something I had lost but had forgotten I even lost it. I like everything about this game from the simplicity of the rules to the collection of sets of cards to the claiming of routes. The game is also well-balanced between the desire to collect more cards and the need to claim routes before others get them. 

I consider the 1910 expansion essential, both for the larger cards and for the expanded ticket selection.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.75
Ticket to Ride is an interesting one to track on BGG.  I never know whether to track plays under the expansions or the base game, since you basically ignore everything except the trains and a deck of cards from the original.  I've leaned toward logging under expansions, but have not been consistent with it.

There's not a lot left to be said about Ticket to Ride that hasn't already been said.  It's a classic family game for a reason, and the elitists can pooh-pooh it all they want, but I still think it's a fantastic game that has stood the test of time very well.  The expansions add some neat twists, and the game is easy to teach.  Perhaps the best praise I can give to Ticket to Ride is to say that it's been a gateway game for family who really aren't gamers, and that is just wonderful.  I once organized a big family gathering at a rented house on the beach, and brought along some games to pass time in the evenings.  Two different people who were visiting went out and bought TTR within a week or two of the trip's end.  That's high praise coming from folks who hadn't played a board game in years.

My current ranking of the expansions / alt versions I've played:

1.) UK / Pennsylvania.  Both maps in this recent expansion are excellent.  The tech tree in UK is a lot of fun and gives you the opportunity to follow what other players are able to do and race to get access to the regions / routes that you want and need.  The set collection of the stocks in PA helps give alternatives to pulling tickets and makes end-game much more tense as you try to balance route size and chasing stock majorities.

2.) India / Switzerland.  I like that both of these maps are tighter, more heavily branched, so there's lots of competition, but less "oh, you took the one five train route going where I need to go, so now I have to come up with 15 different cards to work around it", because the links are typically closer together and shorter with more options.

3.) Original TTR.  Really solid, good ole USA map.  Fun with 1910 or the original rules.

4.) Africa.  I didn't really care for the way colors tended to cluster together.  If you are trying to get to a particular city, and it has two red routes facing the direction you're coming from, and you can't find any red, you're pretty well boned.  The terrain doubling mechanism was novel, but seemed to make for huge point swings that made it difficult to gauge who was the best target for blocking.  I wouldn't be in a hurry to play this map, given how many better choices there are.

5.) Rails and Sails.  Bad.  Bad bad bad.  The worst Ticket to Ride map by a huge margin.  The new depots combined with the two-card market made the game waaaayyyyyy more random.  The bigger board and higher piece count made the game wayyyyyyy longer than it should be.  This isn't just my least favorite of a game a like a lot.  This is a game I actively dislike.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
A very enjoyable card drafting game, with area denial elements. Simple to teach, but subtle enough to permit tactics. While some randomness is present due to the card drafting mechanic, this can be managed somewhat by learning to correctly assess the situation at hand, and deduce the intentions of your opponents. (Counting card helps too!) The conflict is indirect, but the effect of your actions can create significant impact on the other players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Rating history: 6|7...|8...|7.......|6..|5

Played 30+ times.
2p - lots
3p - lots
4p - some
5p - rare

2005: Played 20+ times. This game is WAAAAY simple, but somehow every playing this game gets a bit better. A cross between the lightness and theme of TransAmerica, the card drafting and turn angst of Union Pacific, and the route claiming of Empire Builder. And this game goes over INCREDIBLY well with non-gamers who seem to enjoy it even more than I do. A little duller with 2 players, but certainly quite good with any number.

July 2014: As you can see from my ratings history, there was a period of time where I quite enjoyed playing this game. But after 20+ plays, it comes to a point where it is easy to recognize when a player is going for a 20 point route, and then you have to block them, or match them. The gameplay itself is fine and has some tension, but 20 plays was enough of this game, and I am WAY past twenty plays. I feel like Union Pacific really is the better Moon train game - I still have that one at a 7. Ticket to Ride is down to a 5, and is close to going to a 4. I just don't want to play it anymore. I WON'T put it at a 4 though, because the game itself is fun for a while. Just not a lot of replayability in it for me.

Rather play:
Moon train game - Union Pacific
Light tactics game - Carcassonne
Short board game - Suburbia
Simple board game - Elfenland (3 rounds)

RATING: 9
This is a great game for new and old gamers.  I'm not sure how to rate this game because it should be 10 based on it's gateway potential alone.  In my situation it helped turn family and friends into a weekly gaming group.  That's worth a lot!  I recommend this before Settlers of Catan as a gateway game for new folks.  I think it plays faster and has more eye candy than Settlers.  On a personal level I find the US map kind of boring and the small cards in this game are really a pain to hold and shuffle.  For those reasons I rate Marklin higher and prefer it of the two.  I have not played Europe yet.  I have to admit that I was put off by the Choo-Choo look of the box and bought it as a sacrifice to family gaming with the kids. Turns out I love the gameplay and I'm hooked!   The game has tension and decision making delivered with a minimum of rules.  I'm always happy to play it.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
[Set Collection, Hand Management, Trains] [5P:5, 4P:5] Whee, this feels like a Michael Schacht game! Well, it also actually feels like an Alan Moon game - too simple, rather dry, zero tension, generally random and completely boring. I usually find myself saying to myself "is this it?", "what's taking everyone so long?" and "doo bee doo bee doo". TtR will probably win the SdJ (update: it just did) which just reinforces that it doesn't have the "X" factor that I look for in my games of choice. However, the production values are topnotch, and Days of Wonder continues to crank out absolutely stunning games. Now we need them to start working on heavier games than fluff like Pirate's Cove, Queen's Necklace, Mystery of the Abbey, Ticket to Ride and Memoir '44. I get giddy when I think of them doing a more substantial game. Here's hoping they snag Knizia's next "gamer's game"! *** UPDATE: Okay, TtR is painless, and it's a decent choice for people who need a simple, low-depth game to introduce non-gamers to the hobby. It's certainly leaps and bounds ahead of Settlers and that awful, awful aberration called Carcassonne. If you must have a nice, shiny featherlight game for non-gamers, make it this one.

RATING: 6.6
Added a bunch of plays to it but the true number of plays are probably closer to a hundred. It was my gateway game, bought it on a fluke at a sale and loved it. I have the USA 1910 expansion
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Has become a staple in our family since we got it in December 2011. Very simple to teach but surprisingly difficult to master, as you need to adjust your strategy based on the tickets you get - do you go for longest cross country routes or do you have bad tickets for that which forces you to do blocking and going for random 6 car routes? Do you start completing your tickets early to seize critical routes or do you hoard cards so as not to tip your hand before you have all the needed cards? When do you force the game to end? The optimal answers to these questions differ with each game and better players will win the vast majority of the time, despite the randomness associated with drawing tickets, drawing cards, and whether you end up competing heavily for certain routes.

Another fun aspect to this game is aesthetic as routes criss cross the board. One game ended with such a beautiful pattern that I literally snapped a picture and made it my phone's lock screen for a couple months.

My only complaint is the variability associated with drawing tickets - it is possible to be at a huge disadvantage out of the gate if you draw poor initial tickets. So we've been experimenting with variants like starting with 6 tickets and keeping at least 3, or starting with 4 tickets and keeping at least 2, etc.

Our family loves gateway games that are light-to medium rules complexity with medium depth to them, and this game fits the bill perfectly, right along with Pandemic and Settlers of Catan. This game's terrific reputation as an awesome gateway game is well deserved.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I love the simplicity of this game along with it's strategic implications.  This game simply does not click with me as a particularly fun game.

RATING: 7
After dropping hours and hours into the online game, I've decided to see how the board-version measured up. This is a fantastic game, but it isn't the greatest thing ever. In fact, I honestly preferred the online version, because it is insanely fast (games are 1/3 of the board-time).

Here's my view: If a game is lacking player interaction, then it better be a mind-bend (worthy of some serious thought and consideration). Otherwise, I'll pass, because it is a game where people sit around the table, don't interact with each other, and play solitaire.

I've found the only interaction in this game to be either: a) when two or more people need some of the same routes (this is the best interaction this game offers but it doesn't happen as often as I'd like in a 4 player game), or b) when you decide to be a complete ass and play a train route that you don't need only to destroy someone else's plans (this is cheap and I don't like it).

When all is done and said, good game that is easy to teach and periodically fun to play but I'd rather spend my time elsewhere.

RATING: 8
Received in Mail - 4/6/04. Scores of times both f-t-f and online. Rating this is difficult for me. It's a quick game, easy to teach, a great intro game for non-Euro gamers. And, it is equally good as a 2-player game. In all those respects, it deserves a 10. But is there enough depth to warrent a 10? Not in my book. It falls far short in depth and strategy. In those respects it rates a 6. Thus, over-all I would rate it a 7.5 to 8. When I want something fun and light with enough tension to keep my interest, this is the "Ticket." But when my destination is deeper involvement, this one doesn't take me there.

RATING: 9.5
This one is a no-brainer.  It has a great feel to it, is very easy to teach, and I imagine it will be considered a classic 10 years from now.  One of the best family/group of friends board games out there.  

Update February 2013: Have finally gotten back into gaming after a sort of break, and this game is still a ton of fun. I keep expecting it to get old, but it really doesn't. There's a reason it's so popular.  

Update feb 2016: Ticket to ride is a modern classic without equal for playing with ANYONE. The only thing keeping me from giving it a 10 is I can't decide which version is my favorite, but you cannot go wrong with original Ticket to ride and the 1910 expansion.

RATING: 7
I prefer European version, but a great house rule is that you can stop a player if you have locomotives (wild cards) equal to an opponent's number of played trains on their turn. Ie if someone wants a route and plays 4 whites, you can lay 4 wilds and you both lose the cards, but no trains are laid.

RATING: 6.5
I use this as a gateway game for playing with new or inexperienced gamers. I don't love it, but it is mildly engaging and super accessible.

This version has tiny train cards, which is quite unfortunate. I've played versions with standard cards and they are much nicer. Other versions add more elements to make the game more interesting as well - highly contested routes, tunnels, stations, and other innovations. Each of these adds a little - I think a more recent version might actually be a game I quite enjoy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A game which is OK, but not great. I do like that it's a connection game where you're competing to make connections, and there's skill in choosing the tickets you need to achieve. However I don't like that invariably everybody else is taking the cards you need so you're frustrated from making the connections anyway.

I like games where you can make a great move that sets you up. That just doesn't happen in Ticket to Ride - you have to lay down your tracks one at a time and it becomes very obvious which direction you're heading in. Your opponents are never surprised by your brilliant move. There's a lot of tension in the game, but it's just "I hope I don't get screwed over". I much prefer games where the tension is "I hope nobody sees my brilliant plan".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I have this on Xbox 360
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Blockbuster family game with good reason: great components, easy rules with some interesting choices (mostly about whether to lay short tracks or wait for better cards to lay long tracks, and whether to block other people). One of the first modern boardgames I played, so it'll always have a special place in my heart :-)

RATING: 8

RATING: 6
Made the mistake of playing Ticket to Ride: Europe before the original, and thus the original seems a bit bland by comparison. Still a very good game, though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Ticket to Ride offers a light route connection/set collection game.  I enjoy playing this game with both new gamers, and fellow long timers.  The choices aren't difficult, but this game can get wonderfully cutthroat, and then it's a race to avoid complete disaster.  Familiarity with TtR aids in the gameplay and can turn what appears to be a rather mundane exercise in collecting cards into a fun, strategic (on the light side), screw your neighbor route connection game.  The U.S. is still my favorite of the maps, and with the addition of 1910 expansion has added replay value (but makes it harder to figure out your opponents intentions).  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good game to bring to the table to get new players engaged and interested. The set collection is very straightforward and the ability to interact with opponents and block their routes creates enough tension to maintain interest to the end.  As is the case with Carcassonne, this gateway game is more satisfying with mean players.

RATING: 8
A very popular train game, and for good reason.  It's relatively simple, quick to learn, full of suspense and doesn't take hours to play.  Best with 4-5 players.  The components are well made and the board is rich with detail.  One downside is that one or two players can tend to master the game after a few sessions and dominate over less experienced players.  Overall, it's a great game that hits the table often.

RATING: 9.5
[Original comment] Excellent game. Our adult family group really enjoys this (as of August 2005, February 2006). Is played almost weekly. Good challenges, requires much planning and analysis, and some luck.

May 2009 -- This is still a favorite game for the family. However, with so many other fun games, and a little less gaming time, it doesn't get played as often as in the past. If it accommodated six players, it would be played more frequently.

October -- When we have fewer than 6 players for a game day, this (or TtR:Europe) is usually one we choose to play. It is definitely one of my wife's favorite games.

2013-November:  Still a bit family favorite. In fact, our grandson requested his own copy of this for a gift, and really enjoys playing it.

RATING: 8

RATING: 6
Unfortunately I just don't get this game a whole lot. Of the 3 gateways, this is my least favorite, and mostly has to do with the simplicity of the game. There is not very much strategy to this game, and the limited strategy that there is, everyone can pretty much get in their first couple of games. So, where's the challenge? It's still a fun 'activity' and won't really turn down a game of it, but wouldn't really suggest it. I guess why this is one of the better gateways--not a lot of challenge/strategy that people can't 'get'.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Pros:
* Easy to teach and it's usually very popular with non-gamers
* Components are both nice to look at and color/symbol coded to facilitate gameplay.
* Every turn has a nice tense feeling where you hope that your opponents don't see what you're up to and mess things up for you.

Cons:
* Too many long tracks and an incentive to just build a long consecutive track (because of the longest track bonus) leads to people just drawing massive amounts of cards and not really interacting with each other.
* Extra destination tickets are rarely drawn because of the above problem
* Too few destination tickets
* The cards are too small

The USA 1910 expansion solves much of the problems I have with this game. If you are going to play Ticket to Ride: USA, get the 1910 expansion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Played in a vicious/blocking high level fashion, it's a little interesting, but I'll usually choose something else.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.3
For our 2 player games we use the "Mega" card set with the following variant:

-2 Sets of trains for each player
-Separate destination tickets for each set (color)
-1 set of train cards for both colors

You decide on each of your turns which set to use your cards on.

When you pull new destination tickets you must declare which set they are for BEFORE looking at them.

The game does not end until the player has reduced both of his sets to 2 trains or less.

Score each player's lowest color x2, highest x1
Example: Player A has the Red and Blue sets. 
Blue scores 80. Red scores 110.
Player A's total score would be 80 X 2 + 110 = 270

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
To many players this is the ultimate gateway game. And I have to agree, this has many qualities to lure in people how don’t know that they are gamers. For me personally though, the game has faded a bit from its initial shine as it feels like rinse and repeat. However, there is a tension in when you are going to reveal your plan and when to build the most crucial parts of your network. If you start too early, it becomes easy to block you when people know where you want to build. If you are too late the good connections are taken. There is also a tension when you draw tickets, but other than that the game consists mostly of drawing cards. Personally I prefer the other games in the Ticket to Ride line more, but nothing beats the simplicity of the first game.

The game works well with any number of players.

[b]Last updated:[/b] October 2010

It's not an immediate go-to for me, but still one that I think everyone should have in their collection.

RATING: 9
Played 20+ Played with 3,4 and 5. This is a great game for the family. We played 3 times over the Easter break. Like with Elfenland, sensitive family members can get upset when a route they have been planning for an hour is maliciously messed up by another player in the last 5 minutes of play. The story about traveling around America in 7 days makes little sense. A more believable tale could have been thought up by Alan Moon which would have made the rules seem less abstract. Was enjoyed by a group who normally only play Trivial Pursuit. *UPDATE* This game is getting a lot of play and my respect is increasing. It stands up to competetive play online which is a good test. Oct 04

*UPDATE* I have now played this game face to face over 30 times mostly with none gaming relatives. It is the perfect Christmas game. I'll promote it to a 9. Dec 11

RATING: 5

I imagine that game play is improved by expansions or other base sets, but I am fairly turned off from the series at this point.

RATING: 7.5
Update: After 30 games (base and expansions), I have grown to appreciate this game more than I once did. It works with almost any group. I have never played with anyone who really hated it. I do think they should have included some variants to account for the fact that the base game does not play very well with 2 or 3. Instead you have to buy an expansion to fix this problem. An alternate board side or built in mechanism using routes would have been nice.

Regardless the mechanic is good, and the theme is nice. This is one of the few games that everyone I have introduced it to has requested again --- all non gamers and including my wife who is notoriously picky. If you only play 2 or 3 you could skip this entirely and go straight for Nordic Countries, it is designed for a small group.

RATING: 6.95

It's not that bad, decent actually,  but if you are playing with people who don't know how to play for fun, this one will end up generating some recriminations at the end "you blocked my only route, yadda, yadda, shut the fuck up already, yadda". If the game was a bit more complex, then I wouldn't mind that really (the whining that is), but in this particular case, someone is always going to be screwed, so unless you are a good sport, you may either want to avoid the game, or just put a lid on your complaints.

RATING: 9.5
This game is truly a 10. It may not be the game that I want to play all of the time anymore, but this game rivals or may even best Catan at this point for the most converts into gaming. It's not even in my top 10 games of all time, but I can't discount it's genius. If you are just getting into the hobby, do yourself a favor and go buy this game right now. Accessible, fun, hidden objectives, set collection, board play, take that, long term strategy, quick tactical decisions, expandable, great art, easy to teach, short game time, addictive and not the nerdiest thing on the block (all due respect to all of us nerds). Must have in any gamers collection. Parents will love it around holidays and my wife surely loves it so all I can say is, GAMING PERFECTION!

RATING: 7
Simple and fun, basically a set collection game with a train theme pasted on.  Strangely addictive.  I wish it had more choices and more conflict.  I find myself wanting the expansion even though I don't think it will fix either of my problems with the game.  I vascillate between disliking the game and playing it for 4 hours at a time.  The luck of the ticket draw can ruin a game, but the board is beautiful and the components are top notch.  The rating could go down a little but I don't see it ever going up.  My wife likes it and I can see pulling it out with non-gaming family, so thats a plus.

Update:  Dropped the initial rating...  this game is almost totally mindless.  It bores me after just a few plays.  I think the problem is that once you've got the 2 (maybe 3) winning tactics down, there isn't much here.  How much fun you will have playing this is directly proportional to how much fun the people you are playing it with are.  I guess thats true about all games but especially true about one as simple as TTR.

Still, I like this game.  You have to see it for what it is.  Full of luck, a filler, good for nongamers, etc.  This is what monopoly SHOULD have been!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Newbies love this game.  I don't think it's the bee's knees (I greatly prefer Union Pacific), but it's got some strategic merit.  I prefer playing with 3 players than with 5 -- strategy is worth more than luck with fewer players.  One key to the game is to play as many 6-links as you can, even if they don't help your routes that much.  In fact, if you're really daring, take the two cheapest routes, then ignore them completely, and try to screw with the other people's routes... that can lead to some pretty big negative scores all around, but less for you, because you're just going for the most points in links.  And don't take new tickets -- they don't help, as far as I can tell.  A 6-link is better than most tickets.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I find the game good fun. What I like best is its broad appeal, and finding people to play is easy. I actually prefer the T2R:Europe to this original version.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
An easy "euro" type game (no dice).  Players draw cards and attempt to build railroad segments between cities to score points.  These segments are built using color coded cards.  As an example, one needs to hand in a set of colored cards equal to the lenght and color of the track one wants to build/own between two cities.

Tickets are double edged, in that they provide you with extra points if you complete the route listed on the ticket, else you loose the points.

Once a player's markers (45) are reduced to less than 3, the last turn of the game is played, then the points are counted and compared to find a winner.

Player interaction is limited, although one may block another player by building a segment of track which he/she thinks the other player needs in order to complete a ticket.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[Initial Impression: 7]
This train-themed game is simple enough to be enjoyed by the whole family, but introduces newer players to multiple options on each turn and multiple scoring possibilities.  This makes it a very good introductory game (although TtR: Europe may be even better for this because the stations mitigate some possible cutthroat blocking moves).  However, with only one action per turn, the game can really bog down with high player counts (4-5), as each player will typically draw cards, wait for everyone else to take a turn, and then draw more cards.  This makes it feel like you aren't doing anything but drawing cards for much of the game.  In fact, some players will hoard cards by simply drawing for the first half of the game, only laying track when their needed routes appear threatened by other players.  Such hoarding can be a very good strategy, because it increases your ability to claim longer (and high-scoring) routes later, while also limiting which color routes your opponents will be able to claim.  Good players will usually also block some routes that they don't need, making it more difficult for opponents to complete their destination tickets.  Such play can sometimes put off new gamers, so it is important to know your group before employing such cutthroat tactics.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Trains Trains trains! A game of trains... Luck and strategy involved

Player takes two cards which (from 5 colours or 1 randomed) and once have sufficient number of color cards play and place trains according to the map.

Player with the most VP end of game wins. VP is based on number of trains placed - the longer the track more VP is awarded. There are mission cards to where player needs to connect two locations but if they do not by end of the game, their points will be deducted!

I love this game! Takes less than 20 minutes to explain and play a dummy round. 

Playable rating 8/10!

RATING: 6
I hate this game. Everybody has that reserved one time game where they can say "I hate this game, and you can't take that opinion away from me." I hate it like the Grinch hates Christmas, and I hate to see other people enjoy it even.

Still, I'll be a good sport and play it to the best of my ability, but don't mind me if I want to yawn my face off.

The game aims to be a gateway game and it is successful in that respect. There aren't a lot of options, and the depth you have is....well, you can potentially make a ton of decisions, but the decisions are extremely straightforward. Build your ticket.

I am giving this a 6 because it is a good gateway game, but I don't want to play it. No interaction with fellow players stops it from receiving a 7.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
11-10-09
I'll probably always hold an element of nostalgia towards this game.  It's the first 'eurogame' that I had, which my fiancee bought for us, looking for something with a little more depth without getting overburdened by rules.  It's a game that I can teach to and play with anyone - family, friends, gamers, non-gamers.  It's fun each time.  What it lacks in depth, I think it makes up for in ease-of-gameplay and overall fun factor.

I've lowered my rating to an 8 though after playing games of irritation by the cards.  Basically, you can have a perfect setup of destination cards but never get the right car cards and lose.  Or the opposite - you'll have great car cards to setup any track you want but can't get a good chain of destination cards.  Better yet, when a good endgame strategy become shotgunning through destination cards hoping you pick one you're already close to, the other 90% of the game feels unnecessary and lame.  We may as well just randomly drop train pieces on the board and randomly pick destination cards and see who came closest.

It's an irritating problem that has driven me to not want to play this game much.  I'll keep it with a relatively high rating because it has provided a lot of fun and I'll probably still play it in the future, but I don't view it as highly as my other 9-rated games.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
“You choo choo choose me?" - Ralph Wiggum

GAMEPLAY
One of the most well-known designer board games out there it has recently seen a huge influx of players with a very well done ios version of the game. The game turn consists of three simple choices. Pick up cards, play a train route by playing cards, or get more route cards. It's great because rounds go very quickly and no one feels left out. There is no direct interaction between players, but it is possible to block others from connecting routes.

COMPONENTS
The board is a good quality card stock and the cards are smaller than playing cards so small hands won’t have a problem. Days of wonder includes some extra trains of each color in case you lose some. Make sure to count out your trains before each game. The art throughout is wonderful, The trains themselves leave something to be desired, I would like to see wooden trains but that's nitpicking.

THEME
The base game uses a map of America which has about 40 cities on it. Connecting routes throughout the country is simple and resonates with most people as a traveling adventure. The small disconnect is that the players don’t have to connect the routes in sequence. This abstraction doesn’t distract from the enjoyment.

WHO IS IT FOR?
This game is for everybody. Really. I entertained three nephews ages 15, 16, and 18 recently. None of them gamers and they all had a great time. Families with children as young as 8 will have a great time with games lasting about 45 minutes. Even power gamers will enjoy it once in a while; there is light strategy based on your route cards and blocking the other players. For established gamers use it as a gateway for your friends you would like to engage in your hobby.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Yes, I've heard people say this is a "set collection" game, but it's simple fun nevertheless. Simple, quick, fun. It "feels" like one is building a railroad network, much like Railroad Tycoon, without the economics, but with all the desperation and paranoia as players fight to connect their cities. It seems to be a very good gateway game too. The 1910 expansion is a definite must have, as it has larger cards and more destinations.

Update (10/30/11): All plays recorded in the "1910" entry.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A feather-light gateway game that neatly unhorses [gameid=13] as the premier intro to hobby boardgaming.*  Surprisingly tense for such a simple setup.  You get to play tactically in the now, maneuver for mid-range goals as well as nurture an overall strategy.  Can be taught and grokked in moments; bright colors and beautiful art design make it a sensual pleasure to play.  Rating is probably slightly higher for newbies and slightly lower for hardcore gamers.  Still, an excellent way for veterans of the psychic wars to disengage, drop the intellect into neutral and just coast pleasantly along as a warm-up, a night-ender or as a relaxing activity when otherwise impaired.

Recommended!

:city::bluetrain::bluetrain::city::redtrain::city::bluetrain::bluetrain::city:

[size=7]Fig. 1 — [i]GODDAMMIT[/i][/size]

UPDATE:  Okay, it's just Rummy with scoring sets on a board, and secret scoring goals on the Ticket cards.  And like Rummy it's a mild social game.  An "eat, drink & be merry with good friends" game.  Played seriously or in silence it's stupid.  It's for chillin' while counting cards.

UP-UPDATE:  The only way I can play this game and maintain my sanity anymore is to pretend the board is the yarn map at FBI headquarters where they're tracking all those random railway murders.  Why did I have to get to Little Rock so damn bad?

HOBO STABBIN'

(+1 copy in the camping bin.)

[size=7]*I realize that today this notion is hideously out of date:  "Settlers of huh-what?"  But at the time it was all the rage, along with terror alerts and Nickelback.[/size]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A colourful set collection and route building game with universal appeal. There are a couple of fairly minor downsides: luck of the draw can't be eliminated from the initial tickets that you get, and once you've completed your first 2/3 tickets the game's nearly over, so taking more is a high risk play. The key to winning is to save your cards to build the longer links and not get rushed into building the shortest route to your destination. The US map is a bit bland when compared with later versions, but it's the balance between most of the scoring methods that makes this game, imbalance would make it half as good. The 1910 update goes a long way to solving the ticket problem, so I rarely play without it, but the base game is fine for casual play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Wish some of the games were expansions, but solid light fun. My non gamer friends seem to enjoy this one. (Even my Dad)

RATING: 7
Gets non-gamers' attention, but there is not much player interaction and the small cards are annoying if you don't buy the expansion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
When I tell people I play board games for a hobby, there's always the stigma that they think I spend hours and hours playing games like Monopoly and Candy Land. Not so. And if you're on this site reading this review, you probably know what I mean. So, in an effort to share our wonderful hobby we sometimes need those games that bridge the gap between the hardcore enthusiast, and the person who thinks Clue is a brain burner.

Enter Ticket to Ride! This is one of my go-to gateway games. You can teach it in about 5 minutes, and the game can be played within an hour...depending on your players of course.

And it's a pretty easy sell to. A train game of building railroads across the country. Connecting cities from one coast to another. There are all sorts of different sizes of tracks, that when claimed, give you victory points. This is a set collection game (i.e. you collect different sets of different colored train cars to claim routes). But the key to victory is in each players specific "tickets." These tickets are hidden information, for your eyes only. On them are two cities that you need to connect with a continuous railroad. At the end of the game, you score more points for completing these tickets. But beware, you will also go back that many points for NOT completing them!
This game is perfect for families. And the last few rounds always provide nail-biting tension that just seems to make the game enjoyable as you're all desperately trying to finish routes. Oh, and route blocking is perfectly legal!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
July 5th, 2007, I played my 2nd game. It's a quick learn (less than 5min) and quick play (~30min for 3 player). It does have a good balance of luck and strategy going for it, perhaps more luck. You build secret routes connecting two cities. Your opponents see your line forming, however they don't know your cities. You get more points the longer your route is between cities. Special bonus goes to the longest connected rail line. I'd recommend giving this a gameplay and consideration putting it into your rotation of games to play on a regular basis.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Players take turns drafting & drawing cards which they form sets with. Players can turn in their sets to claim sections of track on the map. Players try to complete there routes before their opponents claim tracks they need. Player with the most points wins.

RATING: 6
Ideal Players: 3-5

Description: Collect sets of colored cards to build your train line. Your goal is to complete secret missions dealt at the start of the game.

Pro: Simple and easy to understand. Great little plastic trains. Missions provide replayability.

Con: No depth of strategy. Cards make the game somewhat random.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Ticket to ride is clearly a well thoughtout and well made game. 

This game offers an absolutely beautiful game board with colorful pieces and an easy to read map.   It's fairly easy to learn and there are many ways to pull out the victory in this crazy train ride of a game.

The issue i have with this game is in the gameplay itself.  It's just simply not a game that anyone seems to get too rallied up or emotional over.  Its fun, and requires strategy,  however i dont feel the gameplay offers the wow factor.

With all this in consideration i give ticket to ride a 7.5 and one thumbs up.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A fairly decent family game, in which you are collecting sets of cards in order to claim train routes. 

Works well as a a gateway game, very simple rules and quick to get into.  I like any game that has missions of some description and as such I like the ticket mechanic here, you are always trying to connect two towns in order to score maximum points.

Only thing I don't like is the fact that seem cities can be blocked entirely from all directions quite quickly, this can mean that when drawing a new ticket all the options are impossible, meaning that by simply trying to draw new tickets you are guaranteed to lose points at the end of the game.  This is unlikely but can certainly happen, I believe that some of the expansions address this issue.

Overall, a nice game to introduce to non gamers and children, not much to keep a seasoned gamer interested though unfortunately.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Best gateway game I have, and one of the best games in my collection.  This game has been successful, at least to some degree, with every group I have shown it to.  Don't be fooled by the simplicity in the game design, there is a lot of strategy to be had with Ticket to Ride.

That being said, you absolutely, positively, need the 1910 expansion for this game.  The cards that come stock with this game are tiny, making it a hassle to read destinations, and shuffle train cards.  You can end up holding a lot of cards in your hand, so the small cards are terrible.  Aside from that complaint, the rest of the components are really nice.  Nicest board I own, it really impresses people the first time they play.

Another small complaint I have is that the game ends very abruptly, right when you feel like you are getting into the groove, someone runs out of trains and you only have 1 more turn.  This can be very strategic, because you can really mess other players up by trying to play a faster game, but I feel like the pacing is just a tad off.  The rest of the game is great though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Simple to learn, good depth of strategy to grow into.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Poor card stock limits this from going higher.  This is a great game with lots of different ways to win.  Always lots of fun as well.

Update:  I hear the expansion will provide bigger card stock!  Yey!  Pushing up my score to where it should be to reflect this.  8 -> 8.5

RATING: 7.5
I read the rules and had to pick up this game.  It was a risk since trains don't really appeal to me.  It's a good thing I did; it's one of my group's favorite games in my collection.  The game is very quick and tense as players fight and worm their way between cities to complete their tickets.  Very cutthroat game with three players, but less so with four.  Unfortunately, you can *easily* get screwed by another player (intentionally or not); that lowers the score by a point.  (I've traded the game away since picking up TtR Europe, because it is superior in every way.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great gateway game, my wife who is not into gaming and she loves to play this game. I would purchase the Expansion pack as it really increases the replay value. I think without the expansion I would lower my rating one or two points. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
With one play under my belt, I'm sad to say, given all the recommendations from friends, I'm underwhelmed. Just on sight alone, I would have guessed there were opportunities afoot to lose my lines or deal with other players to exchange them. Instead, once somebody was able to build on a one-train track, it was gone. I made both route tickets I opted to keep, sure, but the game just sat there for me. There's little room, in my opinion, with just two cards on a draw turn, to sense somebody going in a certain direction and work on trying to stop them. You're just hoping the trains you build are enough to make your tickets, and enough to stop others from overtaking you. I'd try it again to see which way the scales tip: towards the "pass" pile, or towards the "play" pile. On first glance of the comments, it seems people were really enamored with it when it came out. The low scores are more recent.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a game anyone new to board games should play.  It is essentially a route building game where you collect different colored train cards to be able to connect cities across the country.  You get points for making longer connections, and bonus points at the end for having the longest train network.

RATING: 7
After multiple playings this game is fun and I would play again but probably wouldn't be the one to suggest playing it. I fear that the same simplicity that makes this a great starter game in the eyes of many will equal shallowness and boredom upon too many repeat playings. However, it hasn't happened yet.  (Update: now it has)

Most annoying of all is the choice of components.  I hate the fact that many euros use non-standard card sizes.  The small cards in many euros are annoying, but often forgivable because the cards are usually only a small part of the game.  However, ANY game which focuses primarily on card play including BLUE MOON and Ticket to Ride should most definitely stick with standard sized cards.  They are what we are all used to holding comfortably and can be protected from wear by sleeves if heavily played.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Ask yourself this question, why is this better than Monopoly? Honestly think about it and you realize how overrated this game is...36??????????. (I am not a big fan of Monopoly BTW)

This is probably more random, same amount of luck (card draw vs. dice), same amount of strategy (very very little)although Monopoly probably has more, they are both set collection, the only bonus is this is over faster but most of the game all you do is draw cards like "GO FISH"? This is fun? Almost no choices to make here, pull a ticket, pull some more cards or build a route.

Monopoly at least has trading & negotiation, building up properties and an economic factor that makes it fun getting rich. The first 2 games of this I thought it wasn't bad and could see why people liked it but then it became very uninteresting and repetitive after that, this would have been somewhat better off being shorter and therefore not a bad filler, as it is it plays like a LONG filler but can still be used as a 'gateway game'. 

This gets rated one fraction below Monopoly and Europe is only a tad better but then its a tad longer which is not good for these kind of games. 

If you are looking for a very light gateway game that kids could play this certainly fits the bill. If you want a good gateway game that also has some substance and meaningful decisions to make keep looking.

RATING: 3
I don't really get it - what is so compelling about drawing two cards and claiming routes?  This game is BORING...

Negatives: it is repetitive, it has little to no replay value, it has few if any strategic decisions, it has few tactical decisions, and it is not even a proper train game.

Pluses: you can think about other games while you're playing, it is good for the younger crowd, you can play with the plastic trains and put them in little symmetric lines, and that's about it.

*yawn*

RATING: 6.2
In Ticket to Ride, players vie to create the most valuable train network using a limited number of route markers.  This is the game that introduced me to the world of designer board games.  While I am not always eager to put it back on the table now that I favor games with deeper game play, once play begins I have a great time strategizing my routes and laying down some track.  This should be a great family game.

Rating: 6.2 (Fun 6; Gameplay 6; Components 7; Theme 6)
Formula:
[Weighted rating = (((Fun*4) + (Gameplay*3) + (Components *2) + (Theme *1))/10)]

RATING: 8
Very fun and simple game. This game has seen a lot of play time and is a great introduction to boardgames for people that haven't played much beyond your typically thought of (i.e. monopoly) boardgame.  

Very simple mechanics and yet very tense play.

We have taught this to several non-gamers who have later gone out and purchased their own copy.

So far this is my favorite of the series, though the only other two I've played are [GameID=14996] and [GameID=21348].

All but four of my recorded games are played with the 1910 expansion cards and I have at least a dozen plays of this from before I started recording games.
