RATING: 8
No, this won't replace Transamerica in my lineup, as some may lead you to believe. Don't get me wrong, this is an excellent game. Tight and tough, where you feel as if you need to lock up a few key connections immediately, and sometimes you really must! This is a  longer and more challenging game than Transamerica. While TA is high on my list due to its simplicity and fast play, TTR is great when you need a little more game. This is my 2nd favorite Alan Moon game to date after Union Pacific. ***Special thanks to gamesurplus.com for this game!***

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Players either draft rail car cards, play melds of these cards to connect cities together (and score points), or draw ticket cards (hidden agenda points). Most points wins. It's a fun meld/connection game, looks wonderful, and like many Moon games it's quite derivative with that "I've seen this before" air about it. Sits between ultra-fluffy TransAmerica and more meaty Santa Fe Rails. Looks like it's aimed at families, and I can see it being a strong SdJ contender.

RATING: 7
Ticket to Ride is my gateway game of choice. It always seems to go over well with new players thanks to its simple mechanics and enough luck to make the game feel competitive, but veteran players also enjoy it thanks to plenty of advanced tactics that give them a better shot at winning.

For the USA map (which is a fine starting point for the series), I recommend it in all cases except for two players. There is too much empty space on the board without at least three playing. Luckily, there are plenty of other maps in the series that play great with two.

[b]Me[/b]: The game is way too easy.
[b]Wife[/b]: Then why do you always lose when we play it?
[b]Me[/b]: Because my brain shuts down and I just try to rush the end of the game. You're busy going for the longest route and I [i]really don't care[/i].

My favorite part of the game: putting it back into the box.

RATING: 8
The awesome thing about Ticket to Ride is that the decisions you have to make each turn are very small and manageable. This makes it easy to teach new players and good for parties where a lot of conversation is happening while you play. The price it pays for simplifying each turn, however, is pushing all the complexity to the end of the game when scores are finally totaled up. One or two sticklers almost always get stuck doing all the scoring while everyone else shrugs and walks away without really knowing who won. Everyone still always seems to have fun, though.

RATING: 3
2013-05-08

Initial Rating: 7.0 (April 2010)

One of the first games I ever played. At that time I actually liked the game, but nowadays I find the game to be very boring so I almost always do my best to avoid playing this although I can be convinced (if there is no other game available).

The problem is that I feel the game have obvious choices (always the same strategy), way too random for my liking (either you got the cards and tickets you need or you don`t) and also too light. In general I dislike games from Days of Wonders for those same reasons.

On the other hand the game is perfect to play with the family or to introduce new gamers to the hobby. It also have gorgeous components.

Current Rating: 3.0

RATING: 8
Classic fun for the family.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Ticket to Ride is simply the best game I've used for introducing people to gaming.

It is quickly picked up, it is fun for most, it does involve some thought, tension in timing, and risk in gambling (the destination tickets). The other important aspect of the game is the bonding and socializing of the players. That is true gaming interaction betwixt the gamers. Socializing is also the main lure to draw the new people back to gaming.

If you have a great night, even a relaxing night, with laughs and some gaming...well, you're going to get repeat players.
As long as I have people to play with, people to share my life with, people who will play my games I will be happy; and I will find (or create) deeper game groups too.

It's all about balance, and that's something that Ticket to Ride has. It's why the game works. It's why people learn it quick, it's why people come back to it. You can talk. You can laugh. You can block others. You can take risks. You can plan. 
Ticket to Ride has a very important element in its design; it's got the basics most gamers (even extremely casual ones) grew up with and it's close to card games they played. It doesn't hurt the head when playing (though I've seen lots of pained faces brooding over their cards and the board) and it allows for people to relax and talk. It removes the "chess" fear (think of math anxiety and you'll know what I'm talking about) from new players.

Is it the best gateway game? Yep.

I don't really find myself wanting to play it too often, but it's probably the best "gateway" game and it is easy for initiates and "non-gamers" to get into. I feel like I could rate this higher if the player count were higher than 5 in the base game (so that it can be played at large family gatherings). Still, good game nonetheless.

RATING: 7.5

RATING: 9

People dismiss it as "gateway" only, but I feel it has tons of strategy too. I think the comparison to "Canasta with a board" is accurate.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The perfect gateway game.  From the familiar map (for people in the US anyway), to the rummy-style card collecting and route-building, this game gets it all just right.  The turns move quickly, there's only indirect player interaction and I feel like everyone gets a sense of accomplishment, even if they didn't win.  The only minor drawbacks are the small cards it ships with (fixed with the 1910 expansion) and I would prefer wooden trains to plastic.  These small issues do not detract from the fact that this should be in everyone's collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
vendido 5/6/2015 20€
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
[b][url=http://www.spieldesjahres.de/cms/front_content.php?idcat=8]2004 Spiel des Jahres Winner[/url][/b]

With elegantly simple gameplay, Ticket to Ride can be learned in under 15 minutes, while providing players with intense strategic and tactical decisions every turn. Players collect cards of various types of train cars they then use to claim railway routes in North America. The longer the routes, the more points they earn. Additional points come to those who fulfill Destination Tickets – goal cards that connect distant cities; and to the player who builds the longest continuous route.

Players:   2, 3, 4, 5
Time:      30-60 min
Mechanics:  [property=2040][/property], [property=2081][/property], [property=2004][/property]

[u]Expansions[/u]
[center][floatleft][thing=24439]USA 1910[/thing][ImageID=144599 micro][/floatleft][/center]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Important step in the development of European games in North America: this is a simple game in which players compete for route completion between cities across North America for points. Fail to get the route finished by the end, you lose those points. The artwork is beautiful, routes are marked with detailed plastic train markers, and the game is easily graspable for kids too. Fun for the whole family!

BIG PLUS: quality of pieces, ease of play, replay ability
MINUS: easy to see when you're losing, tiny cards

RATING: 5
Liked it quite a bit when it first came out, but now all the expansions seem better (something that's not true with many other games).  The problem with the original was you could actually win by just taking all the 15-point links, make a couple of tickets and then get the longest train bonus.  I actually prefer versions that emphasize routes and getting more tickets and the 1910 version, which emphasizes tickets (with the Globemaster bonus for completed tickets), offers different tickets than the original came, and finally the larger size and more colorful train cards is far more enjoyable than the original.

RATING: 6
Always puzzled why anyone would think this is better than the obviously superior TTR: Europe

I saw a post where someone was saying they don't like Europe because the stations make blocking pointless and take away the tension. At least I have a view on why some might prefer Original. But of course you lose points using your stations, so if your opponents use them and you don't you get an advantage. 

Personally think stations, tunnels and ferries make it such a much better game thier really is no comparison, but to each there own.

RATING: 9
This game is pure 100% Euro genius.  It's simple to learn and addictive to play.  I've only played the American version so far but I have to say, my favorite part, hands down, is the extra points for having the longest train.  Nothing for the quickest route.  Nothing for the most efficient train line.  Nope.  In the American version, you get 10 extra points just for having the biggest, longest train that you can take from San Francisco to Orlando and still get to see most of Montana, North Dakota, and Maine along the way.  'MURICA!  Great game.

RATING: N/A
2 to 5 players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Start with route cards and figure out a path. Then collect the number of colored cards that match a track segment. Grey segments can allow any cards of the same color to be used. Engines are wild cards. Track segments score points with longer track segments scoring more points.  Complete the routes on the cards to score additional points. It is a nice family game.

RATING: 9
Great gateway/family game. Can be taught in a few minutes, and almost everyone I've ever played it with enjoys it. While many people complain that luck plays a large role in the game, from my experience the better players almost always win, sometimes in dramatic fashion. It can be played very cutthroat by experienced gamers, or enjoyed on a lower level by casual gamers.

USA is by far the best map, as it is the only one with enough long routes to make finishing quickly and scoring lots of points from non ticket sources a viable option. Blocking is also an important aspect to this map.

RATING: 9.25

Update (7/2014) - in reviewing my ratings I noticed that I unjustly had this at a 7. It is a wonderful game, my favorite map. Those that think that this is a luck game are simply wrong. In fact, I often hesitate to introduce this to new game players because they would lose so badly. With all experienced players, Ticket to Ride always guarantees a good time. The only thing keeping me from putting this at a 10 is the need to buy the 1910 expansion for full size cards. The cards included in this game are a travesty.

RATING: 8
Nice game for a non-gamer. I can see why it's easy and appealing. However, I feel that this game is a bit [b]too simple[/b]. Feels like a drawn-out Carcassonne. It has the same mechanics of indirect attacks like a good Eurogame. Perhaps there is more uncertainty in a large player game.Maybe this game is the recommended gateway game compared to Carcassonne because Carcassonne has the farmer element. It's hard for people to grasp that, where as Ticket to Ride's concepts are all [b]easily comprehended[/b].

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.7
A big hit in my circle. Fantastic thematically, great fun to play. turns are short so its always quick to come back to you so not too much down time. trying to create intricate routes to connect cities, and gambling on taking more mission cards as the game goes on are all fun mechanics. Super fun any everyone is always happy to play when we have a group, even the non gamers. Fun saving up cards of different colors and then building that one big track. Not too much strategic depth to be found, but for a game to relax and play with friends its a sure success.  

Cons:
-Can sometimes feel really bad if you get blocked from completing a big route and then you know you have lost the game but have to continue to play anyway. Has the potential for some really nasty plays made just to screw people over which leaves a sour taste. And losing a 21 point mission isnt just missing out on 21 points, its also getting -21 so its a 42 point swing which will single handedly decide a game. Many games decided in one turn/move.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Awesome game that is great for beginners just getting into more complex board games. This is a favorite at my house and I usually won't turn down a game when it's suggested. Works great as a two player game as well as with more plays (just note that the game can get really long if you have a lot of people playing). The train theme is very interesting and the little train figures are modelled well (and they give you a few extras in case you lose some!). I like how the cards are miniature so they don't take up as much room on the table (however, you still need a pretty big area to play this game properly). The only annoyance is that it's kind of annoying to be the person viewing the map from above (i.e. backwards, or to the south), as you're looking at everything upside-down.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Nice and quite fast. There's a high possibility of positive stress to be found in the endgame when you need to draw some crucial card to win a huge amount of points. It's, however, a little sad that the early game is just about drawing more and more cards because putting wagons on the board too early offers your opponents quite an easy chance to screw your game. Scoring system also benefits longer tracks too much which also encourages drawing cards early. With new maps and mechanical additions the basic TtR is turning more and more into a mere platform, for better, newer stuff. Also, I consider the original US map to be one of the weaker ones and most of my plays come on expansion maps.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I initially played this w/ a larger group when I first moved to Portland and really enjoyed it.  Then I discovered the wild world of gaming and forgot about this because I thought it was simplistic.  Now I've come back to it and appreciate it for what it is.  There is definitely a big component of luck with the card draw but the decision of where and when to play your trains can feel very strategic and I find myself in anxious anticipation of everyone's moves.  I have yet to play using the 1910 expansion (outside of just using the larger cards) nor any other expansions and am really looking forward to getting plays of this in again.  This will also play well with newbies/family which gives it an extra plus.

RATING: 8.3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Perhaps the perfect gateway game, I have yet to play this with a non-gamer who wasn't at least partially intrigued.  A brilliant design that deserves every award and accolade it has received.  Most games don't give you much of a clue as to any overarching strategy - your first couple plays might solely consist of fumbling through, trying different things out and seeing what works.  TTR obviates this through the destination tickets - right off the bat you have a few long term goals, and you can see each turn how much progress you have made toward them.  This makes things a lot easier for new players, and also leads to a nice balance between strategy and tactics.  

And yet... the more games I add to my collection, the less enthusiasm I have to get this one to the table.  A victim of its own success perhaps?  

approximate number of plays (pre-2017):  15
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
My family really loves this game, I like it well enough but I'd rather play something else if given the choice.  Probably one for most gaming libraries.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very well-designed game. Every turn you decide between only three things, but there is a lot of weight behind those decisions. Turns move quickly and the game is flexible in that if someone cuts off your original route, you can respond in a number of ways to better your situation. Maybe you'll find a different path. If you can't do that, maybe you'll abandon that ticket and go for the longest single route on the board just for the points, or maybe you'll take a chance and draw more tickets... There's a lot of hidden press-your-luck decisions in this game. It's always fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
~ Own digital edition (Android, STEAM)

RATING: 6
A simple gateway family route-building game. Great components, as usual, from Days of Wonder. The game is fun enough, but the base game is lacking. In my opinion, it is only really worth playing if you also have the 1910 expansion.

There certainly is a sense of increasing tension as the game progresses, but luck plays too large a factor in the outcome. I suppose this is normal for gateway games, but still I wish there was some way to mitigate the luck of the draw.

RATING: 9.5
[b]Purchase/Selling History[/b]: 
First played with Becca Barringer
Bought June '10 at Borders 40% off.

[b]Rating: 9.5[/b]
[i]Design rating[/i]: [b]4[/b]
[i]Component rating[/i]: [b]1[/b]
[i]Willingness to play rating[/i]: [b]1.5[/b] (+.5)
[i]Fun rating[/i]: [b]1.5[/b] (+.5)

[b]Players considerations[/b]: 
More the better, as routes become more scarce and players cannot simply do their own thing. But, players great for 2-3 also.

[b]My thoughts[/b]: I enjoy the race aspects of this game immensely, trying to fill your route before the other players and trying not to stretch yourself too thin.  Seems almost similar to Elfenland in that race regard, idk.  I wouldn't ever turn down a game of this, simple and fun and easy to teach and learn.

RATING: 9
This game for me never gets tiring it always seems fresh. It's like and not like elfenland, there are  simalarities and differences and here they are,  in both games you travel to cites and collect points,  and the differnce os in ticket to ride you get "destination cards" which if you travel from A to point B while building track (or using some of your old track) you earn a certain amount of points And in elfenland you get animal cards are boats that each one has different amount ofmovement they can move in each distinct area. I would recommend it to people  who are already fans of Alan R. Moon  are interested in it ( which should be everyone or your missing  out on fantastic game!

07_03
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Still my favorite game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It seems that you can’t go wrong with a Ticket to Ride board game. I’ve yet to find a person who doesn’t enjoy them and I've played them with nephews, nieces, in-laws, parents, friends, gamers, and non-gamers. Plus I still get a kick out of them after many plays. For all of the games in the series the rules are easy to learn, turns go quickly, and the basic strategy is apparent but the competition for links and the risk of getting blocked keeps things interesting for everyone.

This version is a great starting point. This, the first in the series, is the core system with no extra rules making it the quickest one to comprehend and teach while still being just as compelling as the other games. 

One drawback of this version is the tiny cards. This can be easily remedied by picking up the USA 1910 expansion which is highly recommended since it replaces all of the cards with larger format versions and also includes many extra optional destination tickets, an extra reward goal (the ’Globetrotter’ bonus for completing the most tickets) all of which work together to make a great game even better without adding complexity.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of the best introductory Euro games, I still love to play and teach it. The larger 1910 cards help a lot when shuffling.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Extremely easy to teach. Whenever I want to introduce the archetypical "non-gamer" to the hobby, chances are I'll start with this one. Turns moves fast and a full game can be finished within an hour, even with total newbies.

The amount of conflict can be adjusted by the players, so it has the potential of offering two different experiences without throwing balance out of the window, which is nice. Want a friendly game where each player tries to mind their own business, yet competing with others when they have similar objectives? You can have that. Or maybe you prefer a super cutthroat game where players are constantly blocking each other? That's possible too.

Funny enough, this is the opposite of Settlers in terms of luck impact: while luck can have a tremendous impact in determining the winner, its mechanisms give the illusion of a larger degree of control.

Rating: :star::star::star::star::nostar:

RATING: 9
Great family game.  If playing with 2 I strongly recommend my TTR Ghost Train variant.  Check the variants forums for it.  It makes a 2-player game much more enjoyable IMO.

After 60+ plays I still really enjoy this. It can suffer from randomness sometimes and that's frustrating but I perceive the randomness to also be a sort of wager component. Usually you aren't stretched to the end to finish tickets unless you set yourself up for that. I also really like how you can play casually and cutthroat.

This is my favorite map due to its elegance.

RATING: 10
Ticket to Ride / Zug um Zug is a fantastic - and light - railroad game. AND look at those components: Days of Wonders have made an outstanding beautiful game!
The game itself is simple and works like a toilet in train: Easy enough for the kids or no-gamers but still offers enough excitement for the real-gamers. Okay, there is quite a lot of card luck in this game, but I've seen, that veterans are in a better positions. This game is one of the best SdJ winner ever! I've played this one over 1000 games so far. If you love TtR, but wants some variations, just get the 1910 -expansion; it's better than those Europe/Scandinavion/Switzerland -editions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Based on the North American map, Ticket to Ride is the original. (Many board gamers erroneously call this game's map, the US map, but the game board does include Canadian cities, so they are only partially correct.) Although TtR does lack some of the more interesting features of its newer cousins (a la 'Ticket to Ride Europe' and 'Ticket to Ride Märklin Edition'), it is still a fun game to play. Be forewarned that luck is required (because of the card and ticket draws). However, the game plays quickly since there are only three possible actions to choose from during any particular turn. Some tactical play is possible (by blocking your opponent's key routes), but only if you have protected your own destination routes. All-in-all it's a good game to try out and play, if you've never done so before. If you are thinking of permanently adding one of the TtR games to your collection, one of the newer games in this series might be a better choice. {7}

RATING: 7
I enjoy Ticket to Ride. I'm not madly in love with it. In fact I like the app more than the actual board game, mostly because dealing with the trains and the scoring is so fiddly. The original is also not my favorite. It favors those who snag the 6-train routes. Too many tickets overlap, which encourages ticket-fishing. And it has too many choke points (the optimal number would be zero). 

Furthermore, I still hate that they sell this and Europe without the expansion decks. The expansion decks are far too expensive for what you are getting. Considering both this and Europe now routinely sell for under $40, they need to be done with the expansions and sell Deluxe versions of both.

RATING: 4
This game is the reference game that should win the award for HIGHEST INFORMATION OVEFLOW. First you must think of which connection you can do to connect your cities. Second, you must look out which colors you need to connect them. Third you must plan how are you going to pick up cards and manage your hand to place up track. At this point, there is enough informatin to manage. 

But normally, you should also be trying to expect where your oppoenent is trying to move. To do this You should watch the cards drawn and played by other players. And this should also influence the cards you are going to draw and play because you want to prevent other player from getting the right card or connecting the right city. 

Look, I am NOT a computer, I cannot keep track of that much information while playing.  So it is almost a solo multiplayer game, you do what you have to do and the game ends. Then you win or lose without knowing why.

edit

[q]This game is the reference game that should win the award for HIGHEST INFORMATION OVEFLOW[/q]

There is worst now, it's called dominant spiecies.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
An excellent game with only a slight superficial resemblance (in appearance) to Union Pacific, also designed by Mr. Moon.  T2R has universal appeal to the casual/non-gamer crowd and gamer fans alike, so it makes a great "gateway" game to introduce boardgaming to newbies.  The game's central challenges are card-set collections and tactical board strategy by laying train links.  It's nerve-wracking from turn to turn, in a delightful way, watching to see if others lay track where you want your tracks to be, or taking the train cards you covet.  The production quality is outstanding (as you come to expect from Days of Wonder).  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I've bumped my rating up after repeated playings. The game plays fast and is a great introduction game for new players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I liked this on my first play, back when I was new to this board game thing, but time and repeated plays have knocked it from its generous perch of a "7" rating. And it hit every branch.

I would almost go so far as to say this is the "illusion of a game".  You're basically playing an open-draw variant of rummy.  Scoring happens by placing trains on a map of the States, but this is where the game falls apart.  

You're secretly trying to connect certain cities to fulfill "Destination Tickets", but the winner is almost always decided by whomever happens to draw the Destination Tickets that work best together.  If you've got "Chicago - Boston" and also "New York - Santa Fe", all you've got to do is tack a few extra routes  to either end of the smaller one and you've got an extra 10 points free and clear.  Stupid.

Also, blocking other people is a negligible strategy, and I almost never saw it happen.  Sure, if you've got a Destination Ticket that directly competes with another person's, both of you are screwed.  As for claiming routes to purposely block someone else's path, are you really gonna waste the cards and a turn just to slow someone else down?  You're likely hurting yourself as much as her.

Lastly, the worst thing I can say about the game is that the best strategy I ever played with was to completely ignore the Destinations and just claim the longest routes on the board.  Completely contrary to the theme and spirit of the game, and so we arrive back at TtR's real predecessor:  RUMMY.

The only nice things I can say about this are (a) at least it's simple to teach and (b) the train theme is fun.  It's a shame they are selling so many of these, though, because all it's likely to do is make people think these "designer games" are almost as bad as Monopoly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Simple to learn. Easy to play. A great gateway game which has been well received by friends. I especially like the opportunity to play online through the excellent Days of Wonder site.

"Unnecessarily complicated. There are no dice or "action" modes. Players simply draw cards and try to complete their color-coded routes by using all or almost all of their 45 train-car pieces that mark the routes and hope that they aren’t blocked because an opponent has claimed that route. The scoring system is arcane and involves adding points as you progress on your routes. Of course, you may have to subtract points at the game’s merciful end if you are left with destination cards, each of which has an assigned point value. This also plays more like a card game than a board game.

What we learned: Ticket to Ride has nothing to do with the Beatles. There are several versions of the game, among them Ticket to Ride: Nordic Countries, and this was once named the German "Game of the Year," which we found fairly astounding."
[Star-Telegram 2009]
https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/471377/so-why-did-they-publish

RATING: 8
no dice, lots of trains. this game isn't like most "train" games where you manage how the trains function - this is about accumulating cards of the right type to enable you to build a route to put your trains on and gain victory points for those routes. you can also gain addition points by connecting cities. every game is different; even though the map never changes - the players and their approaches to the game are.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One of the perennial questions that people ask once they get deep into the board gaming hobby is "what's a good game to play with non-gamers?" with non-gamers including people who play the odd hand of Cribbage or game of Yahtzee once or twice a month. Right now, my best generic answer is Ticket to Ride.

Among Ticket to Ride's virtues, I would count the way it is built from a collection of straightforward mechanics (Carcassonne suffers from the opacity of farmers) that revolve around the fundamental act of building a network of connections on the map; turns go quickly, and many plays are obvious or straightforward – so not too stressful – but you have an underlying plan that keeps them meaningful; meaningful but non-malicious interaction (yes, deliberate blocking is possible, but you can avoid it without being obvious about it, a la the Robber in Settlers of Catan) and a nice sense of narrative produced organically by the fulfillment of tickets and how decisions feel different as the board fills up.

Not everything is sunshine and roses, of course. Arguably, the game would be better if it could keep the narrative arc while shaving fifteen minutes off the play time. For gamers, at least, I think you can argue that the game goes on a bit when it clocks in at 45 minutes. While the luck of the ticket draw is mitigated, it's not trivial, and I'm not sure the push your luck element of drawing more tickets evens it out. Because of the longest route bonus, a collection of tickets that naturally trace out a long route have a distinct advantage over a collection that are easier to fulfill when you branch your network.

I've only played one of the expansions (Switzerland) and that only once so far, so I'm not prepared to pontificate on that topic. Instead, I would say the general guidelines for good extensions would be: keep new systems strongly attached to TtR's network-building heart; extra randomness is deliberately push your luck, not getting randomly hosed with little option and don't make the game noticeably longer.

Not the second coming of Princes of Florence, but well-crafted light fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
If you didn't already know, Ticket to Ride is a light network building game that serves great as a gateway for new gamers. I wish hoarding train cards until you laid them all down in one fell swoop wasn't as good as it was (aside for the occasional choke point route), but that seems to be the most solid strategy in this game.

EDIT: I lowered my rating because I realized stockpiling cards before splurging in large bursts or just making aimless long connections can be quite good, and that really abstracts the theme of the game, focusing more on the set collection rummy part rather than the route building that implements up the train theme.

RATING: 3
This is hands down the most overrated game. People taut it as a great gateway game, but I think this would have discouraged me from gaming because there’s just so little to it. I hate games where there is always an obvious play. I could maybe enjoy this if there were points to be gained from preventing other people from completing routes somehow? But I’ve won every game I’ve played because there is just always an obvious decision. I played on my iPad for a little while, and I could tell from my initial destination draws roughly what my score would be and whether or not I would win. If you know the outcome before you start based on random luck, why even play?

RATING: 10
This game gets better the more you play.  Playing it online made me appreciate the subtle tension in the game.  Sometimes it is a little dry for me, but with the right group (mainly, a fast-playing one) this game shines.

The main tension is simple really.  It comes in deciding whether to take more cards or spend the cards you have to grab routes.  If you draw too many cards you might lose a key route, but if you move too fast to grab a route you'll find it hard to grab the longer, more valuable routes.  It's a simple game with simple decisions, but these simple decisions make for some interesting and challenging decisions.  The game's challenging simplicity makes it a classic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Easy to grasp yet with interesting, deep strategy behind it. Quite fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Classic, rummy style train game where you collect color sets to setup routes and score points.  Connect a couple of cities and you will score more points at the end of the game.  But if you do not finish the route, you go back that number of points.  

The base game can be a little mean in that you can cutoff players before they complete their routes.  

After many plays, there is an optimal set of East-West routes you can build which can make you very hard to beat.  But still a great family and gateway game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great lightweight draw and set-collecting game.  It really is brilliant in its simplicity.  It even has a little opportunity for player interaction by blocking routes.  Days of Wonder has a great site to play this by web.  Playing this online, however, has reduced my patience for playing face-to-face.

RATING: 5
Picked up 2006 (Christmas 2005)

This is probably the biggest game let-down I've ever had.

Simple to teach and easy to learn, so it does live up to its reputation as a great gateway game, but the lack of player interaction is a big dissapointment. Also, the game tension didn't feel very strong to us so we didn't feel like we accomplished anything after the game was over. Best with 5 players but even then we all found it to be pretty weak.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Fun entry level game that is easy to learn.  Each turn goes quickly with one of three simple options for each player, and there is opportunity to go big with risk-taking.  It is not a game with much depth, but is entertaining for a mixed-crowd or family.  Nice tension in the game while competing to claim routes,

The map and parts look nice - the game visually appealing with the different colored train routes.  The cards also have great art and nice quality.

The kids liked it right away but fun for adults too.

I rate the game higher with a higher number of players in which there is more tension in deciding where and when to build a track.

1
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
After 3 plays, not as excited as I thought I'd be. Midway through the first play the long route strategy became obvious to all of us. Perhaps there's a way around that, but right now it seems near-unstoppable. 

12/25: one play of this today convinced me to lower from 8 to 7. It's not the long-route strategy that annoys me. It's the solo feeling it gives. There is very little interaction, because screwing with others ALWAYS will hurt YOU more in the end, so you don't bother screwing with others. The decisions (lay down track now? or draw and lay down more track another turn?) *feel* important but now I see it matters very very little, and therefore is a pseudo-decision, which kinda pisses me off. Maaaaaybe I was spoiled this evening by playing a few games of Ingenious first, whose strategies began unfurling their petals like a flower. TtR felt incredibly flat in comparison.

3-1-08: Lowering to 6. I don't hate it, I guess.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Simple card driven railroad game. No stocks, no pick-up and deliver. Just collect the sets of cards and play them in order to establish a route between two cities. The more players, the more you curse your opponents. Excellent family game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I put off buying or playing this game for a few years because it looked like something I'd have played with my kids (except they were too old when I found it). I kept reading how grownups were playing, but the look still put me off. When out of town (non-gamer) relatives came in for a visit, we finally picked this up. We were amazed at how much fun it was and it remains a go-to favorite years later.

I only have the base game listed here because I consider TTR to be one game, with several variations. We own all of the boards and all of the maps now, and we even have the "First Journey" game for our grandson. We got rid of the card version because it was horrible. We never dared buy the dice version because the card version sucked so much.

Rules to TTR can be learned quickly and easily, by anyone from an 80 year old great grandma to a pre-teen. (Don't start with Rails and Sails or the England map.) The underlying strategy however, is another story. Turns move quickly, because you can only do one thing during your turn and you usually know what you want to do by the time your turn rolls around, except Dave.

This game is truly fun to play. Everyone we've ever taught to play LOVES the game and most people end up buying their own copy. I recommend the 1910 expansion because the cards are bigger and I'm old and blind. If you play a lot, I'd recommend some of the extra maps. Alvin & Dexter make for an interesting variant too.

Overall, this is probably the most played game in our collection.

RATING: 8
Honestly, I didn't think I would enjoy this game based on what I had read. Just seemed too tame and boring. Boy was I wrong.

While it is certainly not a deep game, it has enough light strategy going on to hold a players interest. It's universal appeal is a big upside here as it makes it easy to teach new players and get them interested in the game...and it can and will hit the table very often.

Any game I can teach to my parents, wife, and friends and that they actually request playing is certainly a win in my eyes.

Make routes, get points, block opponents, and make sure everything is well timed. A very enjoyable game.

Components are excellent too!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The perfect game system with which to introduce new players to the Euro-style game, and it has enough elegant depth to keep me playing. I love the subtle interaction between the drive to complete your own tickets, and the desire to block others. But why are they "tickets"? In my mind this is a game about building railways, not completing journeys.

RATING: 8
First impression: 8

Excelent game to play with the family. It is pretty light and luck based, but IMHO well balanced, and most important if you are planning to play with your non-gamer family, easy on rules and attractive, I've enjoyed it with family members from 12 years old to 65.

On the other hand, if you are planning to have a more serious gaming session with more advanced players, probably it is not a very good choice.

RATING: 7.5
Sencillo pero muy chulo! Un básico para empezar la afición. Pero me encanta!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Really the best gateway game for me : ultra-easy to teach, fun board and fun theme, with a strong strategy depth (there is an obvious difference between a first-timer and an experienced player, despite the simplicity of the gameplay).
What sells the prize to me is that, similarly to Carcassonne, you can either play competitively or "by yourself", and have fun in both cases, but contrary to Carc, a "nasty" move is costly to your own progress, and you only do it after careful examination (as opposed to attack as the only worthwhile way to play an unlucky tile).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I thought I wouldn't like this as much as TTR:Europe, which is the first game I played, but I like the tension on this board.  It's tough to get everywhere you want, especially when you can't use any stations to pull you through at the end!  The more I play this, the more I like this better than TTR:E.

Overall, I enjoy all the TTR games (I have all but Marklin).  Each works well in different groups and with different players.

[i]*Also own the USA 1910 expansion.[/i]

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is excellent for gamers and non-gamers alike. The rules are simple, the goal is clear, the game plays quick and smooth and tension is building quickly.

But the game has a unexpected depth as well. Shall I go for the long routes (20 points or so) or the short ones? Shall I collect more cards for the long tracks (5 and 6) or spill it on the shorter ones?
How should I detour when other players disrupt my perfect plans? And do I detour deliberately for more points? Or even for more flexibility?

This game is brilliant! 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
A delightful but highly competitive card/strategy/train building game that I am sure will get a higher rating after more plays.  A bit light on theme, but can get very tense (in a good way) near the end.  Ticket to Ride is the only game I know of where the scoring phase at the end of the game is as high stakes as the actual game play.  Not recommended for people who are put-off by high competition or sabotage; both are a big element of this game.  Looking forward to playing more.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
you dont need to love trains to love this game. This is brilliant - like carcassonne or settlers it is a good game to introduce to non-gamers. Better yet - I can play this with my five year old with a few minor rule changes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My husband and I really love this game. We played it many times (sometimes 3 per day) during my pregnancy. Now that our baby requires us to be more at home we find us playing this board game so happy as if we were dining out. Now we play it with more people and there is a sense of a party, mostly because of the game. I think that its best side is that you do not know if you may win or not until the end. I do not like Risk precisely for the opposite: Risk is designed for smashing others in a predatory way, so at the middle of the game a guy feels "dictatorial" and the others are just looking at their watches... I love Ticket to Ride exactly for being the opposite. TR has a little share of luck but no dice, so it is more strategical; almost all the players feel, throughout the game, that they can win. It is very easy to play, addictive and fun, really fun.

RATING: 8
Les Aventuriers du Rail

Parcourir le réseau tarabiscoté (représentant les Etats-Unis), atteindre ses objectifs et bloquer ceux des autres seront les moteurs des aventuriers du rail... 

Chaque joueur dispose pour cela de 45 wagons en tout et pour tout, et la partie se termine quand un joueur a moins de 3 wagons.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Nice tension between need to build up your hand for the future vs. the need to get track laid now before your opponents block you.  Easy enough to get new players and non-gamers into, but truly experienced players can easily demonstrate that there actually is a learning curve.

This is a great game, and I like the clean, elegant system of this game better than its descendants.

I object to the half-sized cards, particularly in a game that requires as much shuffling as this one.  But I guess if that's my only complaint, this game must be pretty darn good.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Have only played once, and then in the company of extremely experienced players.  It definately wasn't bad, it's another of Moon's set collection games and that's something he apparently has a great deal of experince with.  But I found the limited actions frustrating -- the choices were hard but not in a particularly "fun" way.  The lots of things to do but limited choice is also found in "Through the Desert" or "E&T" where I always want to be doing 2 or 3 different things.  A key difference there, I think, is that I always have to do the same amount of work.  Here,  I feel ripped off if I have to play 1 train or I need to draw one more card to do something useful.  The geometric point progression confounds this by making the short tracks huge wastes of your time score wise instead of merely large losses that are necessary for position.  Again, this isn't to say that I think it isn't fun or that it is unbalanced, rather it was just that I often felt an odd feeling of having been ripped off.  The route cards require a large degree of knowledge of the deck making a light game substantially less light if played correctly.

Update: have played a few online games and my ho-hum opinion still stands.  Maybe the next game will make it click for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The perfect gateway game, while still being fun for experienced gamers -- TTR changed how I thought about board games, and taught me a lot about what I liked. I'd been sticking with games like Carcassonne despite fading interest, and playing TTR for the first time was like a breath of fresh air. I've gone on to really enjoy a lot of other lighter Euros, particularly Zooloretto.

TTR was also the first game my entire group was always in the mood to play -- a rarity! I prefer both Marklin and Europe to vanilla TTR, but I'll still happily play it anytime.

The only problem I've run into is that (at least the way my group plays it) whoever lucks into the best long route tends to win. I'm told that if you play TTR more aggressively -- blocking at every opportunity -- an entirely different game emerges; I'd like to try that.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of the best games ever. It´s balanced mechanics blend together perfectly and make every game different. Depending in  the players experience the game has different layers, getting more and more complex.

Great replay ability however the game is best played with 4 players.

RATING: 5
While I see how the game could be attractive to so many gamers, I find it weirdly unsophisticated (perhaps because of its roots in melding card games). There is just too little in this game that could contribute to its "fun-factor". It feels very dry, and I really don't enjoy the silence that this games seems to induce at the table. And that I don't seem to get a handle on how to win TtR:xx doesn't help either.

While being an elegant, in many ways even a paradigmatic or iconic design, I have zero fun playing it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
If you can accept this game for what it is (a largely luck-driven game) then you should enjoy it. If you do not like randomness, look elsewhere.

Pros: 
-Easy to learn
-Easy to teach
-Great gateway game for new gamers and fun to play with non-gamers as well
-Most people seem to enjoy it
-Limited AP
-Expandability seems endless

Cons:
-Considering its price tag, the components should be better (I had to upgrade to wooden trains).
-Minimal strategy involved. Mostly luck-driven--cards are usually drawn randomly
-Multiplayer solitaire--if you like high player interaction, then this is not the game for you. Direct confrontation is rare

Overall, I really enjoy this game. It has grown on me quite a bit thanks to the exceptional iPad implementation. For 2 players though, definitely check out Switzerland/India map or Big Cites under the 1910 expansion. I have played Nordic Countries and did not enjoy it. I would recommend TTR to most people. In particular, I think children 12 and under would enjoy this game. For serious gamers, it can certainly be frustrating. Though, if you can accept it for what it is--a light, fun game, and don't take it too seriously, I think even the most hardcore gamers can find a gem here.

RATING: 8

This one also is more cutthroat, which adds a fun dimension to a simple gateway game.

RATING: 9
A great game for non-gamers. I like this game with any number of players. My wife and I have played it a couple times as a 2-player game. It was enjoyable. The game is solid with 3,4 or 5 players. It is best to adjust your strategy according to the number of players. Routes and tactics that work well in 3-player games, may not work well in 2-player or 5-player games for example. My family loves this game. Karen and I taught our Parents to play. They went back to Tulsa and bought 6 copies of the game as presents. Affectionately called "The Train Game."

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
One of the standard gateway games that I play with non-gamers or if people want a shorter game.  It serves this purpose very well.

What I like:
- Very easy to teach.  Only 3 fairly simple actions to explain
- It is a fairly short game (45-60 minutes) and there is not much downtime between turns.
- There is some tension in being able to complete your routes without being blocked (4-5 players)

What I don't like:
- You can get screwed right from the beginning with a poor starting ticket hand
- Luck of the draw (both from the deck and the face up pile) largely determines if you can collect all the sets you need
- There is not much tension with 2 players
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Great quick game.  The "expansion" really slows it down.  Easy to teach, great for a group with out much patience, or not big into games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Despite all the hype, all the awards, and all the love, Ticket to Ride is merely an ok set collection game.  In it, you are attempting to collect cards of the same colour to complete train routes across North America.  Whomever completes the routes totalling the greatest number of points wins.

No doubt the components are top notch.  The overly large board is a nice map, and the cards are very good quality. The best component is the plastic train pieces that are put out on the board to complete routes.

When I discovered Airlines Europe, by the same designer, it killed any lingering desire I had for continued ownership of Ticket to Ride.  That game is also about making routes, but with much more interesting decisions.  I can not, in good conscience, ever recommend Ticket to Ride knowing the far superior Airlines Europe exists. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Best game of 2004 and one of my top10 favorites.
This is the ultimate modern boardgame. If you don't enjoy TTR then our tastes probably don't have much in common! TTR has very simple rules, lots of replayability, possibility of memorable games ("remember when I stole that huge road there"), beautiful components, chance to improve your skill and hint of luck to even it out for new players (and to add excitement). 1910 isn't necessary but it's certainly very recommended expansion if you plan to play a lot! This is simply PERFECT game that brings non-gamers and gamers together in unique way.

2-Player Comment:
* I love all Ticket to Ride maps as 2p, it's the game I play most often with my wife. 

Expansions:
+Ticket to Ride: USA 1910 
+Ticket to Ride: Map Collection Volume 1 - Team Asia & Legendary Asia 
+Ticket to Ride: Map Collection Volume 2 - India & Switzerland 
+Ticket to Ride: Map Collection Volume 3 - The Heart of Africa
+Ticket to Ride: Map Collection Volume 4 - Nederland 
+Ticket to Ride: Map Collection Volume 5 - United Kingdom & Pennsylvania 

I also own Ticket to Ride: Europe, Nordic Countries and Märklin versions.

RATING: 7.5
We just "own" the computer version... despite buying TtRE, we got free access to TtRUSA - go figure. Feels a lot simpler than the European version - no tunnels, ferries or stations - just collect sets and slap 'em down. The single country (OK, 2) is a little dull, too, the Duluth-Houston link is hardly evocative of an epic train journey! The quality of play online is decent but weirdly, the downtime feels longer than when FtF despite the reverse being true. The computer AI in the solo version of the game is regrettably very weak, and you have to be pretty unlucky to lose even in what should be a crowded 5 player game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The word 'angst' is often used as a compliment for a game. We all want hard and crucial decisions to make each turn in our games. But for me Ticket to Ride has too much angst! You get to do so little per turn compared to what you'd like/need to do that it often feels very frustrating. The worst thing is playing a connection that is less than 4 trains. It is such an obviously inefficient move that it is literally painful to do. I don%u2019t think a game should punish a player so harshly for doing what is the central mechanic of the game %u2013 connecting two cities with trains. ****UPDATE**** After several more plays I've raised my rating a point. The funny thing is I still agree with all my criticisms above, but there's no denying that the game has a certain spark. And it's such a great introductory game for newbies that it deserves some credit for that. Overall I think it's a fine game that I don't mind playing.

RATING: 8
Awesome game. A nice game where multiple strategies can win, there is just enough luck and variability to keep it interesting without ruining things, and where you may have to change strategies even to win, not just react. And it has trains, so there you are :)

A great concept from start to finish and clearly it's been successful. It plays quickly if you think when it's not your turn, otherwise it can cause lag. Great looking board and pieces, good instructions, flexible for different number of players. 

Great replayability.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Take possession of color-coded railroads between cities by gaining and spending cards.

Easy game to understand, good for families.
Relies quite heavily on luck though, both with the destinations you get and the Wagon Cards you can pick.
Also, since the objectives are secret, it's pretty much a solitaire game until another player is taking routes near the ones you're trying to get and you have to adapt.

Other than that, a pleasant experience
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
The definitive gateway game. Not at all complicated, easy to teach, colorful, engaging for family and non-gamers. RATING: 9
Another great 'Infection vector' for getting new people into board games, suitable for children if you are willing not to be too strategic with them (i.e. don't block their obvious destination as they march from one city to the other link-by-link). On the other hand, when playing with adults there's nothing quite so much fun as buying a link somebody else clearly needs just to make them go the long way around. A good game to play before Munchkin.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.25
Interesting game of train routes that is really about optimizing over a grid.  The idea is to tie various cities together that are distant - the farther they are apart, the higher the score.  The best way of doing this is to build a web of routes and then get destination cards that are close to what you already have built.  It's a fun game and can get a little tense if you try to destroy other players' goals.

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Other games take the TtR formula and take it leaps and bounds above what this game offers, but this still stands as one of the great gateway games to turn newcomers on to resource management/territory control games.

This game will have every turn ending with players lamenting over their singular action and worrying about another player ruining their well-laid plans. From that comes my only real gripe with the game - it can be easy to dogpile a player in the lead, especially if you're a veteran who knows the route values and destinations more so than a newbie. With that in mind, it's generally best to minimize table talk and pseudo-quarterbacking between players.

If you're a veteran to the genre, you probably already have this game or can skip it, but it's a solid game to have in the collection otherwise.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This has been called the greatest gateway game ever, and I'd have to agree with that assessment.  This game has beautiful pieces and artwork, plus it's simple to explain, simple to understand, and simple to play.  It's so easy to get new players excited about this game, and the strategy is simple enough that everyone has a good time playing it.  The really tough strategy comes through meta-gaming as you try to outsmart your opponents and block their success, but none of that is required for simply having an enjoyable game.  While I'd generally prefer to play a more strategic middle-weight game with more experienced players, I love playing this game with a group of casual gamers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Our most played game and the #1 choice for introducing new people to board games. Easy to teach and heavy enough for some strategy but light enough to carry on a conversation during.

RATING: 9
Truly a gem in our family!  The game has some excellent qualities that are seemingly exclusive of each other.  Relatively deep planning and strategy with very little downtime.  Oftentimes, it's my turn again just after pouring myself a cup of coffee (yes, it's just that fast!).  Also, the scoring mechanisms are straightforward and doesn't require a lot of fiddling.  The game's final outcome always leaves everyone on the edge of their seat.  Truly a game that draws you in and keeps you.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Game in a Nutshell: Collect and play cards to create a chain of your trains connecting cities across the map. 

Played as: 3,4,5 player (online: 4 and 5 player)

Played with: 1910 expansion and without.

Pros: Fast pace, involving from beginning to end. Visually, very satisfying in a way that gives players a sense of progress when compared to other cube-pushers. My favorite map in the Ticket to Ride series, and the one best suited as a gateway for fellow Americans. And big props to any game that will get the non-gamers out there interested. You get a code when purchased that lets you play it online... with real people! 

Cons: Really there's one dominant strategy to this map and rules-set and it can hinge on what route cards you get. Generally the player who gets luckiest there is going to win. It's not going to draw in all new gamers since there isn't as much thought involved and may not feel challenging intellectually.

Other: It's been said that the expansion does more to fix the game rather then expand on it. I wouldn't go that far as I believe there is still a worthy game even without it. 

Best Use: Moving the rummy-variant aficionados into games with boards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Not a deep game, but overall a great game to play with non-gamers. There is some strategy involved in selecting routes which is something I like as opposed to solely a luck based game (though of course there is some luck with destination and train card draws). Can't say I would like to play this game all the time, but normally won't pass this up because it's one of the few games I can get my family to play. Only reason game is not a 9 is because I do get bored of the game, but still play anyway because it still provides somewhat of a challenge and tension and because my family enjoys it.

RATING: 6
I really USED to love this game. It was one of the first strategy games I learned. Very simple rules- collect cards and use cards of the same color to build routes connecting cities. Non-gamers can easily learn the rules in 5 minutes and play it in 30 minutes.

Some resource management in terms of deciding what cards to collect and when/where/how to build the routes.

However, after playing it online for a year, I have burnt out on the game big time. I do bring it every week to my games group as it's very popular among the lighter gamers and they can easily teach others to play. I think it's a good starter game but lacks the challenges, variety, and strategy to keep gamers interested in it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[microbadge=21390]

26-Jan-2014:  Still my favorite "gateway" game.  It's a great option for family gaming or a lighter option for hobby gamers.  With the absolute must-buy USA 1910 expansion, the replay value of this one is very high.  The rules are simple.  The components are great.  This is my first recommendation to any new gamer or family interested in the hobby.

08-Feb-2013: This is easily my favorite family friendly hobby game (or "gateway" game, if you will).  If you boil it down, it's basically a rummy style, set collection card game.  Players collect cards of various colors and when you have enough of one color to make a link between two cities on the map, you turn the cards in and place your trains marking track you own on the map.  You get points for reaching destinations based on other cards you choose at the beginning of the game as well as ones you add during gameplay.

This is a simple, fun, easy to learn/teach game for almost anyone.  Some gamers may find it too light and lacking in strategy for their taste, but for the right audience, this is an easy win in my book.

The components are great with a large, thick map board.  There are colorful, plastic trains to place on the map.  The one negative I have is the size of the cards that come with the base game.  Unless you have hands the size of a 6 year old, they can be pretty annoying.  I highly recommend buying the 1910 Expansion immediately upon purchase of the base set.  It's so worth it.  You get full size cards to replace the ones in the base game.  And you get additional destination cards, one additional end bonus card, and three additional ways to play the game.

We play this game with unintentional conflict, for the most part.  As a family, we are all generally working on our own set collections and destinations.  Eventually, as the map fills up more and more, you'll get in each others' way, but it's not malicious.  However, you can also just play it cutthroat and grab those hard to get, smaller connections right from the start and look to purposely block your opponents once you have a good idea where they are headed.  It depends on your group.

Either way, this is one of the best games I own for almost any situation where I want others to get a feel for our hobby.  It's not the deepest game around, but I think it's one of the best.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ticket to Ride offers quite a bit of bang for your buck, where I measure bucks in terms of time required to explain the game, ability to play without referring to the rules, and to play comfortably without too much familiarity with the game, or with gaming in general; and bang in terms of giving you different things to think about (timing, long routes vs. completing lots of tickets...) and different possible approaches. First time, Carl made a spider, which I thought was an intriguing borrowing of strategy from Havannah, which he's never played... 

Lighter than I'd imagined, but a very simple set of rules, which I appreciate. In theory, as people get more experienced and learn the cards, the game could turn overly defensive for something so light, although I haven't actually experienced this, and it seems to be addressed by the 1910 expansion. 

I had to drop my rating a bit due to the endgame problem. (That is, "luck into" a win by drawing the right tickets near the end, when you've nothing else to do.) I also have a problem with some details like the Duluth-to-Houston route being so useless. But (unlike Carcassonne) I'm still playing it, and it seems to have legs. Better with three than with two.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is a classic gateway game that works well with most families or non-gamers.  If you are new to gaming or need something to introduce others to this hobby this is a great choice.  However, my favorite of the series is the Europe version, so after reading these comments go check out my Europe comments.

In ticket to ride players are fighting to build train connections between cities.  Also enough of these connections will make a destination route from one city to another that isn't next to it.  Whoever can do the best will score the most points and win.

To start the game each player is dealt 3 destination routes.  These have point values on them where longer routes are worth more points than shorter routes.  So going from El Paso to Denver isn't worth as many points as going from San Francisco to Atlanta.  Before starting you may give up one of your routes if it just doesn't seem to fit well with the others, because it is advantageous to work on multiple routes all at once.

Now play will continue around the table with each player getting to choose one action from three options.  The first, and probably most commonly used, is to take train cards.  Five of them will be face up, with the rest face down.  These are a bunch of different colors that match the colors on the map which are required to get a certain connection between to cities.  You can either take a face up wild card, or you can take any two other cards, either face up or face down.  The other option is to use these train cards to actually build on the map.  One key here is once you take a connection nobody else can use it, so getting blocked and having to go around is common.  Each of these connections will score you points as you go.  The last option is to draw additional destination routes.  You draw 3, but you only have to keep 1 of them.  You can keep all 3 if you want, but this isn't common.

The game ends when somebody uses up almost all their trains (until they have less than 3) and each player then gets one last turn.  Then you add on to your points for each destination ticket you completed, and take away points for each one you don't.

This is very simple, for new gamers it can be very addictive.  This is a must have for any collection, although as I said before, I prefer the Europe version to this one.

[b]Game Length:[/b] (Short) :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Long)
[b]Complexity:[/b] (Easy) :star::halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Complex)
[b]Accessibility:[/b] (Non-Gamers) :star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Gamers)
[b]Luck Factor:[/b] (Luck Based) :star::halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Strategy Based)
[b]Re-playability:[/b] (Low) :star::halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar: (High)
[b]Value for Time:[/b] (Waste) :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Worth)
[b]Recommended # of Players:[/b] 3-5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
1.88
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.1
Enjoy it.  Light, a random element but it takes a decent bit of thought to play well, with a few different routes you can take(meant in the figurative sense).  Go for 5-6 length routes to score points.  Go for shorter length routes focusing on making a 'spiderweb' to make it easy to pick up extra destinations.  Play vicious and make connections solely to block others off.  It's enjoying a lot of play right now due to the fact its a recent addition, but I have the feeling this will be a 'at least once every two gaming sessions' light game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The best gateway game.  Still haven't played with anyone who didn't like it.

RATING: 8
A simple concept that can lead to deceptively complex game play.  This game was quite popular over the Christmas holiday of 2005.  I was able to introduce my extended family to the concept of board games without dice!  Because this game is so easy to jump in and go, it was very well received.  I actually lost on the first game to my sister who blew us all out of the water.  Fortunately I was able to redeem myself otherwise seppuku would have been in order.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is the game i pull out most when playing with non-gamers.  The 1910 expansion is a must with the larger cards.  My mother actually went out and purchased her own copy after playing one time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My sister-in-law got this game for Christmas, so at 5pm on Xmas day we sat down to play. Playing one game after another, we finished at 1am! The next day, the calls started early afternoon:
'You busy this evening? Maybe you want to play Ticket to Ride again?'
'Actually, I was gonna call you and suggest it, but I didn't want to sound like I've been thinking about it all morning.'
We played again on the 26th, 27th and New Year's Day. It's truly addictive.
There's a great cocktail of emotions when you play Ticket to Ride: Hope that you'll build your lines and complete tickets, fear that others will block your routes, relief at securing key connections and frustration when your plans are thwarted. Playing at a fast tempo with practically no downtime, you rollercoaster between these positive and negative emotions for 45 minutes and finish wanting more! 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A simple game at first. When you have some experience, you learn to guess what tickets your opponents have and what routes they will take. Then you can block them or make sure they don't grab a route you want before they do. There are also a lot of card-drafting tactics you can learn.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
[size=10][u][i][b]r{Initial Thoughts}r (after 5 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size]
* One of a handful of prototypical gateway games
* Mechanic (set collection) is easy/quick to teach to the newbiest of gaming newbies
* Game is enjoyable played politely or as a cutthroat affair
* Never disappoints as a great primer to our niche hobby, even with the most skeptical
* Great knifefight of a game with 2, crazy free for all with more
* Good for set collection fans and to inititate the uninitiated
* Initial rating: [b]7/10[/b]

[size=10][u][i][b]b{Further Thoughts}b (after 25 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size]
* Hasn't lost a step as the go to game when entertaining gaming newbies
* [b]1910[/b] expansion is essential for both extra routes and better-sized cards
* Have played other versions, but the original U.S. map has the most staying power
* Further rating: [b]7/10[/b]

[size=10][u][i][b]g{Advanced Thoughts}g (after 50 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size]
* Continues to hold a place in the collection as the newbie game of choice
* Rarely sees the light of day with anyone but the gaming uninitiated
* The next 50 plays might come as gaming/geography lessons with the kids
* Advanced rating: [b]7/10[/b]

RATING: 8
Played once.  This is a relatively simple network building game, but it's simplicity is its beauty.  It takes only minutes to explain, yet it's got both strategic (planning which routes to build) and tactical elements (responding to other players who are getting in your way), heavy player interaction (only a few trains can follow each route), and enough hard decisions to make the game just deliciously frustrating.  While it's no Puerto Rico or El Grande, it's a fun, enjoyable game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Draft and play sets of cards to build train routes and connect tickets for most points.

Plays: More than 100.
Type: VP race = a game where you race to collect victory points (fastest/most).
Complexity: Family game = a game that is easy to teach and play.
# of players: 3-5.
Playing time: 10 mins per player.
Player interaction: Competition for routes.
Randomness: Medium - card draw (lower with USA 1910 expansion).

Replayability: Very high, often everyone wants to play again immediately.
Fun: The fun lies in the decision making of hand and board management.
Memorability: Low, it's a VP engine that doesn't create stories.

Thematic integration: Weak.
Components: Nice.
Expansions: Definitely get USA 1910.

Who will like this: Everyone. No kidding. This is a must-have in every game collection. I have yet to encounter anyone who doesn't enjoy TTR. Even non-gamers often buy their own copy after playing.

RATING: 6.5
Szinte az összes TtR megvan 1-2 kivétellel, úgyhogy helytakarékossági okok miatt ezt már csak android appban vásároltam meg.

Szerintem az Európánál gyengébb valamivel (nincsenek kompok és alagutak pl), de egyébként teljesen jól működik az USA térkép is, főleg ha legalább négy játékos pakolgatja le egyszerre a vagonjait.

Kettesben nem túl jó a hatalmas térkép miatt, mert kevés az interakció (bár az az Európával sem az igazi, 2-3 játékosra a Nordic ajánlott, azt kifejezetten úgy tervezték, hogy kevesen is jó legyen).

Beugró játéknak oké, de inkább akkor már a TtR Europe vagy a Nordic, esetleg valamelyik egzotikus térkép (India, Afrika).

RATING: 6

If everyone knows how to play, Ticket to Ride can easily be tackled in 35-40 minutes.  Highly conducive to pounding beers!  Extra fun if all players agree to a "full aggression" pact, continually blocking each other's routes!

A solid 6.  Fun to play, but not enough of a gamers game for me to actually crave playing it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very simple gameplay and some simple strategy makes this one light and easy to pick up, but great fun to play. With 5 players games seem to go on for up to 1.5 hours which is longer than advertised. Suggested strategy would seem to be to accumulate a number of train cards over the first few rounds, then start laying down routes, aiming for the higher scoring, longer sections where possible.

RATING: 3
Good, light fun. Not a huge deal, but I can get the family to play it with me and not feel like beating my head against the table.

At least, I thought so.

As I noted for TTR: Europe, I am at a point now, where this is ultimately a total yawn-fest. I mean seriously, there may as well not even be a board and plastic trains - the game would play just as well with the deck of cards and a chart that lists score values for trading in particular sets. That really is all there is to it. No trading, no real interaction, just take cards or play cards. Not really that much fun. There are games they refuse to play with me. This may be one of the games I refuse to play with them.

RATING: 7.5
Fun game, but a little too much luck, I think. If a player draws a long route early, the game is heavily biased towards their eventual victory. A decent online game also makes the game available to people who otherwise might not come out for a board game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
For a design that ought to lead to a lighter, more social Eurogame, Ticket to Ride rewards silent and intense strategic contemplation and punishes players who are interested in talking together or otherwise interacting. (Cf. Settlers, where talk is built into the core mechanics of the game.) Also, as a game that rewards undermining other players its character seems closer to, say, Caylus than to Dominion. If you are not playing the game intensely, it seems more luck-driven than BGG players usually enjoy.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I have two main problems with TtR.  First of all, it's too easy to score points strictly by taking only the longest routes, despite the tickets you start with.  Just snag as many six-spot routes as you can and you'll almost always win - you can usually pick up a ticket or two along the way with only a couple of other routes.  Second, I despise the way that on the last turn or two of the game, someone who's losing can shoot the moon - they just grab three tickets, hoping that they'll either already have one completed, or be able to easily complete one by slapping down a quick one or two train route.  It's risky enough that someone in the lead should not try it, but not so risky that it doesn't work a good portion of the time.  It just irritates me.  A good gateway game, though, and we've used it successfully to bring a few gamers into the "Euro-Gamer" fold, and then we can move them along to something I like better.  (And it's all about me, of course...)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I've played this game to death. It's okay for what it is, but every time I play it, I am reminded of why I've gravitated away from gateway games. Too much luck of the draw. Get a good set of tickets, and you're golden. Get stuck with a couple duds, or get blocked out of the route you wanted to build, and you're going to have a bad game. Both of those things can be mitigated somewhat, of course. You can (and should) pay attention to what color cards your opponents are drawing, where they're building on the board, etc. But that only goes so far, and more often than not, you still end up being at the mercy of the tickets you've drawn.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.6
Ticket to Ride shows how a few simple rules can be combined to make an exceptionally rich and deep playing experience.  When played quickly, this feels like a wild race of the wits - it is fast, exciting, suspenseful and challenging.

EUROPE:  This is such a big map that there is no competition for routes.  Competition is further lessened by the station rules.  I guess this is good for folks who like a less aggressive style of play, but other maps support both play styles whereas this one does not allow for the aggressive, "dynamite joe" style of play.

ASIA: One side is a large map meant to be played with teams.  I haven't played the team game, but it's otherwise a big open map.  The smaller modern Asia map is a good map with some tough routes.

UK:  The board is a bit hard to read.  The technologies divide your attention away from the card-play and route-building.  It's a different feeling experience.

PENN:  The stock buying is somewhat neat, but not great at 2-players.

(Includes 1910, Europe, Asia, UK expansions)

RATING: 7.5
Ticket to Ride oder deutsch Zug um Zug ist schon fast ein Klassiker unter den Brettspielen und sollte in keiner Sammlung fehlen. Denn das Spielprinzip ist schnell erklärt und einfach zu meistern, liefert aber trotzdem genügend Abwechslung, um nicht zu schnell langweillig zu werden. Die Spieler müssen Zugstrecken zwischen einzelnen Städten vervollständigen, dafür benötigen sie Karten in der entsprechenden Farbe. Außerdem hat jeder Spieler noch Zielkarten, wodurch eher mehrere Städte miteinander verbinden muss. Dafür gibt es extra Siegpunkte.

RATING: 6.25
