That said, I prefer TTR:Europe to TTR for a few reasons:
 - I like the tunnels.  Yes, it adds some randomness, but it also adds a little tension.
 - I like the stations.  It adds another possible decision while making the game a little more newbie-friendly.
 - I prefer the European map more.  Of course, this is entirely subjective.

RATING: 10

Highly recommended as a gateway game and as a gift.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]Like:[/b]
-Pretty wel known
-Tension that comes from placing your trains before your opponents
-Funny thoughts and situations

[b]Dislike:[/b]
-Theme

A lovely game that has the advantage that a lot of people know it. It has so many small details that I'll mention in the following paragraphs that together make it sooo good!

The moment someone first starts placing their trains and everyone is like "Oh God, I better hurry up" and also start placing their trains like a chain reaction. Sooo funny!

The wild trains make this game amazing! "Should I place this route now that I can with the wild train or should I wait till I get the right color so I still have it left for later?" Mostly I choose the later and just end up with lots of unused wild trains.

Lastly, the moment you think "I kinda want a pink train, but there is none in the pool. I do have literally every other train though so I have nothing to lose drawing 2 blindly right? Oh God, I didn't have a green train yet! WHAT?! BROWN IS IN THE GAME TOO?!"

The only problem I find though is that it's hard to sell the game to someone with just the theme. Also, counting points is a bit tedious compared to other games but at least you don't know (exactly) how far you are behind.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A great game to break newbies into the world of board gaming past regular Risk or Monopoly. Simple, and fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Don't be fooled by Ticket to Ride.  It's light wargame that the whole family can enjoy.  First, you need to plan your axis of attack using destination cards.  Then you assemble your forces to conquer as many cities as you can - while keeping your lines of communication open.  It's great fun to foil your opponent's plans by conducting spoiler attacks to deny his or her avenue of approach or to keep the enemy guessing.  There are some tough choices that need to be made at the endgame which adds to the tension level.  After playing TtR, you'll be ready to move up to A Victory Lost.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The 1st time I played this game... I was open in my expectations yet still anticipating that it would be very good as it has a lot of supporters on BGG. I didn't get an immediate vibe of... "yes this is very good". Upon playing a 2nd and 3rd time it has improved as I see the strategies and tactics that can be explored in the game. The game is dead simple to play  and learn yet there are enough points where you need to make interesting and meaningful decisions that the game is not just a spiraling luck fest. While I don't think the game is extremely deep... there are several interesting strategies that can be pursued and I think we will get our money's worth out of this one as replayability looks good at this point. I have basically played only 2 player so far but 3-5 player looks to be even more interesting.

RATING: 5
I finally got to play this "gateway game" and Ticket to Ride certainly deserves its reputation. Simple and approachable with subtle interaction and a good balance between skill and luck. Plan your rail network based on hidden objectives but act before someone else claims a railway. Gamble to accept new objectives but be prepared to be penalized if you fail. A bit similar to the deeper Power Grid (which is recommended as the next game if you like Ticket to Ride).

It Sucks.  T2R is a game of trains. Build railroads which are previously marked on the board. Build the big ones first and be rewarded for it... then, start playing towards your mission cards. Pretty straight game and you play towards the same strategy over and over... until you get bored.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Overall comments: This is a rummy type game that is played with a board and a train theme. It is simple to grasp the concept and easy to get up and playing quickly. Card players have no trouble transitioning to this game.

Ratings:
Initial(wow factor):8 (very bright and colorful but the trains seemed kind of cheap)
Family: 6 (playing by the rules); 8 (playing developed variant)
Game group: 5 (most refuse to play it but I have one friend who enjoys the game)
AP rating: 9 (decisions are light)
Solo play: 8 (a very thought provoking twist on the Ticket to Ride idea - it takes away/limits the downsides to the original play - TtR Europe SoloPlay has also been put together)

When purchased: 2006
Recommend expansions: No
Age range: 8+ (4+ when playing variant)
Time to play: 60 minutes (20 minutes with variant)
Luck factor: 7 (card game but you can choose from those left by others)

Reason purchased: Geek and looking for a gateway game

Pros: it plays quick and decisions are light
Cons: bland play and if played correctly (ie. not using a variant) is very boring, card hoarding makes the gameplay inconsistent, game scores at the end are usually not close, game group won't touch it.  I played the Swiss expansion and that didn't help my opinion.  If anything it deepened it.

Recommendation: if you are a card player you may find this game an interesting diversion.  If you are looking for a strategic game, this is not it.  I do not recommend this game for the serious gamer.
Replayability: Low (plays the same everytime)
Gamevalue (play/cost ratio):Medium (only the occasional family variant play gets the game any group time but the SoloPlay rules set has increased the value to acceptable)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Collect cards of a train route to claim routes and fulfill destination tickets to earn points. Longer routes give more points. This maybe Alan Moon's best game so far. Lots of angst when deciding to collect cards but seeing your opponents inch closer to one of your destinations. Also tough decisions to whether draw from the destination ticket pile as well. Some luck on what you draw as destinations, and from drawing from the top of the train pile. The best game to play as an introductory Eurogame and can be played with any group.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I honestly don't understand the popularity of this game. at all. It is such a boring mediocre game. I would never recommend it as a gateway game either, because if I were new to boardgameing and got introduced this game, I will not come back to boardgaming again.

The game is essentially rummy variant. You spend many turns drawing two cards - oh dear. There is very little player-interaction in this game. It costs too much to block your opponents. So blocking happens rather randomly. This sort of random personal attack is my least favorite aspects in the player-interaction. You can, but don't need to care about other people's hand in this game because blocking is rare as the map has many alternative routes.

Destination cards have too much luck and huge swing between completion or incompletion - positive or negative. This is too rough and seems very unbalanced. Also tickets are valued merely by the length and, needless to say, they are quite unbalanced.

I must mention that the scoring scheme is extremely artificial. 1,2,4,7,10,15? What kind of sequence is that?
http://www.research.att.com/~njas/sequences/A027384
Long segments (5 or 6) clearly has huge advantage because they are far more economical. So of course everyone just keeps drawing cards until they get a set of 5 or 6.

I prefer Santa Fe for Moon's railroad game. As a train game (connection game), Trans America is much better than this. Something similar to Ticket to Ride that I much prefer will be Looting London and Marco Polo.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b][COLOR=#66CC33]Pro:[/COLOR][/b]  The accessibility for this game is amazing. You could teach kids probably as young as 5 this game, and even people that are stressed out from a hard days work and don't want to do any thinking could easily learn this and strategize in it if they were willing.

[b][COLOR=#66CC33]Pro:[/COLOR][/b]   The artwork is great, the colors on the board are clear, even with city names and route tracks all over the board, the game never seems like a cluttered mess so much as a beautiful and busy system of railroads. Because this game deals with color, if you're colorblind, this game will be impossible to play.

[b][COLOR=#66CC33]Pro:[/COLOR][/b]  The area control really is a lot of fun. You can collect cards in your hand of the same color for a specific rail road and think you're safe. "Ha, who else would have six white cards in their hand, right? Yeah... that track is safe". Suddenly your mother throws done a single white and five locomotives, and instantly demolishes the effort you put in to your collection. It's actually joyously devious, even when it doesn't mean to be.

[b][COLOR=#66CC33]Pro:[/COLOR][/b]  There's a push your luck element, which I really love. You can grab tickets whenever you want, but not completing them will lose you points, and you have to keep at least one. You need to consider when you draw them. But if two of the ones you draw are kinda in the same area, maybe you want to keep both? But remember, if you choose both, over the course of the game, the board will change with people placing their tracks, and suddenly those two cities that were really close now have the straight pathway blocked, and you have to travel halfway around the country in a circle to get to it. This game constantly throws wrenches into your plan when other players start catching on to your movements (and sometimes, even by accident).

[b][COLOR=#FF0033]Con:[/COLOR][/b] This game is decent at 2, but really shines at 4. If I were to rate it based on my experience with 4 player games alone, it may be a 9 or even a 10. But getting 4 players together isn't always possible, and lower counts of this game make it a lot less tight.

[b][COLOR=#FF0033]Con:[/COLOR][/b] When you're drawing tickets, you are drawing blindly from the top of a deck. For this reason, you may get three cards that completely screw you over, especially in the last half of the game when tracks are placed everywhere. Then someone else may draw cards that fit their strategy perfectly. This is part of the luck of this game that I'm not a huge fan of, but it's not that big of a problem.

[i][COLOR=#33CCFF]Final thoughts:[/COLOR] Gateways and mass market games get a reputation for being either too simple or too random to be good. I think Ticket to Ride subverts that reputation. Yeah, there's some randomness in it, but I think that there's only just enough randomness to provide excitement, while letting strategy and some risk taking pave the way to success in most circumstances.                 [/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
THE quintessential game for any occasion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
2-5 (2-5) [1.9]

Theme: Railroads

Mechanics: Set Collection, Area Control, Hidden Goals

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Ticket to Ride does a great many things well. It has simple rules: easy to learn, and easy to teach. Games are quick, taking about an hour to play. The game lets individuals build train networks (and building things is inherently fun), but it forces players to interact as players will place their trains in each other's way. There are genuine strategic choices, but there is enough luck to keep the game winnable for a wide range of players: the most strategic players will tend to do better but will not dominate every game.

All this makes it a game that appeals to a wide audience. I love playing this game, but I absolutely adore how I can play this game with anyone.

However, the original USA game is not my favorite. The cards are small. A few cities (like St. Louis and Charleston) do not have destination cards. Players dealt long east-west routes hold a distinct advantage over players trying to connect multiple short north-south routes. I strongly advise you to buy the USA 1910 expansion. It gives you larger cards, adds more destinations, and adds the most completed routes bonus.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
First Euro game owned.  Great gateway game. Depending on my mood and people playing present, it is played often.

An okay game, but stick with the online version.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Ticket To Ride is a good, yet childishly simple game. Its simplicity isn't a bad thing though; it is easy to teach. Play can be very fast if players don't overthink each turn as only one action is possible.

On our first playthrough a friend came up with a strategy that seems to circumvent the games intent: If a player does nothing but go for all the 6-car routes he'll make more points on average then someone completing tickets. If everyone were to play in this fashion then the tickets deck seems superfluous after the initial draw. After several games of testing, this method is a gamble: If other players haven't been snatching up the 6-car routes to complete their tickets, this strategy can pay off big. If the others have done so, then a player using this plan will have nothing more than a bunch of disconnected routes. If 2 people try the same method they will wind up with the lowest overall scores.

Oh, and everyone is right about the cards being way too small. The train deck as a whole is almost impossible to shuffle conventionally. Can't wait to get my hands on the Anniversary Edition!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One of the first games I got.  I believe this is the game that actually broke the mold for my wife and I.  It opened our horizons and left us wanting more.  I consider this game to be my groups original gateway game and I owe it a lot more than I give it credit for.

Players take destination cards that tell them what cities they need to connect by collecting train cards and matching sets of the proper colors to claim routes.  In the end players score points on the destination cards they finished, and the amount of trains they have on the board.

Fun game that is easy to teach and does not last too long.  Allows players to make some tough decisions without hurting the brain.

RATING: N/A
This game has a permanent spot in my heart as it was a birthday present from Zeynep. It's simple and light, it's very easy to learn, teach, yet very elegant in design, and most importantly it's always a crowd pleaser! A great gateway game that helped us introduce a few of our friends to modern board gaming. The game works best with four in my opinion, with two you get one of two scenarios: either both players fight for the same routes, which can get really annoying for both players, or players play on different sides of the board, which is just boring. Just for this reason alone I am thinking about getting an expansion for the game. We’ll see...

Note: This game has been played several times before I started logging plays.

RATING: 5
It's a game.  Not bad, but I will only suggest it if I know that I'll get declined for everything else.  Too chaotic and random for my taste.  I do not enjoy working intensely but blindly against the other player.  It has a little take that factor, but most of the time that is random (Oh, did you need Portland to Seattle? Sorry, so did I).  On the flip side, it is really hard to knock a game of which my family immediately purchased 4 copies.  Played mostly 2 and 3 player games.

After a week of playing a 5 player game every night, my feelings are the same.  If I want to impede someone, I want to do so purposefully.  If someone messes with me, I want it to be planned.  This just does not happen in our games.  BUT my family LOVES it!

Why this is not a 10:
-> I do not want to play this all the time
-> I feel like San Juan/RFTG has way more interaction than this game (which I prefer).
-> It feels like one draws a lot of cards, plays a bunch of trains, and sees what the score is
+ My family loves it so I get to play a game - Yeah!

RATING: 8
A fun and quick game. Easy to learn. Enough strategy to be light and keep you occupied. The standard US map seems to have a basic solution. If you get a route from New York to Los Angeles, you're pretty much set up for most routes. Any time I've won, I've had a cross country route.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
Great gateway game, probably the best one (replacing Catan). Even if it's very simple, it's not likely I'd refuse a game :-)

It doesn't have an important strategic content, but you take meaningful decisions each turn, and the tension keeps building up during the game, as you fill the pressure to place your links...

3 and 5 player games can be mean.

My only critics:
-> In some games you are already doomed at midgame, without any hope of catching up.
-> The ticket Los Angeles - Miami is ultra-powerful, and usually means winning the game. Not only the 20 points, but the 3 6 wagon links provide 45 points, and there are not enough tickets to create competition for these links.

RATING: 7.9
Exactly a family game. Easy to teach. Fun to play. You can play it with not-experienced board gamers too. Be sure they will like it. As you know some people does not like board games. They can see how funny playing board games can be by starting playing with Ticket To Ride. You cannot teach detailed games to these people but this one is easy to teach. No in game language texts, good usage of colors, quality game pieces and board. Balanced game and great game idea is included behind. Every game is not won by same person but generally better one wins but not 100%. A bit luck is included and it effects winner about 30%. Of course you also have to use your brain. A totally stupid one cannot win any game. Can playable fast it can end in 40-45 minutes in average after you experience some. Great replability, you can replay up to 5 times in some days. All families should have one. 

Increased score 0.2 points after playing its IPAD version tons of time.

Again increased score 0.2 points after playing its IPAD version tons of time. At total 0.4 score is increased. What a deep strategy game it was. I could not realize it in my first 20 games. Now I win 90% of my games with using better strategies. I was thinking it was a luck based game at first. After playing nearly 150 times at ipad aganist worldwide opponents I understood game's mechanics totally. And this game is awesome. Both it is easy and deep strategy. Have a very good replayibility. In all cases it is a good game and a good design. Congrats Alan R. Moon!

But still I lose because of luck, bad cards, opponents build in my way suddenly sometimes:(

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A great amount of risk vs. reward decisions in a short, non-threatening package. A touch too long for some casual gamers, and probably a few minutes too long for the depth of play.

I must also note that I absolutely adore the blocking, and find it hilarious how many people complain about the blocking element. That IS the entire game: trying to reach your destinations without tipping off too early where exactly you're going for. It's like a game of Twixt in that regard. If you can't handle a little competition and only want to deal with your own little farm/economy/castle without getting your feelings hurt, this isn't the game for you
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Finally played the much talked about and highly rated TtR, bringing it home for a weekend with the family. Was surprised how enjoyable it was (having read the rules before, it appeared a bit too simple and "flat" for me.)  Turns out it has alot of appeal, and a very good set of critical choices per turn.

I must confess, there's just something deeply entertaining about laying out your lines of train cars. In my opinion the Destination Tickets really help define the game, as I prefer games with some hidden element to them, and the surprise win from filling out your DT's while also building high-scoring routes turns TtR from a thought exercise into a true pleasure of a game.  

Another very important point for me is that the game flows along very smoothly, with very little downtime between turns, as the "analysis paralysis" seems to stay at a low rate with only mild peaks every so often.

Finally, it appears this weekend was yet another definite confirmation that this game works fabulously as an introduction to the bigger world of board games for non-heavy-gamers.  My brother was frothing at the mouth to play it again and again all weekend, and even my mom was eager to play another game right after the first.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

What is more, the USA version is much better than the Europe edition- mostly because the map is times better and, having no stations, the game is more thrilling.

RATING: 10
[b]Ticket to Ride[/b] was received in a trade (3/3/14). [COLOR=#FF0000]

A year later... thoughts and rating (10):[/COLOR]

[i]My family and I love this game, it is definitely a classic and in my opinion a must buy. This has also been a huge hit with extended family, my in-laws now have a copy and my dad really likes it. TTR has actually gotten more play as the months have rolled on. Everyone in my house loves this game and adding a new map was really fun. If I had to recommend one game to recommend to anyone, especially as a gateway game for family game nights, Ticket to Ride would be that game.[/i]

[COLOR=#FF0000]Initial thoughts and rating (9):[/COLOR]

[i]- Simplicity of choices: take trains, build routes, choose new route cards.
- My wife loves it!
- A very fun, relaxing game to play. (In the same vein as Finca and Takenoko)
Don't get me wrong, things still get tense when you think you have been cut out of a certain city, but usually you can find some way to get where you need to go.

We didn't play this game until we had been gaming for over 1.5 years. I was hesitant to get it because I thought we would find it too light, well I was wrong my whole family enjoys this game.[/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
(05/06/06)  Typisch zo'n spel waarin er weinig uitleg moet gegeven worden, en toch genoeg uitdaging biedt.  Een ideaal instap spel (naast de kolonisten van Catan) om iedereen kennis te laten maken met de wondere wereld der spellen.
De bedoeling in dit spel is om een aantal steden (kaart USA) met elkaar te verbinden.  Dit doe je door kleurkaartjes te verzamelen en op het gepaste moment te gebruiken om jou trajekt te bouwen.  Maar, wacht niet te lang, of anders ben je te laat en moet je soms grote omwegen maken om je opdracht(en) nog te kunnen vervullen.  Let op, alle opdrachten die niet vervuld zijn, zijn minpunten.  Wie er dan nog eens in slaagt om de langste route te bouwen, krijgt 10 extra punten.  (speelden mee: Danny, Dirk, Frederik en ikzelf).

If you are searching for a first game for yourself or someone else, this is a great pick.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Awesome game- I'll push my luck, a bit further, a bit further, yes, AAARRGHH I need that route, but now I don't even have enough trains to even complete my tickets... I'm so screwed!

Needs 1910. It's still good without it, but to be truly excellent T2R needs the expansion. 

The tension comes from the press your luck element. The more you build the more you empty your hand. If you have a big hand, you are threatening your opponents to potentially build anywhere. Hence you want to maintain a large hand for most of the game, keeping Jokers in reserve and using them last (I typically hoard them until either I'm desperate or to do a random 15 point build just before the end). Also draw face down cards early, and face up cards late. Most games I never take a face up loco.

It is best to go in cycles of "pick up, pick up, pick up, build, build, build" rather than "pick up, build, pick up, build, pick up, build" i.e. do as much building as possible in a short time frame. This reduces the window of opportunity for others to react to what you're doing in a way that harms you. However, this is where we reach the core problem of the game. The longer you wait before building, the more chance someone builds a key link before you.

Bought Dec 2004 and again summer 2012
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
not bad, but I expected a simulation of some kind.
in this game, you don´t have to build  networks to connect cities, you don´t have to transport goods or passengers, you don´t even have to catch a train in time.
It´s quite abstract with these colour-coded tracks.
Apart from that it is a nice family game, some risk and tactical decisions involved (so, do I take another destination card or not?), but not too deep, and nearly no interaction.

RATING: 10
All in all, Ticket to Ride is a great game for anyone. New or veteran gamer, it can be played by children as young as eight and would be a great game for a family game night. It may not be as in depth as some of the other games out there, but for a game that can be explained in minutes and introduced to new players with ease, it is a must in any game collection. After hundreds of plays, online and off, I still enjoy a good game of Ticket. Also, it plays very well at two players and at five, so it is very flexible.

RATING: 7
Great game with the family. Never introduced it to someone that didn't like it, although it can wear out its welcome after a while.

Quite tense when you are trying to get those last few routes done. Usually in my group there is high demand for routes and the person that gets all the long routes that line up ends up winning.

Doesn't get played much recently except for 2 player, since my sister burned out on it. She too much enjoyed blocking people and she got a bit twisted when she was on the receiving end a couple times.

So far enjoy USA, Europe, and Nordic Countries. Looking to pick up a couple more maps but haven't yet, as the cost seems a bit high. Mostly play 2 player anymore.

1910 expansion is mandatory. Death to the baby cards!

Great at all player counts.

High Score - Mega Game = 265 points
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
TTR got me into what I think of as modern boardgaming. simply collecting resources and marking territory by spending the correct resources allows you to complete goals. Resources are train cars of certain color,  territory is defined by rail paths, and goals are to two cities via paths. The real fun is trying to determine the path your opponent may be completing and claim those path segments to force your opponent to spend more resources.

Points are awarded based on all path segments and goals.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
All-time best gateway game (heard that one before?). Bonus: the addition of the 1910 expansion will keep veteran players into the game even after repeated plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Incredibly easy to teach, yet possesses a great deal of long-term strategy and planning.  I find it amazing that such simple mechanics can provide such a deep and rich game experience.  This game is all about timing, you really have to be able to read other players and play the routes you want right before someone else does.  I'm not a huge fan of the elimination of double-routes in the 3-player game, as it really makes getting certain cities difficult.

(5+ plays)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I need to try the USA expansion as this would add a lot to the rather bland base game?

One of the first games in my collection. The guy from my local game store always recommended it but I never fell for the 'train theme'. It turned out to be a lovely game and it got played a lot in the beginning. Learned me not to bother uninteresting themes and graphics on many euro games.

Nowadays it doesn't get played much because of the low interactivity with two players. Depending on the tickets you get in the game, you might never get in the way of the other player. Trying to mess with your opponent in a two player game is mostly a big guess work because there's so much alternative routes to complete your goals. Messing with other players works way better with 3+ players.

I'd love to try out the 'Nordic Countries' versionsbecause of the added mechanics but I must admit that it's on the lowest level of my wishlist. Playing someone else's game once might be enough to kill the itch. Ticket to Ride Europe is a much better game with the extra mechanics.

Great with newcomers to the hobby. Tried it once with five players; three where newbies that overtought their decisions which made such a nice a simple game drag for over two hours. Yuk.

More fun with three than two people.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Each player must complete a series of rail lines spanning cities based upon destination cards drawn at the beginning (and throughout) the game. Each destination carries points related to the length of the line, so a New York to Los Angeles line would score more points than Chicago to Boston. Incomplete destinations count against players at the end of the game, so completing them, even through circuitous routes is a must. The exciting part of the game comes from not knowing who is completing his or her lines, plus the ability to overlap lines, stymieing other players.

Game play takes between 30 and 90 minutes depending on the number of players and the speed at which they make decisions.

GAME PIECES

High quality throughout, the game includes:

- A fold-out board of the United States and southern Canada, plus a scoring track around the edge. The cities on the board connect through colored track lines, each line between one and six units in length.

- A set of destination cards showing lines that must be completed.

- Five sets of forty-five train pieces. Each player takes one same-color set of trains.

- A set of colored train cards that correspond to the colored lines that connect cities.

- Scoring markers that correspond to a player's train color.


Each player is dealt three destination cards in the beginning and must keep at least two. These form the basis for their lines. They also receive four train cards. To claim a line, players must create sets of the same color and number of train cards as the line connecting two cities. (The color of the lines has nothing to do with the player's train color, but the cards they have in hand.)

Each player, in turn, can perform one of three actions:

1. Draw two train cards per turn from either the set of five placed up for all players to see, or blind from the train card deck. (One card if one of the showing wild cards is chosen.)

2. Play a set of matching train card colors to claim a line between two cities.

3. Get dealt a new set of three destination cards, keeping at least one.

Players score points when they claim a line of track connecting two cities, the length of the track yielding proportionately higher scores. Scoring markers are moved around the 100-point scoring guide on the board perimeter.

When one player has laid all his or her train pieces, the other players get one last turn. Players then reveal their destination cards and add (or subtract, for incomplete lines) to their total. The longest continuous length of claimed track scores additional points, too. Highest point total wins.

Overall its a really fun game that can last a good amount of time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Light, entertaining game. The mechanics are extremely simple: collect sets of coulored train cards in order to claim routes between cities and fulfill your objective cards (called "tickets") or deny your opponents' tickets. The longer the routes between each city and the harder the tickets, the more points you get.
Ideal for introducing non-gamers to the hobby or when you just feel like relaxing a bit.

RATING: 8
I played this a couple of times back in they day and wasn't very impressed with it.  I gave the IOS app a shot and I'm glad I did, I wound up playing hundreds of games.  When I switched to an Android phone I downloaded again and kept playing.  Dozens of hours spent playing this on my phone.

With an increased appreciation for the game I bought a physical copy and I'm glad I did.  Playing face to face is a lot different than on the phone and I've found I've had to re-learn the strategy.

Also, as is often noted, this is one of the best gateway games of all time.

An excellent game, I'm glad I gave it a second chance.

RATING: 7
Simple and straightforward, this game is a modern classic. Collect sets of cards to build connections between cities in North America. String those connections together to complete missions in the form of tickets for additional points. Make sure you get that crucial connection before another player blocks you off.

This is one of the modern games I could recommend for nongamers without a geek introducing the game and rules.

RATING: 7
Good, easy to learn and play.  Biggest problem is the prevelance of the long routes winning.  TtR: Europe fixes this.

Update:  After having played some games recently, I think this is just a twist of TtR that is a little more cutthroat.  There's some definite viable strategy since there are such dangerous implications of being cut off (i.e. no stations, many critical single routes).  I still think that some of the routes might be a bit overpowered and overemphasized (Houston-New Orleans & Nashville-Atlanta), but I upped it from a 6 to a 7.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
*I've revisited TtR because I love connection games and the geography lesson they throw in. Now that the hype has gone, I've warmed to the design though it will never surpass the charm of the distilled and less confrontational TransAmerica. 

The race to place trains on prime routes, enforced by the tickets, is a source of most of the tension in the minds of some, though the set collecting (coupled with the 3 wild discard rule) and risk taking in drawing additional tickets ratchets up the stress as well, (though I find the US map for 2 player is too 'open' so not as exciting). Yet I can see that such an adrenaline rich experience can also be a source of frustration, especially with more players. 

I appreciate there is alot more decision making involved here than in TransAmerica, such as when to wait and draw or when to lay track, or when to switch from picking tickets to getting all your trains on the board.

But the main reason TtR falls short for me is that it is too 'score' heavy, with the summing up of the tickets making the end too anticlimatic unless I can enforced the "reveal rule". 

Update: Recently played 7 games in 3 days, which included 3 newbies who play Rummikub. Definitely a good intro to the new breed of boardgames (as well as the series) which initially induces alot of tension, but this soon evaporates when played with 2 or 3 as there doesn't seem to be enough conflict for cities (will have to try the expansion). Rating for at least 4 players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
When people think too hard about their turns it ruins an otherwise fast-paced and quick, light game. It is key that you play this with fast players. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
-

Update 08/14/07: Reduced rating from 7.5 to 7.2. Because of the insufficient number of destination cards, particularly the long ones, after several plays the long destination cards become well known and it can become easy to guess an opponent's routes, thus blocking tends to distract from the game. TtR 1910 fixes this issue for the most part, although it introduces its own luck factor. A player may end up with several overlapping routes, giving him a big advantage.

Other than that:
Ttr is highly entertaining, fun, and full of tension. Offers the player lots of play choices, tactical and strategical moves, and risk taking. Great balance for such a multi-player game. Some compare this to TransAmerica, but this is a much better and deeper game with a much higher replayability factor than the one dimentional TransAmerica.

I have further comments about TtR here:

http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geekforum.php3?action=viewthread&threadid=73775

-

RATING: 10
I like "light" games. I like strategic games. I like gateway games. I like family friendly games. I like games with player interaction. I like games where all players can feel they are never so far behind they cannot come out on top. And I like games in which there is luck, but long-term planning will generally win the day. 

TTR, to me, is all of these. 

Combine this with excellent components and a few beautifully simple and unique mechanics, and you have the closest thing we may ever see to an Everyman's game.

This probably isn't a game I'll play over and over; either you rarely play board games and get roped into this once in a while and never progress or this is a stepping stone to many deeper more interesting games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
It nails the lack of direct conflict pretty damn well, since the only interactions with other players are via blocking routes or hoarding colors. And the game is structured so that destination tickets are always hidden information and colors in hand are usually partially hidden. Thus there is rarely enough information to deduce other player's objectives, and next to no strategic basis for ever trying to deny them those objectives in place of pursuing your own. There might be an interesting game of bluff and tells and reading opponents if not for the fundamental flaw that the game calls a point system. Not only is this so fiddly that the typical game will have most players with moves scoring as low as 1 point while the game end totals are usually in the triple digits, but that mere fiddliness was not enough needless complexity for the sake of avoiding the very conflict that makes a game interesting. No sirree bob, Ticket To Ride avoids the low-burn kingblocking of typical Euros like Settlers by making one hundred and ten percent sure that it is impossible to deduce the currently leading player at any point in the game. Destinations are usually the biggest component of a player's endgame score, and they are kept secret until the endgame, and everyone has several all the time. And if you don't complete them, they count negative. So not only is there no way to know any other players' actual score at any point where you could make a choice based on that knowledge, but there's not even a usual approximation based on averages from that hidden information -- you can't assume that the player with more Destination tickets in hand has a higher hidden component of their score, because they are just as likely to have additional negative points as positive points. 

This is not a train game, this is a train wreck of a game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Another great game. Great for families or even just 2 p.

RATING: 5
A fine, if somewhat dull game. There's not much to it, either in the rules themselves or in playing off of the other players. The scoring track is pretty fiddly, as people often forget to record their points after playing a route. Another issue is that the endgame can come down to people who are hopelessly behind drawing random route cards and hoping to draw routes that they already have completed, which feels hollow and unearned. I would always rather play something else.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

RATING: 8
If you like trains you'll probably like Ticket to Ride.  This game is all about completing train routes from city to city throughout the US.  Players collect colored cards that can be used to claim city to city routes on the board. Players are also trying to complete their secret route tickets for big points!

RATING: 8
Much more than the perfect gateway game (which it actually is, that's for granted)
So simple, so elegant, so exciting, so beautiful... we just love it as it is. Don't feel like getting any expansions or moving to any other train games.
After more than 100 plays, everytime we take it we end up playing it more than once.
Finally, I don't agree with so many people that consider it too light (not for real gamers). The rules and the mechanics are pretty easy, it can be great for kids (maybe 7+) and sure there's luck involved, but there's also plenty of strategy and tactics in TTR.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.3
Not a great but not a bad game either. This is definitively one good familly game where chance plays an important rôle, almost has important has strategy. So even if you are not an experienced player, if you can get the right card at the right moment, you can beat anyone. Definitively spouce approuved for me.

Pas un grand jeu, mais en même temps pas un mauvais jeu. Définitivement un bon jeu familiale ou la chance joue un rôle tout aussi important que la stratégie. Donc même si vous êtes inexpérimenté à ce jeu, si vous obtenez les bonnes cartes au bon moment, vous pouvez alors battre n'importe quel joueur. Définitivement un jeu approuvé par ma conjointe.

[ESP]El clásico familiar que sigue y seguirá saliendo a mesa(con su expansión), es para mí el mejor juego para atraer jugadores. Con este empezó a volverse serio el hobby.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
In the three years I lived with my non-gamer college housemates, this was the only one of the games I showed them that they legitimately loved playing. One of my housemates bought the Ticket to Ride app within a week and, at the peak of his obsession, poured six hours a day into playing online with strangers [not counting a few face-to-face games he badgered us into playing with him each night]. It's simple, it's fast, it's strategic, it's fun. I personally find other, more complex games more rewarding and based on my enjoyment alone I'd give it an 8 or 9, but I have to give it a 10 because it fulfills its purpose (introducing non-gamers to our style of games) so well. It's the perfect gateway game.

Edit: On TTR's tenth anniversary, someone posted the article on my Facebook wall, and all the non-gamers I introduced to TTR posted a bunch of comments about how awesome this game is and how much fun they have playing it. Keep that in mind next time someone tries to tell you that this game is "boring" or "not a true game."

#2 on personal list "Top 10 games for a new gamer to own" (should really be #1, and only missed that spot due to blatant favoritism)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I can't really add a whole lot to the volumes that have been written about this game.  It's not bad, and it's great for introducing folks to modern board gaming.  The low rating is a result of situations where there is too much luck involved.  If people are only focusing on their own routes, the winner is almost randomly determined.  The game gets better when people are a little more confrontational, but then you run the risk of someone who is alone on part of the board cruising to victory.  Well, there are far worse ways to spend an hour.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Not a bad game by any account, but considering this is one of the most popular gateway games I did expect more of an intriguingly designed game with some irresistible finesse, a la Settlers of Catan or Carcassonne, two games which are simple, yet ingenious. But Ticket to Ride is more or less nothing but the collection of coloured cards and playing this cards as soon as you accumulated the target number (the higher the better). Throw in the whole kerfuffle about train routes and the ability to 'block' other players and you have yourself a boardgame. It works alright and is not bad but I feel that the game is not more than the sum of its parts and it does not click with me.

RATING: N/A
The game is fun to play.  You get three cards with to and from destinations.  You build your line trying to connect as many of the destinations as possible.  If you connect destinations listed on the card you get the points on the card.  You also get points for destinations in between while trying to full fill the card.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Pros:
1. Easy to teach. This game can be taught about 5 minutes.
2. Fun to play. The game has a good mix of luck and strategy. Making a great game to play with new gamers.
3. Plays quick. This game plays in less than an hour.

Cons:
1. Set Strategies: There is a clear strategy to this game that can give you the upper hand. Experienced players who know this will easy beat any new gamers. It also makes the game boring as once this is figured out, there's not a large reason to play.

Summary: This is a game that should be in every house. Everyone should toss their copy of Monopoly and replace it with this game. I have literally not played this game with somebody who didn't like it. Buy it and play it, you will get your money's worth.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I have played this game with my niece at least 6 or 7 times just this past week. I have also played it with a few adults who aren't very interested in games and it has gone down quite well. Some people might think that it is boring because it isn't a "proper" train game, whatever that may be. There isn't a lot of heavy strategy going on in this game which is nice. Sure there are a lot of ways to connect the different routes, which adds a little to the strategy. Do you try to play in an obvious manner and claim routes in a line, or are you a little sneaky, and try to hope that it all coalesces towards the end of the game? I can imagine that with more players it would become quite intense as there are more players potentially competing for the same routes. 
Sure there is a little downtime while everyone is just taking two (or one if you get the up facing locomotive!) cards. However, in this game you can really crush someones dream. I had to laugh at my niece because she would always celebrate when she got certain cards, and I would think that was funny. If you lose friends over playing a game like this, then maybe you should look at the type of company that you keep? Seriously, if your friends cannot take losing in a game as simple and light as this, then maybe that does say more about you than the game. Overall, I really like this series of games. I think it would appeal mostly to children and non-gamers. I would consider this game as a great gateway game for kids who have only played Cluedo and Monopoly. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Just played this game for the first time! Really enjoyed it. Came fairly close to last, but still liked the fact that it was a fast paced game and simple. Seemed to have a similar feel to the real-thing. Can imagine playing it often in the future.

RATING: 6
Box in fantastic condition, cards all in nearly unplayed condition.  No wear.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
From a gateway-accessibility angle, it is easy to recommend TtR for American non-gamers. [b]One of the best (if not THE best) gateway boardgames.[/b] Stay away from TtR:Europe for American beginners, due to the weirdness of the European cities for Americans.
I can't decide which is the better game, between TtR and TtR:Europe. Each has strengths. I'd rather have TtR:Europe with more hardcore gamers, and TtR with family/non-gamers, I guess. And since family/non-gamers is where this series is aimed at (IMO), I conclude that TtR is the better game at succeeding with its target demographic.
TtR is a hard game to 'play down' on, and unfortunately usually leads to 1st-time players getting blown out, points-wise.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
There is more to this game than just being the first to race from one city to the mext, or from coast to coast as one does in other train games (TransAmerica). That is not enough. You also must be willing to do other things to win, like take on more routes to complete or potentially fail, and making the longest train route.  And you can't just finish your objectives to win, you still must trigger an end of the game by someone having 2 trains or less remaining on their turn.

RATING: 10
This game was one of the first I played after being introduced to gaming. I can't over stress what a great gate-way game this is. The mechanics of the game and the strategy are easy to pick up and the game's dynamics vary a great deal with every new player added to it. The best part of the game is the odd sense of satisfaction a person gets from laying down some track and completing a route. The game is a real motivator for the OCD crowd.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
VERY EASY TO PLAY. I'm talking about 1 page of rules here. Yet the possibilities of the route goals are amazing. I want to play this again and with more people. One thing I'm afraid of is that the cards are so small, which makes finding cases impossible. Also, due to the large amount of cards in one stack, it is hard to shuffle.

It's got a lot of good things going for it. It's really easy to learn, the artwork is bright and interesting, America is easily recognizable and it fits up to 5. It's just that I realized that 90% of the game is just drawing 2 cards. It just takes so long to get little done in this game. It's not particularly good with 2 players as well. I mean you will only get to use 1 of the 2-sided routes, but there just isn't too much blockage there. If they could have made the game end quicker, I'd be happy for it, but as it is... it's too long to be doing something not interesting such as drawing 2 cards each turn.

RATING: 4
My first play of Ticket to Ride did not go well. I was stuck with only cross-country tickets and quickly blocked off from easily achieving any of them. I think Alvin & Dexter might give this game some much needed confrontation, though my main problem with the game might be the way Tickets are handled. There seems to be a problem with a runaway leader as the person who gets the best tracks seems to be able to draw tickets that instantly score. It doesn't help that those who are blocked from completing their goals must also suffer negative points as extra punishment. It's not a bad game, it just supports the worst kind of luck. Though I must say, even after getting thoroughly walloped, I had some fun with Ticket to Ride. It's fast and colorful with a sort of charm I can't really define.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Sort of a competitive, colorful TransAmerica; plays light, moves fast and sometimes hinges on luck-of-the-draw, although consistent card collecting will get you what you want. Finish your route cards early and grab at least one other, to heighten your odds of victory. Forget about building the "longest railway"; the ten-point bonus won't put you in any kind of solid-win position. A fun game, just slightly longer than your average filler.

RATING: 10
Wow! When I first played this one, early in my boardgaming career in January 2005, I couldn't understand what the fuss was about. Was this really the game that drew so many to the hobby, that some people played dozens and dozens and dozens of times and couldn't get enough? Bah. Fast forward to two years later: Thurn und Taxis & the Marklin edition of Ticket to Ride had recently won my heart, so I decided it was time to give the original TtR another chance. Although the simpler mechanics seemed somewhat bland after having playing TtR Marklin, guess what, I liked this one best! The passenger mechanics make Marklin a more complex game, sure, but they don't add all that much fun in return for making the game more difficult to manage and harder to absorb.

RATING: 6
This is a train game completely devoid of any economy. You build trains by first collecting cards (fixed amount each turn) and then just place them on the board. In essence it is only set-collection and route-building. In my view not  really interesting, but it is quickly explained and played and appeals therefore to a wide audience.

RATING: 6
My opinion of the seminal favorite, TtR, dropped dramatically after I finished my second play. The game offers little to nothing in the strategy or tactics department, and it heavily repetitious once you've finished your first game. The three-player game offers lots of opportunities for nasty blocking, but the game never gets confrontational enough for this to ever become a viable strategy. The game really boils down to set collection of the most tedious kind. A pretty big disappointment for me.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I bought it as a way of bringing my wife and me into "real" gaming.  Folks suggested it as a "gateway game" and those folks where right on the money.  Great game for us, including my 8 year-old daughter.  And defintely a hit with non-game playing friends.  So easy to learn and beautiful to look at as well.

Update (Feb.'09): No doubt this is the best gateway game.  We've had it for 3 or 4 years now and it never fails.  A favorite of my study hall and h.s. boardgaming club.  Got students who play a bunch online now too.

P.S. 1910 cards are almost manditory for fans.

Update June '09: Moved rating from "9" to "8" b/c I'm just not crazy about playing it these days.  For trains, I'd rather play Steam.  Still love it (with 1910 cards) to show to new gamers though.

RATING: 7
Ticket to Ride for me is the ideal gateway board game.
It's a great introductory game that provides just a flavour to non-gamers of what is both fun and challenging about the hobby.  
The mechanics are simplicity themselves, you have a set amount of track.  You have destinations to join up on a board.  You need to collect carriages of matching colours for each station hop of the journey.  Whilst there are expansions and twists to this, that's the basis of the game and you have to love it for that.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Shrink Wrapped
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Gin Rummy on steroids. I actually like the train theme and the twist on gin rummy is awesome. You have to make matched sets of cards, but you have to make the right set and you've got goals you're trying to complete...oh yeah and you can probably figure out what everyone else's goal is too and you can either work towards your own goals or screw someone elses' up.

The best way I can describe the emotional impact of this game is: mounting tension.

Each turn you have to decide between:
* Do I try and get more cards to make more/better sets or claim what I can now?
* Do I claim that route before someone else does?
* If I claim that route, will it give me away?
* Do I claim a route that I don't need because I believe that someone else does and it will screw them up?
* Do I risk going for more destination cards or not?

No matter what you choose, you're worried about what you're opponents are thinking and what they're going to do next and if you chose the right thing or not. Great fun! The only down side I can think of is the setup and cleanup take a smidgen longer than a normal game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It's pretty awesome - who doesn't love choo choo trains?  I'm excited at the prospect of trying another version.

RATING: 6

(9/22/07) - [8] - Rarely played anymore now that TtR: Europe is here!

(02/11/14) - [6] - My tastes have changed over the years, and Ticket to Ride has fallen victim. I don't particularly enjoy playing this much anymore. I'll bring it out as an introductory game and hope that I don't end up too bored with it.

SOLD - (04/11/2017) - Ticket to Ride has been sold. One of my earliest board game purchases, it will forever hold a dear place in my heart.

RATING: 7
Ticket to Ride is a pretty decent game. At the heart of it, it is a resource acquisition/placement game. But it does have a fun amount of strategy that goes along with it.

Depending on the amount of players, early turns can be dull. I rarely see any better strategy than stocking up on random cards for a number of turns. This can change a little when playing with 4 players - if other players start playing on Central European routes. Denial is a HUGE strategy in this game! 

The game is really designed for 4 players. 2 players gives too much space so there is little competition for routes. 3 players can, likewise, be a quiet game. 4 players is where this game is experienced best.

This is also a great game to introduce to non-gamers, as it is very easy to pick up and learn.

All in all, a very solid game that I do like to play!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Though I modestly enjoy the game, my high rating is really due to the enthusiasm it has generated amongst my non-gaming peers.  Ticket to ride has been very well received by almost everyone to whom I have introduced it.  The best is watching everyone tap their fingers nervously, biting their nails, trying to hide their disappointment when they are getting blocked.  There are a number of ways to win the game, and you can play a very defensive, interactive game if you like.  I probably have the same level of enjoyment from this as from carcassonne, though the emotions ticket to ride generates in others have been more fun to watch.  EDIT:  never mind about being able to play a 'defensive' game.  Even if you have a very good guess as to what your opponents are doing, hurting someone else hurts yourself nearly as much, as time is ticking for you to complete your task!  Still a good, tense game, though strategically a little limited.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Update 11/6/2017 - Upped my rating. Sometimes, you just want to lay trains with family and friends. TtR does it best.

***

To date, I've played Ticket to Ride multiple times, across four TtR maps: USA, Europe, Nordic Countries, and the updated Marklin map now Germany. TtR is pleasant enough fare for family gaming, and it certainly elevates itself in those scenarios, but the natural competitor in me just turns my nose up at the randomness sometimes. It is married to every aspect of the game, and when it burns you, it burns bad. When games that I spend time with retain this amount of unmitigated randomness, I want them to be quicker, leaner, or else possess means to address it. The Nordic Countries map allows for that, thankfully. 

At the end of the day, I recognize and respect that this is Alan Moon's intent in his design, and he has, without question, succeeded marvelously. While I am not clamoring to play it, in most situations, I will not turn down a game. It is a fine diversion when not taken too seriously.

If I had to pick a favorite map, it would be Nordic Countries, by a long shot. The overall aesthetics and the map layout of that one is, I think, superior to the others, as it creates more moments of head-to-head route competition. However, the other maps are similar enough (and in the case of the USA map, less interesting enough) that I think it is fine to rate the games similarly, as an average of my ratings, for what is essentially the same type of gameplay across all maps.

(+) Truly a classic example of elegant, accessible game design
(+) Modular mechanism lends itself to various scenarios with potential for more interesting gameplay (new maps, new expansions, slight adjustments in rules)
(+) Plays quickly, and smoothly.

(-) Gameplay can be uninteresting and repetitive.
(-) Depending on the route distribution and/or number of players, the amount of player interaction can be less than I like.
(-) Randomness abounds with no way to mitigate it (TtR Europe 1910 expansion has station cards that are a neat idea towards addressing this issue)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Beginning of great series... little lower rating because of small card format and because later versions are a little litle bit better. Still great game which I'm glad I have.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The basic mechanic is similar to rummy, in that players use cards to try to make colored sets.  As they make these sets, they build their rail network.  Players score points for meeting game requirements unique to each player.  The player with the longest rail line receives a bonus at the end of the game.

Ticket to Ride is well-suited for introducing non-gamers to gaming.  A very simple and short game with low-level strategic decisions, it's a good choice for families with kids.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This game worst with little kids and lazy adults that take convincing to play a board game.  it plays a bit slow, but the accessibility makes it great.

RATING: 5
31-05-2014. Rated after 2-3 plays. I dislike Ticket to Ride. You draw goal cards with routes that you aim to connect on the board, that each consists of several (at least 3 I guess) short pieces of rail. Tricksy is that often the routes can be connected just by 1 or 2 people and if you're unlucky you have to connect take a detour. You accomplish this by collecting sets of cards (of a certain color) in order to build similar colored routes on the board to obtain your objective. While the game is NOT bad, it doesn't click with me at all. I would agree that it's a good gateway game, but one which I desire not to play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.25
With only three choices each turn, TtR is a great game to bring out when you have new players looking for some fun. About an hour long for four players, each player tries to build routes from one North American city to another. There are a couple of tricks you will learn after you play a few games but the difference between new players and veterans is not that pronounced, making this game enjoyable, balanced and a lot of fun. There are lots of expansions to keep game play original and enjoyable.

RATING: 8.5
The game almost looks too simple, but the mechanics are elegant.  You want to own routes between cities, but it takes time to build up matches of the same color cards to "buy" those routes.  Shorter routes are easier to buy but give less points.  And there is also the risk and reward of taking on the challenge of trying to aquire specific routes by the end of a game, for a big reward or penalty depending on whether you got it.  Another game where you can only do a limited number of things each turn and you are constantly weighing short term small gain against taking risks to build up resources to buy  big point routes.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
With 2 players..."blah". After so many plays a 2 player game holds little appeal pre-game and provides little fun during the game.

With 4-5 players...more fun, though still not something I enjoy or appreciate. I can deal with the lack of theme and themeless mechanics with more grace when I play with 4-5 players than with 2 players. The game is much more competitive & the board is so much tighter. Highly recommended as a 4-5 player game for new gamers, light Euro gamer types, and Ameritrashers who can suspend their need for theme and blowing things up (which means you're likely not an Ameritrasher!).

Caveats: 
(1) This game is a great game for gateway gamers and gamers who like lighter fare.
(2) This game has no theme, in my opinion. That really drags down its rating. If being immersed in theme or an excellent integration of theme & mechanics is important, proceed cautiously or don't proceed at all.
(3) The 2 player game is competitive but lacks important tension, as the map is generally so wide open. I would rate the 2 player game very low, say a "4".
(4) Played with 4-5 players, the competitive nature of the game more than makes up for most of its shortfalls.

Final verdict: It will not be my first choice, even with 4-5 players, unless there are no other sensible options. But if someone else suggests a 4-5 player game of TTR, I probably won't have a problem playing and will likely enjoy the experience. As a 2 player game..."blah". 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
After enough exposure to the board gaming hobby, my fascination with Ticket to Ride has abruptly come to a halt. Like many lured into playing a game from this franchise, I believe my initial attraction to TtR was due to the snazzy components, and the hype surrounding the game. After enough plays, it completely baffles me how anyone can enjoy this (base) game.

In general, I dislike train (economic) games, but that doesn't matter because TtR is not really a train game. It's a hybrid set collecting/route building game, both are genres I quite enjoy. It would seem that TtR should have been right up my alley. I bought the game with high expectations, but even the first play fell somewhat flat. 
There seemed to be almost no player interaction in our games, except for some accidental blocking. It became a game of draw a card ad infinitum. Then I tried looking for some strategy to be found, but it's almost non existent. Even blocking strategies are almost never worthwhile.

I kept this game around as a possible gateway, but I've since decided against inflicting this drudgery of card drawing, route claiming on anyone. There are so many better gateway games out there, I'd stay far away from this one. It's a shame really, because maybe the Marklin edition is a much better game, but I will not bother to find out. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game never gets old to me. I enjoy playing with my family, and I have not introduced it to a new gamer that didn't like it. Even with first time players, most of the time it's not obvious who won until end game scoring, which really keeps everyone invested in the game from start to finish.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Fun, lighthearted game.  Unfortunatly, lack of strategy caused me to lose interest in Ticket to Ride over time.

If you don't complete your destinations (connecting 2 cities with trains) you lose points.  Therefore, the internal question of "should I go for those extra points?" is the real hook here.  This sense of urgency is neat but becomes boring over time.

Still a fun game that I would play from time to time.  Very popular with gamer and non-gamer friends alike.

The mechanics of the rules are super-simple, super-tight, and just a whole lot of fun.  A problem arises with two players -- one may choose to do nothing but block the other, which becomes a bit tedious.  I recommend three or more where that strategy won't pay off.

You can teach this game in five minutes.  Then the fun begins.  This is a must-own game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Personally, I think this game is broken, but still fun to play in spite of its flaws.  I generally love Days of Wonder games, but this one falls short because I have found that the best way to win is by going for the biggest railroad pieces and not worrying about the tickets.  That's right, build all the six piece lengths for an amazing 15 points each turn instead of taking a ton of turns to connect cities by building in the 1 or 2 slot spots.  Those smallers slots burn up turns without producing much bang at the end when completing the ticket.  Some might argue with me, but I have won the last few games easily by employing this strategy.  And even when players think they can beat me when they know that I am using this strategy by collecting and filling out tickets still come up short in the end and lose.  Like I said, this game is broken.  Maybe the other expansions fixed this issue - I don't know because I have never played them.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]Caveat:[/b] I’ve only played this as a 2-player game, my :thumbsup: and :thumbsdown: are based on that.

:thumbsup: I get why this is popular as a gateway game. It's easy to explain, but doesn't feel like a brainless waste of time once you're playing.
:thumbsup: A fun blend of different 'push your luck'-factors. [i]"Am I going to draw cards or play cards? And if I'm drawing cards, will I draw from the deck or from the open cards? What are my opponents up to?"[/i]
:thumbsup: As can be expected in a Days of Wonder game, the components are top notch.

----

:thumbsdown: Does the game 'grow' with its players? Once a player has (partially) memorized the different tickes, can he easily predict and thwart the routes other players are trying to connect? I.e. does Ticket To Ride get more interactive with more experienced players?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A great family-weight gateway game. I don't want to play it often, but I enjoy it when I do, and the urge to play it actually does come around occasionally.

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Moderately Accessible Light Euro 

THe original (+ all the expansions)! Elfenland on rails. I stank at this for many years, delightedly so, forming vast strategies of networks which would crumble upon contact with the enemy. Attempting a convoluted track structure to complete all routes simultaneously--so fragile that a single opponent link could destroy 3, 4, 5 routes at once. That I would always lose didn't bother me, but at some point, say 5-6 years in to our playing, my wife went on a kick of mocking me for my TtR failures. 

I've cautioned her against such actions, as my fragile male ego can only take so much pressure before it butsts like the proverbial dam and I start calling in sick from work to study game strategies and play simulation scenarios for 12+ HOURS AT A TIME. (oops, accidental caps lock)

the result was what it usually is, of course--we no longer are able to play this game 1 on 1. I think tears actually sprang to her eyes of shock the last time we played Swizerland, I was able to deduce and crush her plans so thoroughly. Add it to the list with Blokus, Quoridor, any trump game, Ingenious, etc. etc.

The thing about me is that I'm not particularly good at new games to start--I'm pretty terrible, actually! and people find this amusing because of my reputation. I don't mind losing for...well, forever, if the game is amusing, but if I get too excited about the game or they make fun of me too much, they learn where my rep (and competitive games record) comes from! I learn games like a demon possessed, when I change mental and emotional gears to uber-competitive mode.

The funny thing about my wife is that she knows this but doesn't really care, it's somehow STILL WORTH IT to be able to mock me mercilessly, rub losses in my face, even though knowing it will result in us not being able to play a certain game together in the future. She likes goading me, knowing I'm helpless before such barbs, that I'll have to ramp up and crush it. She's a keeper--I think that's pretty funny too. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Le standard de base de la nouvelle génération de jeu.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Bought this game for a friend.  Components are beautiful.  Completing a long route can be very satisfying.  Sometimes you need to create very convulted routes to hook up your cities.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Visual Appeal: (4)
The game board looks very nice. The routes are easy to read and have colorblind assistance. Box art looks like every other train game, but a little less serious. It almost hints at having characters although the game itself features none. 

Components: (4)
The original game comes with tiny cards which is really the only thing that I hate. There's no reason for it since there's plenty of room in the box for full size cards. I use the 1910 expansion cards now. The trains are nice and durable. At least one has been stepped on with no noticeable damage caused. I had to replace a few of the mini-bags they come in though. Even with light handling they can tear at the seams.

Theme: (3)
I didn't really expect a theme. I think there is some story along the lines of: some rich people are racing to build a rail network. If that's true then there's a problem. What are they buying it with colored train cards? I think this is one of the few games that is more enjoyable if you ignore the theme and just have fun with screwing people over.

Learning: (4)
The rules are really easy. I've taught this game to first timers more than any other game except maybe Pandemic. The most common issues that arise are wanting to do two different things on the same turn, and wanting to play a partial route between two cities. So, now I make it a point to repeat those points a few times before we start. The rulebook is perfectly succinct and problem free.

Gameplay: (5)
This game can get really heated. My favorites are 3 and 5 players. With 3, the double routes are still locked, so certain areas like around the Mississippi River corridor get really competitive. With 5, you have the max number of players allowed and everyone is just getting up in other peoples' business. There's no limitation to where you are allowed to put trains so if someone blocks you, the great thing is you can block them right back. Just make sure that you are still able to complete some tickets. I tried playing a game once where I didn't focus on tickets, but instead on blocking everyone I could. It didn't go well, so you need those tickets!

Overall Fun: (4)
This is always a reliable game that I can bring out at any time and have a good time. There are some games where I have great feelings and not so great feelings coming out of a play. With this game, I always feel good about it. It doesn't do anything special or complicated. It's just a box o' fun.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a train game wherein players must claim train routes between cities.  Each player has a number of secret "tickets" which dictate which cities the player is trying to establish a route for.  Any incomplete tickets count against you.  On your turn you have only 3 options: draw a train card, claim a route, or draw more tickets.  Given the limited options and that most routes between to adjoining cities may only be claimed once, there is great tension in each turn.  Delay too long and you'll lose opportunity, act too fast and you'll never complete the longer routes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I like a game that has very simple rules but a lot of depth, and Ticket to Ride fits that bill. The goal is to get the most points, and these are obtained by completing short routes, completing service between two assigned cities, and by having the most longest line of continuous routes. On any given turn you're drawing train cards, playing train cards to complete a route, or drawing new assignments for service between two cities. There are a few exceptions to these rules, but overall it's a very easy game to learn. 

UPDATE: Dropping from 9 to an 8. Still very good, but after repeated playings I feel like I want "more to do" in the game. I've begun to see the same strategies repeated, so it's taken a hit on replay value. But still a great game, and really one of the best "full-strength" gateway games to recruit new gamers. I'm very much enjoying the Swiss map variant as included in the PC computer game version of the board game.

UPDATE: Dropping from an 8 to a 7. After numerous plays, the game wears on me. It's still good as a gateway game, though, and I am willing to play. I would prefer to play a TTR variant, and I'm quite likely to bring up a counter-suggestion rather than go ahead with another TTR. Because of this, my rating could drop to a 6.5. I hate to do it though, because it's a great game, I've just played it to death.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Another ultimate eurogame gateway game.  An absurd number of my non-gamer friends have this, Settlers or Carcasonne or all of them yet still bust out Monopoly.  GAH!

RATING: 8
I have continously gone back to Ticket to Ride with newer gamers.  The theme and simplicity of the rules are a huge plus for introducing people to board games (other than monopoly/risk/sorry....etc).

Plays usally in 90 minutes or so, and is easy to converse at the same time as playing.  A great mix of luck and strategy and rarely do anyone feelings gets hurt.

This will continously be played in my household because, as of right now, nothing has come close to taking its place for relaxed night with new gamers.

It adds a little more depth to the game by adding ferries, tunnels, and train stations.

RATING: 8
This has been the favorite of all my games so far.  It has the right amount of strategy vs luck, the rules can be explained in about five minutes, and non-gamers understand the strategies and have a blast playing it.  Referred to as "the train game" by my non-gamers, this is a game you won't hate to play with friends - gamers and non-gamers alike.  Starts slow enough that you can explain rules again a time or two before it hurts much not to know them, and the tension and excitement rises until the frantic ending play.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
2012 tax return splurge for Zack and Julia

This is THE gateway game that I can recommend to anyone curious about 21st century tabletop games.  It is a milestone in modern gaming history and is proof that good introductory strategy games can be both educational, well-designed, simple to teach, and still appeal to both Euro gamers as well as thematic gamers. It never feels like a dumbed down game, rather its simplicity in set-collecting and route-building is what makes the game quite tactical and replayable especially with so many available expansion maps.  The only reason we don't play this board game more often is because it has become available to us to play online locally via our iOS devices. This is a great gift for non-gamer friends and family too!

RATING: 8
I love train games, so this purchase was a given as soon as I heard a description.  Fortunately, it has turned out to be quite a pleasant game.  I like the fact that it is quick (compared to my fave--Empire Builder) and that there is more to it than TransAmerica.  So I now have a continuum of train games (that my wife will request) depending on the amount of time I wish to invest.  At any rate, I like the challenge of trying to put together the routes you are dealt at the beginning of the game and catching hold of necessary routes before they disappear, as well as the possibility of pre-emptively blocking routes you think your opponents might need. [9]
-------------------------------
As much as I hate to do it, I have had to knock the rating on this down a level.  TTR Nordic has come along and replaced as my favorite in the series.  And since most of my games are 2-3 players, it managed to pick up most of the plays as well.  This is still an excellent game, and my second favorite overall--the one I would go to first if I had 4-5 players. [05/07/2009]
