=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
This year I've played some vanilla Ticket to Ride after being accustomed to TTR:E version. And the more I played this version the more I hated it. 

First reason - distribution of tickets. TTR:E and following editions have long tickets separated. 
Second reason and the main reason: this version does not promote drawing more tickets. Instead it awards card counting and doing long relations even if not a part of one's tickets. This turns a game which was for me more of a laid back fun with some risk taking into a calculating game of optimisation. :yuk:
In short: what takes one to be good at this game is what I like the least in TTR:E
Third reason: you call this geography... Heh. Well I live in Europe so I'm kinda more connected to European map. 

Currently I rate TTR:E a 7.0

[66 plays] This is well done at every level. Beautiful components, tight and easy rules, scales well from 2 players on up to 5, fast play, and a healthy mix of fun and light tension. This will be a social gaming favorite well into the future. Easy accessability and appeal to newcomers and non-gamers. This is the gateway drug game of the decade. I have yet to introduce this game to anyone that hasn't immediately enjoyed it.

Most recent play Feb '17.

RATING: 5

Update: Got this in a humble bundle some time ago. Finally got around to trying it 2-player with my wife. It is ok, I guess. Base game map seems too roomy for two. After more careful reflection, I think I don't like this game because of the mean-hearted nature of the interaction. Of course, you don't have to play mean, but in that case it's just boring all around.

Update 2: Played a 3-player game with wife and sister. The app is really irritating when used for pass-and-play, since there is hidden information. I think it works a lot better with 3 than with 2, but it's still either nasty or boring. I did have more fun, though, being on the other end of nasty this time.

RATING: 5.75
Ticket to Ride is a simpler game than Airlines Europe and a very light version of Empire Builder. I'd place TTR more along the lines of Around the World in 80 Days.  Having played all four, I rank this below the rest and would only pull it out as a gateway game. The other games mentioned offer various degrees of depth and strategy whereas TTR is mainly a set collection card game...a little overly simplistic for my tastes. I'm sure millions of other gamers would disagree with me on this one, and that's okay. Maybe the other expansions would offer a better experience?

The game requires a bit of multi-tasking to play well and keep track of several tickets at once.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Based on my limited experience, TtR is a solid, fun game. I think it is likely the best gateway game I have ever played. If I needed a game for a group of gamers and non-gamers, or ALL non-gamers, TtR would be at the top of my list. The set-collecting mechanic works well as a means of developing your routes, and the route cards add a timing element to the strategy of that enriches what would otherwise be a more tedious affair. Best of all, my 5 year old can play it and has fun, even if she doesn't always make the best decisions. Unfortunately, Ticket to Ride takes just a *little* it too long for what it offers: which is a light, social gaming experience. I wouldn't want to play it with more than four players again, and I don't think I would ever request it, but I wouldn't mind playing it as light entertainment while having a discussion about something else.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Quite possibly the perfect game for our group.  Very simple, elegant rules means non-gamers can learn it very quickly and you don't have to spend a lot of time explaining special cases.  Strategically, you have to balance getting your own work done vs sacrificing yourself to hinder the leader.  In building your lines, you must combine deception with backup plans to prevent getting blocked, but on the other hand must construct efficiently.  Risk taking plays a role as well, as you can grab for points which are essential to victory but costs time and is catastrophic if you miss.  The board scales elegantly to fewer or more players with the double line option, and I noticed this game is gender neutral, as women seem just as interested as men and have little trouble winning.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Fun enough.  Super easy to play, but still has some decent decision making and strategy.  Would not turn it down, so 7 seems about right for all TTR versions I have played so far (Regular and Europe)

RATING: 7

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Cutthroat and quick... I like it! With higher player counts it can feel sort of repetitive though. NEEDS fast players, or else it feels like you're constantly just waiting to draw cards... again. Also 1910 expansion is pretty much a must because screw small cards. Globetrotter bonus makes things more fun too.

This is a great map because it handles all player counts 2-5 well. At any given player count there's probably a map that does it marginally better, but here is your versatile map that can handle cutthroat 2 player games just as well as it can handle looser 4 player games or crowded 5 player games

[b]Criticisms:[/b] 

*The 1910 expansion really should have been rolled into the base game by now in a second edition, since it's essentially a minor "fix" or update for the base game, balancing short routes vs long ones and adding the Globetrotter bonus

* This game is often hailed as a great gateway game, and I can see it working for some (and it must have worked for many people to get that reputation in the first place) but honestly the player interaction is subtle and sophisticated, and so it can feel a bit cold and non-inclusive for many people I think. The quiet and tense interaction is very real when everyone already "gets" the game, but as a gateway option that's more interesting to social-types, I'd rather do something with more table talk and inter-person interaction.

(5 Design + 3 Enjoyment)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.02

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Ticket to Ride is a modern classic. It's rare to find something that isn't a party or kids game that I can pull out with the family and have no problems with explaining it. The play is very simple to grasp and the production really helps get people into the game. It also has just the right amount of competitiveness. Taking cards and routes that the other players want can make for some great fun that never gets too serious because the game offers so many alternatives and opportunities. And that is definitely part of the fun. One of my favorite family games and one that will always have a place in my collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Many of my family and friends are non-gamers, so this makes a great entry point!
I've had friends go out and pick this one up after trying my copy, great game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Well, it's ok.  The theme works, the art is appealing, and the gameplay is engaging enough to get you about 2/3rds of the way through the game (if you can get past the lack of interaction).  The problem is that it really comes down to a luck of the draw endgame.  

There are really two ways to win in the game, going for connecting cities, and drafting cards to make long connections. Either way works well and is nicely balanced, but my issue is that the endgame devolves around waiting for the right cards to come up.  After you have connected routes, there is a desire to get more routes as there is nothing left for you to do in the game--no objective.  Well, near the end game, in a desire to continue to get points you are given the decision to draw new routes again and hope that the cards come up that will allow you to connect.  If you can get them you will probably win, if you don't you will probably lose.  

Ultimately, I just can't love a game that relies that heavily on the luck of the draw.  Clippers is more my speed. 

I was coerced into playing Phase 10 at a party and realised that this is really just a variant on that with a board and more to choose from.  Can't see myself ever playing this again. 

Draw, Draw, Draw, Draw, Draw, Draw, Draw, Draw, Draw, Play, Draw, Draw, Draw, Play, Draw, Draw, Draw, Play, Zzzz, Draw, Draw, Draw, Play.

Update: I played it again, thought I should downgrade my rating to a 4, then saw that it was already a 4.  I was right the first time.

RATING: 9
I have played this a couple of times and have found it to be a light but very fun game.  Players are faced with taking one of three actions on every turn, and must weigh decisions of claiming new routes with gambling to take more destination tickets while playing a little defense to recognize opponents' routes and blocking if appropriate.
---
This is still a stalwart game in my collection to play with new players and those of intermediate experience.  Fast and simple enough to play in under an hour, but with enough tension and content to feel like you are really into the game.

RATING: 9
A nice "middle ground" twixt games like Empire Builder and Rail Baron and the "too light" fare of Transamerica. Lots of immediate and consequential decision-making right from the get-go. Seemed to accomodate my "newbie" decisions well, allowing me to feel in contention until game's end. . ."Minus" points for route cards at the end is a little harsh, but it increases the intensity of what might otherwise be a casual decision to expand your network. I liked it. A lot. . .would most definitely play it again and seek it out at my nearby game store.

RATING: 7
Complexity: Easy
Players: 2-5

Fairly simple set collection train game.  Players compete to build train routes between different cities by collecting groups of like-colored cards.  Can be played casually or competitively, but gets somewhat cutthroat at 3/5 players as it becomes easy to screw over an opponent.  Overall a solid game - it's not by chance that Ticket to Ride is so highly regarded as a gateway game to the hobby.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of THE go to game when you are introducing people to tabletop board gaming. It is easy to learn, hard to master. It has a decent amount of luck involved, while not seeming unfair. If you failed a ticket, it's most often because you were off with your timing. You feel responsible.

+ Setup is easy. Grab your bag of trains, set out the board, shuffle the two decks and go.
+ Easy to learn, just 3 options. Everyone can count to six and recognize colors (or you are probably too young for games anyway)
+ The plastic trains are great game pieces and well made

- The tiny cards are just stupid. Days of Wonder, just put the big cards in the big box instead of shoving them into an expansion. It is really annoying and it makes me not want to buy that expansion.   

One third of my 'Introduction Trinity', games I'd play to introduce players to tabletop gaming, with Pandemic and Settlers of Catan

RATING: 6
I prefer playing this game online against bots as a simple diversion -- with other people, I find there's too much analysis paralysis for such a straightforward game.  A little too much solitaire masquerading as a group boardgame, though there is some interaction and screw-your-buddy involved.  Fantastic game for getting newbies into boardgaming, however, and it'll always be one of my first recommendations for new gamers to get into the hobby.  There's just something about trains!

Edit 08/08/09:  Revised down to a 6 from 6.5 after playing TTR:E for the first time (which I gave a 7).  I guess I'd play regular TTR if someone asked, but TTR:E really is the better game and there's no reason not to play it instead (other than not having it on hand).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of the only games I knew I would like just after opening the box and reading the rules.  Simple to learn, fun to play for gamers and newcomers, and many strategic options.  Not a "ten" only because the initial card draw can play too large a role, especially if someone has two or three tickets with cities that interrelate, i.e. you complete Seattle to New York and you also have a second card with Seattle that is completed along the way. Update: you can overcome poor draws, so bump it to ten!

RATING: 7.25
This is a solid game for the holidays, when you find yourself with non-gamer relatives - when you want something accessibly fun but with enough competition to keep it interesting.  It's easy to teach, and the young 'uns can compete and still do relatively well.  I think I'll try the Nordic countries edition, as I hear it's more tight and competitive throughout.  The endgame to the vanilla version can get tight as the options for tracks decrease, as the first 2/3 of the game consist with alot of card picking and players vying for the plentiful tracks on the board.  Still, a classic.

RATING: 8.5

Bumping the score up another 0.5 for that (already bumped from 8 to 9) - it's the only game on this list that friends and family are clamouring to play again and again.
EDIT: Apart from Pandemic, but even so, TTR is the one which family and friends are picking up - to date, Dad, sister, school mate, wife's friends have all picked it up.

"Whoooo - whoooo! I'm laying track baby"

EDIT - score was 9.5 in Jun 2012. Taking it down a bit to 8.5 as it's not really hitting the table in the last 3 years or so...


* except for the Swiss map

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This might be the perfect 'gateway game', if such a thing exists. I can play this with anyone, and they'll almost always have fun. It's a bit too unbalanced to satisfy gamers in the long run; the tickets should be awarded more generously and I dislike the longest route bonus: it only stimulates players even more to invest in long connections.
This is mostly fixed with either USA 1910 or Switzerland, and I hardly play without them anymore.
But setting that aside, it's a very enjoyable game that I can suggest anyone, with the possible exception of hard core gamers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Very light.  Good intro to gaming, but the USA board is way too big for two players.  Have played with 4 and the group had fun, which is a big part of gaming, but I'm always left with a slightly underwhelmed feeling at the end.  My boyfriend enjoys this more than me because he sometimes likes the light games that require a little strategy/thinking but not too much, but I really feel (even as a relatively new gamer) that there aren't enough decisions to make here.  And as with many Euros, there's not enough interaction.  Yes, there's blocking, but sometimes you're guessing as to whether you're even accomplishing a successful "block" and that's still a pretty limited form of interaction.  I think this would be a good game for families with kids.  I've also played the Swiss map with 2 players -- definitely an improvement for 2, but most of my complaints still remain.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4.5
Draw a card or two... draw a card or two... draw a card or two... draw a card or two... play cards to lay a train... and repeat.  This pretty much describes both the advantages and the disadvantages of this game.  On the positive side, it is very simple to learn and fun enough that it makes an ideal game to teach to non-gamers.  On the negative side, there is just not enough going on here to keep me interested in repeat plays.  Of the three editions, I thought that "TTR: Europe" was a slight improvement over the original, but I found "TTR: Marklin" to be the most fun.  Game design: 3/5  Personal enjoyment: 1.5/5  Total: 4.5/10

RATING: 7

PS:  I'm not pleased about this, but I'm reducing my rating from a 9 to a 7 because it's impossible to get it played with my regular group.  They are too deeply invested in the variations.

RATING: N/A
BGG User Bagherra said 
" No gateway game list can be written without a mention of Ticket to Ride. The game pretty much speaks for itself, but just a few words on why I think it is the gateway of gateway games. There are only three things you can do on a turn. There is one printed page of rules (4 with pictures). A three year old can be taught how to play. It readily supports a full family of players. This is the ultimate family game. If you have a family and you want to play a game with them, this is the game I would get. Period. End of story. I cannot think of any other game which is truly a "family game" the way Ticket to Ride is."

RATING: 7
[5 plays]  I had been looking forward to trying this game after hearing about it.  I think it is definately easier to learn and plays at a faster pace than another favorite of mine Sante Fe Rails.  After the first game though, I didn't really know what to think, I really got whooped.  So I thought I didn't get something with it.  The second game I was a close second place though.  I don't think I really played better or worse, but just got better ticket cards and the right colors when I need them more in the second game.  It was decent game and I can understand why it is popular gateway game.  It seemed like it does have a fair amount of luck to me, and I think I prefter games to be a little more calculating and heavy, it felt just a touch lighter than I prefer.  But still an overall fun time and solid game.

RATING: 10
Un biglietto per l’avventura!
2 Ottobre 1900 – Sono passati 28 anni dal giorno in cui l’eccentrico viaggiatore londinese Phileas Fogg accettò e vinse una scommessa del valore di 20000 sterline, in cui dichiarò di poter fare “il giro del mondo in 80 giorni”. Oggi agli albori del XX secolo è tempo per una nuova impossibile sfida. Un gruppo di vecchi amici si sono riuniti per celebrare le mirabolante impresa di Fogg e soprattutto per proporne e compierne una nuova. Il premio: 1 milione di dollari ad un solo vincitore. L’obiettivo: 7 giorni per vedere chi riuscirà a visitare e viaggiare in più città del Nord America.
Il viaggio incomincia ora…
Ticket to ride è un’avvincente sfida ferroviaria attraverso l’America del Nord. I giocatori usano vari tipi di carte Treno con l’obiettivo di connettere diverse città. Più lungo è il percorso, più punti vittoria si accumulano.
Inoltre, addizionali punti vittoria si ottengono costruendo in assoluto il tratto ferroviario più lungo o soddisfando i requisiti delle carte Biglietto.
Che cosa aspetti? Salta in carrozza ed incomincia la tua fantastica avventura ferroviaria! 

Elenco elementi di gioco:
1 Mappa del Nord America
240 Vagoni colorati
110 Carte Treno
30 Carte Biglietto
1 Carta Bonus Percorso più lungo
5 Segnapunti in legno
1 Manuale delle regole
1 Codice di accesso online

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Light set collection game with a railway theme. Players are attempting to collect sets of different coloured cards, which in turn allow them to place their carriages onto the tracks linking different American cities. The longer the track, the more points are awarded (one point for a one length track, 15 for a six length). Players can also earn point by having the longest continual track at the end of the game and from completing tickets, whereby two cities on the map have to be linked together and the further they are apart, the more points are available. This can have a downside as incomplete tickets lead to a deduction of points. The game flows well, it is a simple concept and players new to board gaming seem to grasp it. There is a bit of luck involved when acquiring the tickets as some of them are very similar to one another thereby making them a lot easier to complete, but overall this is a tried and tested gateway game, useful for introducing people to the hobby.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Has this ever happend to you? you're with your favorite gaming group and you dont now what to play. "That one's too complex, the newbie doesnt know that one, that one doesn't play good with four..." Then someone brings up TTR. "It's for beginners and a good introduction to german wargames."

It's like a Budweiser it meets all the general requirements of a generic game without offending anyone and has no character, no edge, to speak of. 

It’s not really a bad game at all it’s biggest fault is probably that it takes too long for what it is. It’s not very deep and there’s not a whole of excitement to it either. This might be fine for ½ hour but 2 hours is way too long. We can get it down to just under 2 hrs but not by much. If it was shorter I would up the mark. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Simple yet brilliant railway game.  For me, it evokes a lot of the fun that is inherent in travel; being able to tick places to visit off your list.  The gamble you take when you choose which cities to try to connect is the key to the greatness of the game.  The feeling of desperation when you think you are not going to make it and then the feeling of relief when you pull it off is classic.  Player interaction isn't a large part of the game, but that is compensated for by the fact that you are always working towards a target.

0702
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
It is ticket to ride, a game which for some reason is one of the "mainstream" games in Norway. 
It is easy to play, some player interaction, and a little boring. Missions is so hit or miss that it is silly, the biggest missions is about 20 points, and if you do not make it you get minus that amount of points. This means that it is over 40 points difference if you make the biggest missions or if you does not make it. And everything comes down to luck because people can sabotage you. I say luck because people often have to sabotage themselves in order to sabotage you.
I usually end up hoarding cards half of the game, and buying the largest railways the second half of the game. This means that the game ends extremely fast, people have no way of stopping it, people struggle with reaching their missions, and I usually end up winning. It is a strategy that requires no thinking at all, and seems like the best strategy to use because it does not requires any luck at all.

There are much better games out there one can play with friends like power grid, prosperity, small world and suburbia to name a few. Ticket to ride is an ok game if you do not have any good alternatives :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I must say, this game is still a gem. It is so simple yet so effective! This is what they call elegant game design: simple, streamlined rules that lead to a more interesting game than one could ever expect judging from the rules.

RATING: 6
My first board game beyond the likes the Monopoly, Risk and Cluedo!:) I am impressed that a game doesn't need rolling of dice to play, haha. My wife who is less than luke-warm to board games also love the game after being cajoled into playing the game. The game mechanics is attractively simply, and I think it is a perfect gateway game for all non-gamers. However, after several plays, I find that players tend to focus on building their own track only, and thus the game lacks interaction and excitement as a result. How well the game plays out is therefore very dependent on the group whom you play with.

RATING: 7
already a classic
plays nicely like a light family game should be
quite abstract

I don't quite get why you put chains of wagons on the board in this game. It's not a train (without a locomotive) and it's just to symbolize that you control that link. It feels wrong not to use something more abstract like colored wooden bars (e.g. like the old wooden road pieces from "Settlers of Catan").

RATING: 5
After two plays. There's a luck of the draw with the ticket cards. You won't come in last from a bad hand, but you won't come in first if one player has a nicely set up hand. On top of that, players who don't have good cards and try to get better cards can be punished and make matters worse.

The game can be redeemed to a 7 for me JUST with a rework of the ticket system. Maybe this will be fixed in a second edition.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Plays pretty well with any number of people -- Fast paced, with interesting decisions to be made.  Along with Settlers, this is a good intro game for new gamers, as it's relatively straightforward to learn and thematically relatable.  We play with a house rule where we divide the tickets into 3 piles according to value, and give each player one ticket from each pile to start.  This prevents someone from getting a ton of long routes and another player getting screwed by getting all short routes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Nice when you don't want to think too much.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
My favorite gateway game especially with the 1910 expansion.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Ticket to Ride is a weird situation - sure, there aren't tons of decisions to be made, and you're really playing something akin to Board Game Rummy.  But I think it has the "Take that!" factor that people want to see in games, without it being too complex, making it the perfect game to introduce to new players (SoC and RA are other successes).

Update:  This has become one of the favorite games of my game group, and I have to admit, I always have fun, even though it isn't as strategic a game as it could otherwise be.  Increased from 6.5--->7.5.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I've played this online only, and it seems like a good game, but the more I play, the less I'm drawn to keep playing it. It winds up being less about strategy and more about procedure, I think.

RATING: 9
This is probably the biggest gateway game I've found to introduce new people to the concept of modern board gaming. It's fun, it's light, it's easy to learn.

It's a lovely social game, as they're aren't many game mechanics, and you can easily play with a group over some drinks and not worry about things getting too complicated.

Usually after introducing people to this game, and playing it a few times, it's really easy to get them to pick up something like Carcassonne, Settlers of Catan, or even Power Grid.

RATING: 8
Ticket to Ride will never be one of my top 10 games, but there really is more to this game that at first appears. You have to be able to predict the other players' moves and block aggressively. You also have to build your network while anticipating your future ticket draws. Putting all of these elements into a perfect play can be fun. But ultimately, this Rummy variant isn't my most preferred style of game.

RATING: 10
New

I've got a Ticket to Ride..
You've got a Ticket to Ri-i-ide...
hey...where are you putting those trains...NOOOOOOOOO!

If I am going to teach a new gamer or a younger game how to play a board game, then this is the game I grab. THE Gateway Game!

Simple Rules. Start play right away. Even if you are doing poorly, you are still playing and having fun.

I have multiple expansions and variants. The only one I did not enjoy was TTR: Marklin. The passengers took something away from the game for me.

I may not know how to say it, but I now know where Sault St. Marie is!!

RATING: 6

RATING: 6.6
I loved this when I first played it, and it really hooked me in. I played it over and over for a few days but quickly became fatigued. It's an interesting and different experience when not used to connection games but I don't think there is much of a game here. I particularly don't like the ticket system, where you are pigeon holed into building a certain way and then you are penalised for drawing more choices of tickets. I understand from a gameplay perspective but it really drives the player with limited choice, and the game is so quick the tickets do little but that. A little random but not too bad, bit of strategy in what cards to pick and when to play them, I like that about it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fun gateway game. Who doesn't love playing with trains? Seems overly simple at first, but the strategy becomes more complicated and compelling over time as you find the most lucrative routes to complete your ticket, guess and sabotage your opponent's routes, and keep them guessing about your own routes so you don't become vulnerable to sabotage. I've heard some people say they play "nice" in this game, but doing that is actually what initially turned me off to it--if you're not trying to screw over your opponent, you're just picking up cards and setting down trains. Even with it, it can get a bit repetitive if played too often, but it's still a great game overall.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.9
Rates just below Marklin, simply because Marklin is a bit better balanced, is more strategic, and includes more risky routes.  Much more enjoyable when played with non-gamers.  Most gamers have games they'd rather play than this one when at a convention or game night.  Rating reflects thoughts when playing with a mixed crowd.

Update:  I realized that this game is the best of the gateway games.  I have never had a bad time playing it, and every single person that I have introduced to it to has loved it, from anti-gaming in-laws to fringe-gamers.  It is not deep nor it is it terribly strategic, but it works so well.

RATING: 2
UGH, this f*cking game. F*ck this game, man. So dumb. Yahtzee, Clue, Pente, Othello; Hell, I'd rather play Shoots and Ladders or Candy Land. Catan was brilliant because for the longest time, non-nerds thought anything at or beyond Monopoly or Risk level were "too complicated", regulating we gamers to playing dumb baby stuff with them. Then Ticket to Ride came out, and some IDIOT was like "It's the new Catan!" and everyone acted like it's a game of substance and strategy when it's dull as dishwater and simpler than Forest Gump. If I could erase a board game and all memory of it from existence... well, actually, I hate Liar's Dice and Apples to Apples too, I guess, but this at least makes my top 3 most hated popular games.

RATING: 9
Not only the best "gateway" game ever created, the TTR series might have the best rules of any game in recent history. The games are simple, play quickly, have great components, and offer a ton of fun choices. The American version is the most simple version of the game, but is also more competitive because it is easier to block other players. It is a better 2 player game than the European version.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Now a family favorite, often the "headliner" of game night, this is THE game which first opened my eyes to the appeal of designer board games. The simple rules, intuitive gameplay, and use of the widely understood set collection mechanic make this the perfect gateway game. I can't imagine a better platform for introducting others to the hobby. 

I've not attempted to play with less than 4 or 5P, but have found the game to be equally good at both of those player counts. I imagine the fun factor would likely decrease with lower player counts due to the lessened competition over routes along with the loss of the associated tension that would entail.

RATING: 5
This is my go to gateway game for new board gamers. It is simple to learn, the strategy is easy, and its fun to play.

As I have played different boards (Europe and Nordic) the American map has lost all interest to me. The best strategy is usually to race for all the 15 point routes and see if you can connect a 20+ destination ticket. Additionally the board is so open that we have dubbed this game "Ticket to Silence" as we have almost zero player interaction.

Played it again and it had a sour taste. For Trade.

That said, I really would like to own the deluxe version with the awesome train minis. I need help.




Suitability for Travel:

I have a 1 to 5 scale for four categories (1 is worst, 5 is best) in order of importance:

Portability (the less luggage space the better) - 1
Footprint (the less table space when playing the better) - 1
Scalability (the wider range of player counts the better) - 3
Learnability (the easier to teach non-gamers the better) - 3


Overall - 1

RATING: 7
A great, great gateway game and still fun to crank through with experienced players.  I played nearly a hundred games of this online, but only log face-to-face plays here.  The intuitive rules and clear goals make it a perfect game for new players, and the playing time is reasonable as well.  The game is somewhat flexible for different groups, since people can play (mostly) friendly, or really work to cut each other off.  I like this better than TTR: Europe, but not as much as TTR: Marklin, TTR: Switzerland or TTR: Nordic Countries.

I had no need to own this, but it is a great game for non-gamers, so I couldn't pass it up when it went on sale at Tanga.com. Damn you Tanga!

RATING: 8.5
This is a favorite family game. It's very accessible (our 6 year old daughter is able to play competetively) while still having a solid strategic backbone. It's not clear who the winner is until the end, but there is a sense of a "leader". There are numerous opportunities to surpass the leader though the further behind you are the more you have to gamble to catch up (trying for ideal destination tickets, blind draw for locomotives, etc.). This game is a standby for us and a favorite to play with non gamers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Another modern classic entry point for new gamers.  This is a fun card collection / route building game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Letter Grade: A.  A modern classic family game.  [05-08-09]

So elegant and simple it's ridiculous no one had thought of it before Mr Moon.  Looks like it's fairly nonconfrontational with two, but at the very end of the game, when tension is heating up as players are attempting to make their final connections, the map gets crowded and can make for some last-second nail-biting offensive and defensive moves.  I could see experienced players having a bit of an edge in that familiarity with destination tickets could clue them in on what other players are attempting to connect. Holds up with any group or number of players, though the end-game tension increases markedly with more players, as the opportunities to make those last few destination tickets dwindles rapidly. 

9-2-08: From 8.5 to 7.  I'm still attracted to this game, partially because of the scale of the map, partially because of the components, but I can't see myself suggesting it with anyone but new or less-experienced board gamers.

12-24-07: Reflecting on Tatsu's comments, would be willing to try this again with really experienced TTR players to see how it changes things.  Perhaps too easy to pigeon-hole this game?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I think this game is finally clicking.  I know it's weird I get RftG in my first play, but TtR takes like 7.  I'm different what can I say.  I still like this game a lot though, it seems very counter-intuitive for me at least, which means it is more interesting to play.

Edit: I've gotten to play this enough that it's dropped a little in interest for me.  I think Europe or at least the 1910 Expansion would bump it back up to 8-range.

RATING: 10
Ticket to Ride is the only game I know whose rules fit comfortably on 3 faces of paper.  Front page, back page, next page front, that's it.  Every other game I've played is 10-12 pages of rules, which isn't a bad thing, but it's remarkable that any game can be created with such simple rules.  On top of that, it's lot of fun as well, which gives it a high replayabilty value.

RATING: 9
A game that I can't help but rate highly for its beautiful properties.  Incredibly simple and elegant, and yet not as light and luck-based as it might first appear (although it is definitely not a 'heavy' game).  Your kids could play it with you, it's that simple, and yet still a real game.  It's short, downtime between turns is low, and set-up is generally pretty easy so long as your significant other can shuffle cards (thankfully, years of working on a card game for PhD finally improved my ability to do this drastically).

RATING: 6
A great game for beginning gamers, but a little devoid in strategy for advanced gamers. The best method to win seems to be ignoring tickets, trying to claim the 4-5 train routes and going for the longest route at end game. It gives a real sense of satisfaction when you block that one route your opponent requires to complete a ticket.

RATING: 8
Excellent gateway game.  Along with Carcassonne and Settlers of Catan, this is one of the three best games for introducing non-gamers into the hobby of strategy board games.  It scales nicely from 2 to 5 players, and the rules are very easy to explain to new players.

Purchased: May 13, 2005

RATING: 9
This is a really fun strategy game. When played with two, you can really concentrate on your routes. When maxed out at 5 (or more if you have teams, which we have done), you need to be fast and sneaky. Scoring is easy with the score board lining the game board and a score legend on the board. The trains are cute and the destinations memorable. The only downside is the smaller cards; if I buy this game then I'll look into the expansion pack that replaces them with full size cards.

RATING: 9
[Rated 2005/04/18, based on 23 plays]

Very easy game to get on the table, non-gaming family and friends are always happy to play.  A good gateway game, as it's possible to pick up quickly, but almost everyone I've played with has started thinking more analytically as we've gone along.  (I've seen Rummy players take to it well, deducing what people are collecting and taking it from there.)

Played exclusively with gamers, it's something of a different game, and much faster-paced, especially on-line.  Still great fun, and I can happily play several games back-to-back when they're clocking in at around the 30 minute mark.

Great components, have yet to try the community-produced additional maps, but the quality of art that people are putting out seems very high there too.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A great gateway game. Compared to Marklin, it is lighter, quicker, and less strategic. There is also more potential for getting hosed and having some intense competition without passengers to bring in extra points. We like this version because it is much easier to finish in a short amount of time, compared to Marklin.

Over time, this game has become a drag for me. I still like playing, but I don't like that every game feels like a game of "who will get the luckiest ticket draws?" The game seems to lack player control, offering little payback for good decisions. This has taken the rating down to 7.5 for me.

The other reason this game has worn on me is that it gets requested so often. As a result, all of the other good games in my collection receive less love. I do like this version more than TTR: Europe, but I'd rather play Marklin anytime.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

More fun if played with more players as it add more excitment to the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
With elegantly simple gameplay, Ticket to Ride can be learned in 3 minutes, while providing players with intense strategic and tactical decisions every turn. Players collect cards of various types of train cars they then use to claim railway routes in North America. The longer the routes, the more points they earn. Additional points come to those who fulfill Destination Tickets – goal cards that connect distant cities; and to the player who builds the longest continuous route.
"The rules are simple enough to write on a train ticket – each turn you either draw more cards, claim a route, or get additional Destination Tickets," says Ticket to Ride author, Alan R. Moon. "The tension comes from being forced to balance greed – adding more cards to your hand, and fear – losing a critical route to a competitor."

RATING: 5
A decent system of gateway games, but I think there are better games in the series than the base game (such as Marklin).

In the base game, the long tickets dominate lots of short ones and the map has just a few too many choke points, so play can get very nasty.

Further, the hoarding strategy seems a bit too strong in the base game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I like the polish of the game, and certainly it's a game you can get most anyone to play.  

But my problems are the following:
1) It's too simplistic and lacking interesting strategy to be worth many plays with experienced gamers
2) It's too long, especially with 4-5 players (a family) which is really the only time I would play it.
3) Even less experienced gamers, who may otherwise enjoy the game, begin to feel the drag. 

I really don't get this one.  The luck factor is high, and while I enjoy the thrills of blocking someone (as they enjoy blocking me), I feel I have too little control. 

Is it a terrible game?  No.  But it's certainly not one I pull out frequently.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Or maybe an 8. Not much strategy or user interaction. The best thing about it is that its fast (1/2 hour).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I have the Steam version. It was the first "modern" board game I played, and I still love it a lot, even though we don't play it as often as we used to. Sure there's luck, but generally it evens out, and that just contributes to the variability.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It's simple enough for my eight year-old to grasp strategies of completing destination cards while not being too rules heavy. Having to draw the correct color of cards adds a chance element to it that has burned me in one game, but it is countered by the locomotives as wild cards. If you've got pre-teen children, this is a fun game to play with them.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good:
-Gateway game
-Builds great internal tension
-Every game plays differently
-Plays well as a two-player game

Bad:
-A little too long for what it is
-Routes deck is a little too random
-A ton of short routes isn't truly a viable strategy
-Rewards for long routes are too large

Overall:
Makes it very clear what you need to do.  Then, uses race mechanics to build excellent tension and build nerves about getting everything done before it's too late.  Gives players the freedom to explore conservative and risky strategies.  I'm usually willing to play but would rather play different or shorter gateway games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The game that started my recent entrance into board gaming. It's fun and so easy to teach (so many family members have been introduced to this game and surprisingly fell in love with it). I do prefer this with the expansion, as well as the Europe map.

RATING: 10
While Agricola might be a deeper game, it cannot match
Ticket to ride in elegance and cleaness of mekanics, which is the main criteria for becoming a classic game. I
think this game has a good chance of outliving us all. It
manages to use set collectiong and point to point movement in such a deep and elegant fashion. There are just a few other games like this that aint abstract and still manages a pureness of mecanics, I can only think of
Aquire and Puerto Rico at the moment. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
08/2008:7
I want to like this game, but the mechanics are too simple in my mind. Large ticket/6-car advantage is hard to overcome.

After a year or so, I downgraded this game. It is just too boring.

After a couple more years, I upped the rank...mainly because I have come to appreciate the simplicity of this game as well as the ease of teaching newbies. I find that if people have fun playing a particular type of game, I tend to up the rankings a tad bit to adjust for the   subtle yet but important "social fun factor"

RATING: 7
Update: Played again for the first time in a few years, this time with my kids. It's still a great family/gateway game, though I still don't have any desire for it to become more than that when there are so many deeper train games out there.

This one gets my vote for the ultimate gateway game. Not as nasty (or as subtle) as Carcassonne, easier to explain and more flexible in number of players than Settlers. However, I think that in the long run it's not as interesting as either of those two competitors.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

One must make a compromise between efficiency and time as you attempt to lay train tracks across the country before your opponents.  As long as no one abuses the '6 rail length' strategy the game is great for both new and experienced board gamers alike.

RATING: 7.5
There are precious few board games that can be taught in under 5 minutes while still being fun to play.  A really good gateway game for a mixed group of players.  I've never seen a player upset during or after a game of Ticket to Ride, it is always a safe choice.

I'm a fan of how the board changes its track mechanics to accomodate more players.  However, I don't like how the *complete route* cards are largely luck-based in the end game (but that is a minor quibble).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a solid game that is reasonably deep, all things considered. The game plays pretty quickly, even with 4, and tends to stay fun and competitive. This one is particularly good at bringing people into the hobby. The gameplay is a touch repetitive, as the number of actions you can do a turn is extremely limited, but it's fun in its simplicity.

RATING: 7
My first rail game. A good family game and a great intro for the kids and non gaming friends. The game play gives just enough depth and the rules can be explained quickly. Play is balanced and not much down time. Lots of tension( and frusration) for the kiddies as they find their plans thwarted. My kids have benifited as it really needs you to have alternatives in place just in case.  When I ask what game should we play tonight the cry is usually the one with trains! DoW have as usual done an outstanding job on production, beautiful artwork and excellent tactile components all add to an enjoyable gaming experience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I can only comment on the 2-player variant, as I usually only play games with my wife (or try desperately to, anyways...). Not a very confrontational game, as we find that it is only beneficial to block one another when it is convenient. The first game I played with my wife, she beat me terribly. She has a longest route train extending from new york to miami and then to LA, completing 3 routes in the process. I think she didn't find the game to be mentally challenging enough, so it was just "ok". You basically work towards completing the destination cards, and pick among your cards to make sure you dont get stuck with negative points at the end of the game. While it is a beautiful game with great components, I don't think it is best with 2, because the board is too big to lead to enough confrontation to make it a challenge.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Okay, okay, I'm a convert, but the rating is still a 5.  This one is a keeper, will probably be played for years to come, and has an accessibility that makes it a good non-gamer-introduction-to-european-style-gaming game.  However. . . it is somewhat fiddly with the bits.  The train metaphor is a thinly camouflaged Gin Rummy variant.  The game can have good player interaction, with both offensive and defensive plays to block other people, but most of the time each player is playing soley for themselves and pays less attention to other player's actions.  This can cause player interaction to become significantly low.  And for a more family-oriented light game, TTR inspires very little table talk.  On the whole, the choices and decisions you make in TTR don't seem as important as they feel in other games.  Still, it's more than a diversion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Perfect to play with people that just don't grasp rules that well.  The rule book is just a front and back cover.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Affectionately known as "the train game" one of the quintessential gateway games. A rummy-based set-collection card game with the addition of a "geographic" component. Intuitive to learn, simple to play, yet strategically sound. Has a little of that "screwage factor" inherent in the competition for  available routes - that said one is never really out of the game because several routes can be taken to complete tickets, though some take you quite the long way around. Components are superb. Cards are a little small but functional but that can be corrected with the expansion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Might be stupid but I still can't see the pattern to win. I oftenly lose by 1 at 5 points because of the longest track
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of our favorite games.  Great for getting new players into Board Games.  Fun because it involves a lot of quick planning and strategy to complete your hidden objectives.  No one really knows who is going to win until the very end!  Often we have the person in last place end up in first!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is not our favorite of the series (that goes to Nordic or Europe), but is one we had to have just because we love the series so much.  If you do get this version, I highly suggest getting the USA 1910 expansion for larger cards.

Pros:
+ Easiest version to teach because it has the simplest rules/mechanics.
+ For US players, there's less frustration about not being able to figure out where cities are.

Cons:
- Lighter than other versions, which is not necessarily a negative for everyone like it is for us.
- Artwork isn't as nice as in later versions.
- We don't enjoy the layout of routes on this map as well as others.  (Again, personal preference.)
- Comes with small cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Ticket to Ride is to me, the perfect gateway game. There is skill and strategy in play, but plenty of luck and chaos, too, so anyone has a chance to win. Turns are very fast, and you can always do something on your turn, so you're never bored. There's a slow build up of tension too as people start to crowd the routes you want, threatening to take it from you!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Moon's famous "draw from x face up cards or the deck" mechanic, distilled into its purest form.  I haven't had the success that so many have trumpeted when I introduce it to non-gamers.  My working hypothesis is that the strategy involved in ticket selection is a little bit too subtle to really absorb until the second or third play, so many of the new gamers don't really understand why they lost.  If the desire to play a train game hits me, I'll usually opt for TtR's meatier older brother, [gameid=94], but this one is a moderately satisfying lighter alternative.

RATING: 7
After fifteen games, I can say this is a good and quite an easy game to learn. All the players must be more or less at the same level for the game to be really enjoyable. I think this original version of Ticket to Ride is the best (I have also played the Europa, Märklin and Nordic editions). In the right company, this is a really challenging and nice game to play.

The game is intuitive, players want to build routes and building routes gives points. Quite straight forward and easy to understand. Great game for non-players, good game for players.

RATING: 8
The quintessential gateway game is the quintessential gateway game for a reason: It's easy to teach, it's easy to understand, and it's easy to play.  I have yet to show this game to someone who doesn't like it, and though I probably prefer to play other, deeper games if I have the choice, it's hard for me to imagine turning down a game of Ticket to Ride (unless it's Märklin, or unless I have the choice between it and Age of Steam).  Even if the draw isn't coming my way, I still enjoy playing.

39 plays: 2 players
3 plays: 3 players
1 play: 4 players
4 plays: 5 players

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
With elegantly simple gameplay, Ticket to Ride can be learned in 3 minutes, while providing players with intense strategic and tactical decisions every turn. Players collect cards of various types of train cars they then use to claim railway routes in North America. The longer the routes, the more points they earn. Additional points come to those who fulfill Destination Tickets – goal cards that connect distant cities; and to the player who builds the longest continuous route.
\13\\13\
The rules are simple enough to write on a train ticket – each turn you either draw more cards, claim a route, or get additional Destination Tickets," says Ticket to Ride author, Alan R. Moon. "The tension comes from being forced to balance greed – adding more cards to your hand, and fear – losing a critical route to a competitor.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ticket to Ride gets loads of praise for being a great gateway game and it's easy to see why. The rules can be explained in minutes, yet there is enough decision making to keep even serious gamers interested. Another nice feature is that it can be played either casually (just score points) or aggressively (by blocking routes), so it's great for playing with non-gamers and younger children. Although no one in my group owns a copy of Ticket to Ride, I get to play all the time thanks to X-box live. Indeed, I think I like Ticket to Ride better as an electronic game, since all of the tedious card shuffling and display refreshing are taken care of by the CPU, not to mention there are always a bevy of online opponents to play. Solid game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very simple to learn and to play. Loads of fun, but can be very frustrating as you may spend multiple rounds simply drawing cards trying to find that one card you need to complete a specific route. Tons of fun with just two players but highly recommend having as many people play to amp up the competitiveness. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game fixed all of the problems I had with Thurn and Taxis...and it came out first. Funny, that. Anyway, the game is really enjoyable. Like Carcassonne, it's nice in that players have the option of playing viciously or not blocking each other. The tickets add a good amount of tension, and the game moves right along. I've never played with the expansion, but I actually like the small cards; since there's no hand limit, I'd imagine that larger cards could get unwieldy, especially with low player counts. I feel like replayability with the same group might be a little lower than I'd like, but that's a very minor complaint.

RATING: 6

They don't give me much scoring...

If you like this game, try Union Pacific. I prefer Union Pacific. For me far more evolving. In this game I know all the routes combined with the shares :). Ha, great game Union Pacific!

RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
It's simple and accessible, but there's not much more to it - overall I find Ticket to Ride to be pretty underwhelming (considering its almost legendary status). There's just not enough interesting decisions here (even by the gateway game standards). You just draw cards, slowly build your hand and hope that others won't block your routes (and trust me - the game can get pretty cutthroat in this regard). 

The starting hand of bad tickets can really hinder your entire game. Not only that -  experienced players who know the highest scoring ticket cards inside-out have a huge advantage over novices as they can predict what you are doing and block you accordingly (as a novice you are put at a disadvantage just because you don't know what to expect from the tickets - this game rewards "experience and memory" over skillful play and I'm not a big fan of that).

I would rather play Quadropolis or Splendor if I were to suggest a great looking gateway game. Even Catan is more interesting and involving due to negotiations and trading aspect. 

I don't hate it, but I'm far from being amazed by it. I understand it has its fans though, it's just not my cup of tea.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Nice light game to play with the kids.  A euro that I will actually play.

RATING: 7
Once more a game with simple rules that is rather engaging. It doesn't give me the agonizing choices feel as in some other games, but still very fun to play. I do feel like the board is too crowded with 5 players. With 2 players, there is little interaction, but it's still enjoyable. Don't compare it with Union Pacific because both games play very different. You could say it has similarities with TransAmerica, but it doesn't replace it. UPDATE: Sold it and replaced it with the Marklin edition as it provides more ways to score points. Note that this doesn't mean I don't like the base game, as I think it's an ideal game to introduce non-gamers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Ticket to ride is one of my favorite games. Players are given tickets which represent train route which they need to complete for points. By collecting and playing sets of different colored trains players can connect cities, and the farther the connection the more points it is worth. It is a simple game, but with a strategic  play structure that makes it a lot of fun.

RATING: 8

I probably prefer Ticket to Ride when I play with non-gamers, and Ticket to Ride: Marklin when I play with gamers.  It's not that they can't handle the Marklin edition, but I find that it's an easier sell with the basic rules without adding in passengers or stations or tunnels, etc.

RATING: 8
I don't own a copy, but my father and my friends do, and this has proved to be one of the most enjoyable games in our library. We have made a house rule that places three tickets (after everyone has received their initial supply) under the edge of the board. When the game is over, these three "mystery routes" are revealed. If any player or players have completed one of these routes, they get bonus points.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Elegantly simple gameplay with intense strategic and tactical decisions every turn. Collect cards of various types of trains to claim railway routes in North America. The longer the routes, the more points they earn. Additional points come to those who fulfill Destination Tickets & goal cards that connect distant cities; and to the player who builds the longest continuous route.

Awards
2004 Spiel des Jahres.
2004 Meeples' Choice Award

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Keeping mainly because it's such a good gateway, although I find it a bit repetitive for my taste. 

15/01/'17: Decided that in spite of its new-player friendliness it isn't worth keeping for us because I don't ever feel like playing it. The main reason for this is the limited play - draw cards to collect a set and play a set to lay trains, with a bit of route building on the side. I always felt like there was something off in the tickets mechanic since they seem really important but actually aren't, and short tickets are not worth it - like they don't score enough or something. Playing with the expansion helps because you can use just the big tickets, but essentially the game is uninteresting because of the limited decision making round to round. Hand-management and tempo (do I build before you) are really the only ongoing gameplay and while it was fun for a bunch of plays I think I am played out.

RATING: 8
Easy to learn and teach, quick set up time, neat bits and a wonderfully familial theme, this one is a winner. Complete your tickets or block others from completing theirs (just guess what they have) and whoever has the most points at the end gets the win! Wonderful game with wonderful production values. A perfect family game and a great gateway game to lure your non-gamer friends in to the fold.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The poster child for gateway games. A good game, but not without flaws. After a few plays it becomes apparent that whoever draws coinciding long tickets (usually coast-to-coast) will be much more successful. Then there's the tactic of just taking as many 6-length routes as you can to speed the game to its end. Outside of those two options, one of which will be determined by chance, there's not much else to do.  An innovative game system re-implemented better in future versions, including the great USA 1910 expansion.

RATING: 8
Excelelnt train game, and with a good perpetual online ladder running on Age of Wonder website if you are short of people to play.  Of the four (TTR, Marklin, Europe, Switzerland) this is my favourite, the board layout is excellent, there are plenty of long routes to build (Europe and Switzerland are short on these) and it avoids the overcomplexity that Marklin introduces for little additional play value.  if you havent played it yet, try it!  the only downside is that most experienced players hoard cards and build late - but a hand of 30 cards is awkward to manage and easy to spill, so teh online version is recommended.

RATING: 9
Growing up, even if people did not play games, they owned a Monopoly set, as it was a game that was available everywhere, with rules easy enough for anyone to play, yet challenging enough to raise it above just a kid's activity.  Ticket to Ride is a near perfect game that has the same qualities.  It has only a few rules, and can be taught in a few minutes.  Easy to do, yet challenging if the opponents are experienced.  With add on maps to add complexity and the fact that this appears now in mass market locations,  hopefully Ticket to Ride will be around a long, long time.

RATING: 8
With very simple rules that anyone can pick up on, even the village idiot, Ticket to Ride and its sequels are games that every aspiring board gamer should play. The original is the simplest and strikes closest to home (considering the map is America). However, the Marklin edition feels faster paced and a little more cut throat, with a few more dimensions of depth added. The Europe addition is an adequate sequel but the hassle of ferries and tunnels just made it a little less enjoyable than it was worth.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
{ P - 2 3 [4] 5 }

You have to give Mr. Moon some credit here. Of the big four gateway games (Ticket, Settlers, Ra, Carcassonne), his wins out. After dissecting every materially different starting draw (base set only - with a larger, expansion-inundated deck of Tickets the game is much worse because players can never infer if certain tickets remain in the deck as well as the probability and necessity of getting them) and how players would thus begin the game, one should figure out that a spinal route is usually optimum. (The route extends from Calgary to L.A. to Pitt to Miami, with endpoints truncated if necessary, e.g. tickets in New York or Montreal. A secondary route folds back on itself slightly to encompass Duluth, and requires the black six to coexist with the aforementioned.) The only other possibilities include central tendencies of geography in either the west or east (these players need to acquire some strategic routes to pinch the spinal folks) or two "big" tickets that are almost exactly the same route. (Lucky contestants here can simply come on down, there's not much you can do to prevent SEA-NY + VAN-MON and the brevity with which they can be completed.) I even mapped out the optimum routes for all west/east as well as basic countermeasures against traditional players and break points where routes can be shortened given the absence of tickets to cities like Santa Fe or Chicago. As you may have expected, this game has lost its luster for me, but hey - at least it's not Ra.

RATING: 6.5
Allright, after a dozen games, I'm dropping my rating to a 7 from a 9.  This games scores high marks for its components and simple rules.  Non-gamers can pick this up in a flash and it's a great way to get them hooked.  BUT... this can get monotonous.  Draw cards. Wait.  Draw cards. Wait. Lay down trains.  And if you draw a good set of route cards at the start, say a couple of medium to long routes with similar start and end points, you have a huge advantage.  This has developed into a long filler for me.  Fun but not hugely rewarding.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The version I have is actually "Ticket to Ride. Europe." This is a solid game. You have to capture roads to connect various points on the map. One road cannot be used by different player, which leads to a competition between the players.   The resourses for building become available sort of random, but the amount of randomness involved is just right. One of the main sourses of risk is that you may take as many "orders" for connecting cities as you wish, but if you cannot fulfil the order then you get some points off. There is a variety of strategies, the game has a certain combinatorial element and it's fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Admittedly I was pretty disappointed with TTR after my first game.  Sure it was easy to pick up and teach, pretty fast to play, but it didn't really feel competitive, there was no real risk involved.  There was very little strategy besides trying to claim the most direct routes first, people don't go out of their way to block others unless it was something they need.  Maybe this was due to the fact that we had only 3 players, I'd imagine the game probably gets more hectic and plays better with 4 or 5.  Anyway, a filler in my eyes at the moment, and not a very satisfying one at that.

RATING: 8
A great game! I think in 20 years this game will be what Monopoly is/was - the "classic" game that everyone has and everyone likes. 

I just wish there was some mechanic to help fix the "stale board" near the end of the game - when the face-up cards are not needed by any particular player, so they never get taken and thus never get refreshed. The players who are looking for a specific color just draw random cards hoping to hit what they are looking for, which takes away some of the fun for me (it's annoying to lose just because you couldn't find that last orange card you were trying to get for 6 turns in a row).

RATING: 8
This is the game (along with Pandemic) that got me interested in board games again. It offers an amazing introduction to the wider world of games and serves as an excellent antidote to the childhood horrors of Monopoly and Risk. With easy to learn rules and great replay value, this game is a must-have. I highly recommend getting the 1910 expansion, with which I rate this game a solid 10. With the 1910 expansion, we play Ticket to Ride all the time and it is still our main go-to game when we're looking to play something.

RATING: 6
Gatway-игра. То есть, из разряда Колонизаторов - только до нас пока ещё в широком масштабе не дошла. Имеем колоду цветных карт, из них можем строить дороги между точками. За длину дорог получаем очки, за выполненные секретные квесты по соединению удалённых точек - тоже очки. Компоненты отличные, но общее впечатления от игры, будто бы она сложнее, чем на самом деле. 

Минусы - довольно проста, но сетап не маленький и количество компонентов превышает идеал довольно сильно.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Deemed as one of the modern gateway games, it's basically rummy beneath the façade of a train theme, though truth be told, the trains only serve as player markers. The game is played on a map of North America and your objective is to complete as many rides (multiple and specific connections between cities) as possible while using different-colored cards as currency to pay for these connections. Though much lighter than Settlers of Catan, I definitely recommend TtR for non-gamers. Strategy is dependent on luck of the draw and plays out wonderfully with a full 5 players. I wouldn't label it to be a must have or a must play. (7 after one play)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.25
Played only on X-Box 360.  I can see why TTR is considered a great gateway game.  It's easy to learn and play.  For a fairly serious gamer, I find that it isn't really tactically deep enough for me to play all the time.  I do like the game enough to get the expansions when they come out on the 360, especially since it seems like they change the game enough to make it play with a bit more depth.  

The bottom line is that there are better "connect cities" games out there that I'd rather be playing (like railroad tycoon!).  But it's a nice distraction online when there aren't real people around to play a board game with.  I doubt I'd play the board game version of this very often at all, but I play the heck out of the console version!
